description: This place was on the list of "to do's" in SF.  As a beer lover I'm in.  Been to lot of places in this country & I have to say this place sucks.   Horrible selection and limited.  Bar tender was not knowledgeable.  Waste of my time and money.  Don't bother
author: Michael W.

description:
The quintessential craft beer dive bar. One of the first craft beer bars in the world. The original Toronado is much smaller than its San Diego equivalent and much more crowded. The bottle list is not very impressive but there is the total steal of being able to get their special edition Lost Abbey Cable Car for $40-50! Multiple vintages were available. Tap and cask list was extensive with just an onslaught of good stuff focusing on local hoppy ales (IPAs).  Ever revolving tap list. I mean $5 pints of Russian River Pliny the Elder? Come on. How can you not love it. 

For newcomers, the staff may be a little rough around the edges.
author: GT W.

description: Worst place I've ever been to in my life! Beertenders are complete a**holes and talk to everyone horrible! Including girls! I know it's a dive bar but no need to curse at ladies for no reason! Will never return here again!
author: Hugh A.

description:
This review is based on the beertenders alone(The taplist, bottles lining the walls and ambiance really deserve a 4+). The staff and service were the worst I have experienced while at a brewery/pub type establishment. 

As if the hipster vibe is not real, the beer tenders are not so courteous to put politely and if you are not ready to take your order or tip a dollar on your tab for one beer, you might as well just leave. Will not be coming back on the service alone, there are way too many good breweries in the area like Cellar Maker, Anchor and the likes who offer exceptional service to match a outstanding taplist. 

Also update the cash only thing, pay the measly service charge. Its San Fran, the tech area of the world, get with the times.
author: Rick A.

description:
This place rules! Had to come twice during a weekend stay. 

It's everything you want in a dive bar PLUS a draft selection you never ever see in real dives. 

Beer only. 

Toronado is definitely a day drinking bar & even better: $1 off all draughts before 6pm

Wish we'd tried the sausages next door - most of the people were eating one with their beer.
author: Lindsay M.

description: NOT MILITARY FRIENDLY! I watched as a bartender of Toronado, wearing a dirty Biker Jacket and a sloppy beard, ejected a Marine after he asked for a sample of beer. This was particularly mentionable because the previous bartender recommended a line of beers that were available for sampling and GLUTEN-FREE. VERY LOW--DOWN FOR A BAR located in a city known for its high veteran count!!
author: N C.

description:
The short:
        Its a dive with a great selection of craft beer. You can get sausages from next door. Bring cash

The Long:
         I have to dress up for work. The bartender (long white hair and a couple teeth missing) must have mistaken me for some sort of snob because he ignored me and started yelling about the glory days of people drinking all night and being able to party with his friends while working. Although I do enjoy raging through the night, it was NOON. I wanted to enjoy a sausage from next door and a beer or two to go with it. I dont think this guy is aware they serve beers at 7% ABV at $10 a piece. I would have loved to order more than 2 beers, but I couldn't get this guy to stop talking about the glory days at other bars. I'm giving this place a 4, bartender a 1. He needs a cape with a big SD on the back for Super Douche.

If you want to serve bud lights to your burn out artsy, musicians who didn't make it crew, don't work in a craft beer bar.
author: Brian R.

description:
How to not be treated rudely at Toronado.
1. Don't be a dick
2. Know what you want to order before you talk to the bartender
3. Pay with cash
4. Tip

This is pretty much how you should conduct yourself every time you visit any bar, with the possible exception of having to pay with cash.

Toronado has one of the best selections of beer of any bar I've ever been to. Sure it's divey.  Sure the bartenders can be gruff. Sure the bathrooms are a little slice of hell.  But, what I think they're getting at is this: if you don't like those types of things then Toronado isn't for you and you can piss off.  Maybe you should just stick to Yard House.
author: TheresNeverAPlan B.

description:
So everyone pretty much knows the reputation here about how rude the bartenders can be. I went for their 28th Anniversary party, and, despite it being busy, the bartenders were hella awesome. The owner, Dave Keene, was beyond gracious the whole day. He even popped open some bottles, including a Batch 2 9L Consecration gifted to him by Russian River Brewery.

Definitely recommend going there.
author: Jerome M.

description: I had friends with me visiting and they heard this was a great spot. Loved the atmosphere, decor, etc. All the makings of a great dive bar. Bartender is horrific. First, he wasn't even behind the bar. He was hanging out with friends. After ten minutes he resurfaced and I said I have 4 drinks to order, two are anchor steam, one a white wine and I was reviewing the drink menu for the last one. He disappeared again. Finally coming back behind the bar he didn't make the drinks I asked for. I again said two anchor steam, one white wine. He said no white wine. I said cool, 3 anchor steam and then I randomly chose a beer from the list in haste. He didn't make the drinks, just produced the beer bottle which was quite large. Asked do I want it? No sorry I didn't know it was that big. I asked for help with the beer menu, he said what do u want I said mild IPAs. He said nothing would suit me here and asked me to leave. My friend went up and asked for 4 anchor steam beers, he demanded we leave the bar. Wtf is wrong with u? When being so inclusive reveals how exclusive you really are.
author: Karen B.

description:
Most number of beers on taps I ever see in a bar! 

Came here specifically for Russian River with a beer dork. There was seats available at the bar when we came at around 1 on a Friday night. 

The bar was pretty busy but not crowded.  And oh I got freaked out the with what the TV was showing halfway. Some guy was dancing around with what looks like a corpse?! So it sobered me right up. 

Bartenders here are really nice! BIG PLUS.
author: Yilin T.

description: Great lineup of draft and bottled beers.  No pretentiousness.  Good Giants crowd as well for games.  Typically have 2 or 3 sour beers on tap too, if thats your thing.
author: Michael H.

description: Hailing from Denver and calling Falling Rock my home beer joint, I was excited to try out San Francisco's most preached about beer bar, pour house, etc. Great beers on draft and nice bottle list. It is a CASH ONLY BAR. Parking was easy at a meter nearby
author: Tony I.

description: I made a quick stop at Toronado on my way to the Painted Ladies. I wish I could've stayed longer. The place is super divey but I knew that already. I love dives btw. The beer list is written on the wall over the bar. By no means am I a beer expert so I just picked a random nitro. I enjoyed it. And it was only 4 bucks. All the beers look reasonably priced. And the bartender was quick and to the point. I liked him. I hope to come back soon to experience the bathroom and have a few more beers haha.
author: Josmauri T.

description: My favorite default bar to go in Haight. It's usually packed, sometimes takes a while to order, but the beer selection is worth it. Get a sausage from next door and ask for Pliny.
author: Anton K.

description: Definitely a locals hangout, fantastic beer selection and destination to get my Pliny the Elder fix on the west coast.
author: Chris T.

description: Pretty sweet beer list, but this bar is loud, crowded, cash-only and doesn't serve food. It wasn't really my scene but that doesn't mean it won't be yours. If you dig beer and are in the mood for a dive, give it a try and see for yourself!
author: Michelle C.

description: This place has a feel of a dive bar that is no longer a dive bar. The walls are covered with little memorabilia and trinkets from the past along with a large selection of draft beer. I had le fin du monde which was a light, citrus beer. The overall vibe is dive bar but the clientele was mostly tech people hanging out after work. I did go around 10pm on a Tuesday so maybe the weekend is better.?.?.?
author: Nicholas H.

description:
This place is a classic. Everyone knows that. I'll summarize a few key facts before coming here. 

1) this place is cash only. There is an ATM inside. 

2) you can bring food from outside. Take advantage of that. There are mexican, vegan, and sausage options within spitting distance.

3) don't ask for Pliny the younger for the hell of it
author: Robert F.

description: I don't understand the hype. Sure its a great tap spot, but with the crowds and lack of space, this is not somewhere that I like to frequently visit. Sure the selcetion of beers is nice, but when you can't hear the person next to you and finding a seat is impossible, the only thing Iend up doing is chugging the beer I just bought in order to go to the next place.
author: Brittini S.

description:
Crowded. Check.
Bouncer. Check.
Beers on tap. Check.
All sorts of beer memorabilia on the wall. Check.
Cash only. Crap, but there's an ATM.

Toronado is a dive bar on Haight St if you didn't already know.  The place was busy when we managed to walk in and busy when we stumbled out.  There are plenty of TV flatscreens to satisfy you and plenty of beer served here.  My cousin and I were in search of Russian River's Toronado 25 but that wasn't meant to be.  Oh well.  This place is still a great place to grab a drink in the middle of the day.  No judgment here.
author: Trina D.

description: Very good beer selection.  Bartenders are not very personable though. I asked for recommendation of best sour they have and he said idk I just got here.  Smh. Not professional. But overall we went for good beer and they had an awesome selection.
author: Angie B.

description:
This place is for a true craft beer lover; for those who appreciate the complexities of beer, rather than the atmosphere they are in when drinking it. I read many negative reviews about the customer service (granted have only been here once) but the lady serving behind the bar was holding it down by herself and was very helpful.

3 out of 5 for atmosphere (small, a bit dated, divey, and tough to have a conversation, even on a Tuesday at 4pm.)

4 out of 5 for location. It's tucked away, but right on a bus route.

4 out of 5 for customer service. Only one person working happy hour, but she was friendly and efficient.

5 out of 5 for beer. All types of beer. About 30+ on tap and listed in alphabetical order by brewery. Rare bottle list and decent happy hour specials. $1 off drafts.

Two things: They don't serve food, so you'll need to eat before or go to sausage place next door (Rosamunde Sausage Grill.) And it's CASH only. Tap into that rubberband bank.

Don't bring a client or a first date here (unless he's/ she's wearing leather chaps) but this is a great watering hole for those serious about the craft of brewing.
author: Kari P.

description: We are BIG FANS of Toronado.. down-to-earth bartenders and clientele - I don't think you'd ever possibly get upset about the people around you - j'adore!
author: Veronica J.

description: Who doesn't like a bar where the bartenders don't tolerate bullshit. I've seen people refused service for being too snotty about having to wait. You come here, it's always at least 2 deep at the bar, the guys know what they are doing. Just wait your turn, it will come. When it does, know what you want to order, remember that 2 deep business? This place is always hoppin' so they don't really have time for you to umm and ahh over what you want after waiting 5 minutes to order. If you're ever in doubt, get the Pliney! Oh, and make sure you have cash!
author: Sarah S.

description: I would give 3.5 stars if it would allow. The ambiance is nice, the beer selections is great. It's small and intimate, there's interesting decor and TVs for sports. They allow dogs which is nice. The reason they lose stars is because they are cash only which sucks. (They do have an ATM, but who wants to pay a fee?) and the bartender was rude. I asked for a Belgian suggestion and he couldn't give me one because he's a "hop guy". If you work in a bar that serves a variety of beer I would suggest being able to give selections of all the different varietys you serve.
author: danyle w.

description:
When I first experienced the horrendous customer service at Toronado, I took it personally. Well, not too personally, since it technically happened to my friend and I was behind him watching the whole exchange. But personally enough to think they had a problem with my friend for some reason that was beyond me.

But then I log onto Yelp a few days later, and I realize the bartenders were not just assholes to my friend, they are assholes to EVERYONE. Made me feel a bit better.

Let me explain the scene. My boyfriend, our friend and I decide to grab a drink at Toronado while my BF and I were vacationing in the city. When we get there, (strangely enough) the front door guy checking IDs was very nice and even cracked a joke with us. Which I think might be why we were all so shocked as to what happened inside.

We go up to the bar, it's fairly crowded (it's a Saturday night, after all). We all decided what we wanted right as we got in so we wouldn't hold anyone up. My friend goes up to the bar to place our orders - one beer for him, another kind for my boyfriend, and the pomegranate cider for me.

The bartender begrudgingly takes the order, but apparently doesn't hear my friend order the second beer. My cider comes up first and then the first beer comes right after. My friend hands me my cider and then asks the bartender which beer it is that he was just handed. Because the bartender didn't hear the second beer order, he looks my friend straight in the face and says "Take a f***ing sip of it. Does it taste like cider or a f***ing beer?"

WOW. Because of a slight miscommunication, Mister Bartender gets his panties in a bunch and decides to cuss at customer. Unbelievable (but actually kind of believable after reading other reviews).

This place isn't Dick's Last Resort. It's shtick is not to have staff who are complete assholes to customers and have no regards for other people. To the bartender who looks like a cross between a wanna be Hells Angel and one of Snow White's seven dwarves, go work somewhere where you don't have to interact with people.

While this place has a good beer selection, the lack of polite (or at least tolerant) staff merits it less than a star.
author: Tressa R.

description:
Skip day adventures stop #3

Because every once in a while there's that day when you're not "feeling well" in the morning, but then undergo a miraculous recovery just after calling in sick. Strange, I know, but it is a phenomenon familiar to many.

A random Tuesday was such a day for me. So after touring Anchor Brewing Company & grabbing a dog next door at Rosamunde (hey, we all have different ways of getting better after not "feeling well"), it was finally time to check out Toronado with a beer nerd cohort.

Finally, because this was somehow my 1st time here. I guess I don't get into the City enough. Well, gotta say I really liked it, for the vibe & the tap selection. It felt divey, Devil-may-care with Heavy Metal blaring & a beertender who looked like the sort of guy who has a switchblade in his pocket.

Of course, the list of beers on tap was impressive. For a bonus, it was Happy Hour, which meant $1 off everything across the board. Like I need extra incentive to drink more beer in the afternoon. Needed or not, at least 1 extra pint can be credited to Happy Hour. Man, why did I not get to Toronado sooner?

I can definitely see how Toronado may not be everyone's cup of tea & I'm guessing this place is a completely different animal at night. But for a lazy afternoon of drinking Happy Hours beers, the vibe here is right up my alley. I'm looking forward to a future day when I'm not "feeling well" again. I will be back.
author: John M.

description: This bar is one of my favorite in SF. They serve a LOT of beers, for all tastes, and the atmosphere of the bar is just unique. It feels like the perfect combination of belgium and america. Highly recommended!
author: Guillaume G.

description:
Not sure what Rick T is referring to, but, having been to this place dozens of times, I haven't once seen a sign indicating patrons should order by number. In fact, there are no numbers on the beer board. Maybe I'm missing something.

This place is awesome. Great beer selection. 

Update: Seems like Rick T and Logan T have suspiciously similar and error filled complaints. Logan's problem was beer week was in early to mid-February - not 5 days ago. I suspect FAKE NEWS!
author: Vincent R.

description: Came in with my work crew after a staff appreciation day around 2pm. Middle-aged female bartender was incredibly rude to our group over and over  and made us feel like we were a major inconvenience to her day. There were 14 of Us ready to enjoy some drinks and spend our money here, but she was so rude, we left.
author: Kassi K.

description: The beer selection here is decent. My experience here has been terrible however. I was there around 7:00pm and the place was half full. After drinking a bit, I took a 15 minute break to wait for my friends to arrive, and the bartender came over and told me I need to order more alcohol because "this isn't a library". I explained I had a group arriving in 10 minutes, and wanted to pace myself until they got there. The bartender then started yelling at me that I had gone long enough without alcohol and that I needed to order more. I found this pretty patronizing, and I doubt I'll be back.
author: Justin R.

description: Superb beer menu, strict bartenders, terrible loos, 85% dudes and the ability to bring in food from next door Rosamunde Sausage Grill makes this place always an interesting time. For as good the beer list is, the restrooms are twice as bad. I can't believe the health department is shutting down Tu Lan and Sam Wo and not this place for those bathrooms. But then again, that would be ashamed because this truly is a hops sanctuary and palace for beer lovers. I always fret when trying to enter this place but am always pleased once I get my first beer. Keep it going guys!
author: Brian J.

description:
Cool place for craft beer and there's so many reviews, i don't have much to say except one thing: why does it stink so bad in there?! it smells like BO...can't you put a few fresheners here and there? 

Also bring cash, and don't expect great customer service from the bartender, it almost seems like they like being known as rude or something
author: Amy Y.

description:
When I was in my early 20s I was pretty wowed by the # of beers here.  I brought my brother here, my dad here, I came here a lot.  I was even mugged as I was leaving one night.

Now that I'm older, though, being treated like a human being has became a higher priority.  So when I came in here tonight and ordered the "Ommegang Fleur", then my bartender proceeded to berate me about only ordering things on the menu, then refused to serve me for several minutes, I almost left.  Ultimately he came back and I explained I wanted the "Ommegang Fleur De Houblon", which is on the menu, in fact, it's the only Ommegang beer on the menu, he yelled at me some more, and I got my beer.

Anyway, enough is enough.  I'd rather pay $1 more to drink some place without assholes that doesn't smell like a frat house.  About a dozen places easily are better beer places than this.  Within a mile there's: Zeitgeist, Magnolia, Black Sands, Barrel Head, Gestalt Haus, The Beer Hall.
author: Jon E.

description:
Probably my favorite beer bar in the city. Lots of excellent options, average price, good place to meet friends for a drink. It can be loud and crowded but what do you expect at a dive bar? Service is what it is. You might have to wait for a beer if it's busy, and you might have a beer snob pouring your drinks. I wouldn't have it any other way, really. 

They don't have food, but they allow you to bring stuff in. Pick up a sausage at Rosamunde or a taco or slice of pizza nearby if you're hungry.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
Paid for 2 beers with $100 - received $8 back in change. Beware the scam-artist bartenders.
"Oh, sorry about that."
author: Daniel F.

description:
Toronado is heaven to any serious micro brew drinker. dozens of brews on tap, even piner the elder. ambience isn't much, just a long bar and some tables. the brews are the stars here. drafts seem local but didn't recognize some of them.

pour:
-deutsches stout(4)
-great value, smooth and strong
-just stopped at one to be safe.

drips:
-quick, friendly service
-toronado looks like a dive, brew is lst class.
author: Victor G.

description:
Who can complain when Pliny the Elder is on tap?!  

I got to notch it down a few stars for the rude bartending to new visitors.  I've brought two out-of-town guests to Toronado for the famous Pliny and each time the bartender has treated them with contempt.  When one of the guests wanted a soda as she didn't drink alcohol, he blew her off like she had asked for a bud light.  I get that Toronado only serves beer, but come on! Easy mistake.

Today, my dad was so excited to be at Toronado that he started looking to buy a t-shirt. He was obviously eyeing the store shirts behind the bar and the bartender ignored him (and it was 12:30 in the afternoon!). When he reached to pick one up for size, the bartender yelled at him to get out from behind the bar.
author: Abby B.

description: There is nothing appealing about this place. The bouncer is incredibly rude. Though they have a wide beer selection, so do plenty of other places nearby that don't have all Toronado's problems. A supposed selling point is that you can bring in food from the sausage restaurant next door. Good luck juggling your food though as the bouncer harasses you and demands that you take your ID out of your wallet. Chances are you will run into this bouncer: he was there two years ago when we came here, and we found him annoying at the time; we decided to give the bar another shot just now but were disappointed that the bouncer is just as rude as before and even negative yelp reviews have not prompted the bar to replace him, so we ended up leaving rather than put up with this smelly, cash-only place. In 21st century San Francisco, there is no legitimate excuse to be cash only. I might put up with the inconvenience of paying in cash if the service were better or the product was worth it, but this bar just doesn't come close to offering anything to justify it.
author: David S.

description:
I daresay this is the best beer bar I've ever been to. AMAZING tap selection and they even have a happy hour?!  The beers I like are always the most expensive on the list, and their reasonable prices on top of happy hour made this drinking experience downright cheap. I had such a hard time deciding, and the saucy (in the best way possible) bartender let me try whatever I wanted to help me decide.

The vibe was very chill and friendly, the bartender seemed to know a lot of the people at the counter which gave it a Cheers kinda of feeling. Diggin it.

Be sure to grab a sausage next door at Rosamunde - wild boar is SO GOOD.

I'll definitely be coming back here when I'm in town.
author: Liz L.

description:
Only in San Francisco you can find a place that's a dive, cash only, has great beer, where bartender doesn't give a crap and metal music is blaring from the speakers; practically preventing anyone from having a conversation at all. But yea, somehow this crazy concept actually works. Must be from all the good beer that's poured here. 

Even though this is surely not my type of a place, and even if I lived in SF I can not see myself being a regular,  I can appreciate one of the best beer cards I have seen ever. Russian River is always on tap and the chances are you will find at least couple of brews from the region that are virtually impossible to find elsewhere. As for the service it has all been said before so not worth repeating but I can add that the bartender left his post couple of times to have a cigarette outside, leaving no one behind the bar. 

Go here if you like beer, bring cash, get a sausage from next door, and enjoy the weirdness. Like I said...only in San Francisco.
author: Vedran V.

description:
To the consistently rude bartender who pretends to not be from the Midwest:
Stop. Being. Unfriendly. 

Here's his current stats:

Steven Wright impressionistic existence
Purposeful 'no-shower' look
Unsolicited entitled attitude
No help when chatting about beer


Every time I come to this bar and he's the only one working, I try different strategies to make myself like this person. All have failed. 

Please fire him and send him back to the shithole farm town that probably doesn't like him either.
author: christopher p.

description:
Toronado (n):  A dive bar with great beer and awful staff.  

This bar has simply the best selection of beer in San Francisco.  Pliny the Elder is always on tap.  Lots of other great beers with a heavy bias towards California microbrews.  

The staff can be a bit variable.  The owner and his wife are lovely.  That cannot be said for most of the other staff.  In particular, there's one who is a textbook example of bad service.  Rude, inaccurate, unwelcoming, etc.  Oh well, it's good beer that's not so expensive.

It can be a fun and friendly vibe with lots of locals and tourists.  It can be quite busy so try to go at off times.

Bathroom is super dirty.  Skip it if at all possible.
author: Ian P.

description:
- Locale Destination - 
It's on Haight St and between Fillmore St and Steiner St in Lower Haight, San Francisco. 

Nicer "dive bar" with cool and hip "San Francisco" vibe and interesting craft beers. "Dive bar" here is meant for "neighborhood bar", but not the definitions you usually assume (trashy, cheap, so laid back etc.).. Nicer here. They have a long bar with seating, tables, and small seating area back side. Staff (all male - I think hot "female" bartender/beer pourer would increase their sales ;p) were cool. Parking around here is tough. 

Dive bar with tons of craft beers... They rotate them often. Cool!!





- Gluttony Expedition - 
Hefweizen : mild, smooth, medium body, little earthy nose. Not bad!





- Conqueror's Deduction - 
Price is a little bit expensive for dive bar - very common for SF in general - unlike the amazing Oregon micro brewery scenes, but good place for craft beers.
author: Akiko I.

description:
Toronado
SF: Lower Haight
Saturday March 3, 2012
Three Stars

[SF#5]

The ambiance of SF Tornado can pretty much be summed up by this article I found: http://sanfrancisco.grubstreet.com/2012/03/toronado-bartenders-jerks.html

and 

http://www.sandiegoreader.com/weblogs/feast/2012/mar/01/a-tale-of-two-toronados/

I will summarize:

Being a SD resident, we wanted to visit the original Toronado but original is by far inferior because SF Beer-Pourers treat their patrons like $&*^.

Our experience:

We found a table which was exciting on Saturday afternoon. The beer selection was standard but I saw nothing of ooh and ahh status.  Why SD is better:  There is no Stale Smell of Beer on unwashed floors or the Deafening Jams of the Metallica Anthology.  There is not a Single Graffiti-Ridden Bathroom and they let me have the option of using a credit card.  Don't be a Cash Only Bar - we live in modern society.
author: Leonard L.

description:
Wow what can I say,

Horrible service and warm beer. 

Would like to give 0 stars, but I can not!
author: Lala T.

description: The rudest place I've ever been to. The bouncer literally yelled at my pregnant friend, and brought her to tears. Just read that sentence again. How can you support an establishment like that in good conscience​.
author: S. L.

description: I went to Toronado because I'm into US craft beer, and I'd heard they have a large number of drafts.  I was happy to find an English bartender, but things quickly turned bad.  The bartender was abusively rude.  Okay, okay, so get that attitude is this place's quirk, and it's what to expect, and that's sort of fine... until they start giving you the wrong order.  The bartender served the wrong beer three times.  The first time, he reluctantly poured a random other one for me.  The second time, he swore at me, refused to replace it and verbally abused me, and the third time, he ignored me.  Beer people will probably want to seek out this place, but they seriously shouldn't bother.  I know Toronado is a chain, and I don't know what the owners think of all this.  I'd love to be recommending this place to others, but I'll be doing exactly the opposite.
author: Ian B.

description:
This is THE best beer craft beer bar in the city. If anyone says different, they don't know what they're talking about. Pliny the Elder on tap literally always, regular hard to find(and insanely cheap) beers from Almanac and Modern Times, nevermind the dozens of other ones. Oh: And they're mostly cheaper than buying them from the store(if you can even find them in the store).

A lot of the negative reviews focus on "bad service". Screw those people. I can read their reviews and tell exactly what went wrong, and it's not on the staff. The rules to having a lovely Toronado experience are simple.

1) Have your money ready and not wadded up. If it's early in the day, the prices are $1 less than the menu says.
2) Know what you want to order, and say it clearly. Or at least the genre of the beer you want.
3) Do not order a Miller or a Cocktail or a shot. They don't have either.

The guys behind the bar are awesome. The drinks are awesome and cheap. They don't give a crap if you bring food in. The only thing that's not awesome is the occasional music selection(metal, ugh) but get over it. This is your new home and you should just accept it.
author: Michael C.

description: Place stank to high heaven of sweat and urine. Awful music. Even worse service. No head on the beer, looked awful, so asked for a straw/spoon to stir and put some air into it, the big bearded oaf behind the bar refused and in general his attitude stank as much as the bar. They can't even pronounce "Pliny" correctly. They pretend to know about beer, avoid this place!
author: Simon P.

description:
You may have an affordable and wonderful selection of craft beer, but being rude for no reason is inexcusable. 

I was recently there on a bar crawl with a large group of people I didn't know. The bar was somewhat busy so I stood behind the patrons at the bar with my hand raised halfway. One of the bartenders walks over and says, "The fact that you have your hand raised means I won't help you," and walks away. I wasn't yelling. I wasn't being rude. I was merely making myself a bit easier to see.  I'm am one of the politest people you will ever encounter in a bar and I've never been treated like dirt before for being polite. 

The other bartender finally came by and poured me a Pliny The Elder. I tipped him, drank my beer and walked out the front door, never to return.
author: Tara H.

description: The server was rude before I even spoke a word and I witnessed the him getting surly with another customer, someone with an accent, perhaps a tourist, who offended by asking a question about the beer on tap. It wasn't crowded. They staff was not especially busy.  I learned later that this place deliberately cultivates a reputation for bad service. If you know the protocol and get smug satisfaction from watching servers bully those who don't, this is the place for you. For those who seek a great selection of craft beer and servers who share your enthusiasm and are willing to talk to you about it, go to Mikkeller or one of the many excellent tap rooms in SF or Oakland.
author: Vicky S.

description:
Here's the deal, I've seen all those punk bands on the bartenders t-shirt so while your trying to figure out what to order and being ignored, he's served me two beers already so get it together, figure out what you want before you go in and we won't read your whiny yelp review on this website.

Get 'The Blind Pig' by Russian River and thank me later.
author: Mark C.

description:
Go here on a weekday, avoid it like the plague on a weekend. 

I'm not a beer snob, so I can't excuse the shitty attitude from the bartender in the sake of "BUT THEY HAVE ALL THESE BEERS". I've been on a weekday, and while it was crowded, there were still a few seats at the bar and the bartender was actually pretty nice. Popped in on Friday night, and the place was super packed. Expected, sure, so no biggie. My friend is a tiny, cute, quiet, sweet girl, and she was trying to order a round for all four of us but couldn't remember all the names off the top of her head (we each got a different brew). So it was like: 

Sweet friend: "Can I have a ___" 
Asshole bartender: "WHAT ELSE"
Sweet friend: "And.. what was yours called again?" *turns around to ask my other friend*
Asshole bartender: "GET YOUR ORDER TOGETHER AND HAVE IT READY" *storms away* 

I get that it's a dive, and it's busy, but that attitude is so out of pocket. It literally would have taken a couple of seconds for my friend to confirm which beer he wanted. He came back with the same shitty attitude, and she still tipped him. 

Also factor in the weird smell that's always there and the fact it's cash only, and this place is just meh for me.
author: Angela L.

description:
Pliney the elder on tap! If you are a double IPA fan, you won't want to miss this place. If you like beer, you have to come here. 

Here's the step-by-step: Order a sausage next door, set your timer for the 10-15 min wait, come in here, get a beer, timer goes off, go back for sausage, bring it back, drink - don't sip your beer. Uber home.
author: Bessie T.

description:
I used to love this place, came here to watch game 6 and eat a sausage. Someone told me to leave because I didn't order a beer yet and I "couldn't just watch the game"

Seriously are you that cash hungry you can't wait for me to get my food before I order a drink. Thanks for making me and my date feel like shit
author: Jake G.

description:
If you're wanting to try lots of beer and you have lots of cash, this is the place for you. 

If you're looking for friendly staff, this is not the place for you. The guy checking cards at the door is not very friendly. In general, he was rude when asking for our cards, and looked at us suspiciously. After he flipped his finger at our cards a couple times, he gave them back to us with no instruction on where to sit or if we should seat ourselves. The beer we had was good. The atmosphere was just not very friendly whatsoever. 

If they have a beer you know you want, you might like it here. Otherwise, I don't see the draw.
author: Nathaniel F.

description: After hearing the hype about this place, as a beer lover/borderline snob, I was so excited to finally be able to visit!  I was so disappointed to find that this was like a college bar clientele-wise.  The only thing different was a better beer list.  Prices were decent/a little cheaper than most Bay Area beer joints, so that was a plus, but the loud, rude patrons did not make it worth it.  Also, for some reason, I expected a more unique tap selection?  Most of what they had was beer I can get anywhere else with an extensive tap selection.  We had Russian River Pliny the Elder, Damnation, La Folie, and something else.  Well, I came, I drank, I happily left after two-ish beers.  I would not come back unless the crowd thinned out substantially.
author: Rose L.

description:
Coming from LA, bars... even so called "dive" bars can be filled with pretentious people.... not here though! 

It was my first time in SF and was staying in the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood. I was looking for some cool bars to hit up while I was there and found this little gem on New Years Eve. I mean.... $4 beers, rare ones that you usually can't find all in one spot, how could I resist?! (fyi: this place is CASH only!)

I chose to order:
-Allagash White
-Dogfish Head 120 minute (wow!)
-Pliney The Elder

This place is what it is. A bar. Don't expect a bunch of done-up snoots, just down to Earth, REAL people looking to have a good time, throw back some drinks or just get smashed. I love the Mom & Pop feel of this place. It's hard to get the bartenders attention though, especially when it's busy.... so definitely know what you want to order or they will leave your sight in a heartbeat. 

Everyone keeps talking about the sausage place next door, but I chose to grub on some pizza at Mythic Pizza which is on the opposite side of the bar. (some of the biggest & best pizza I've had, but I'll save that for another review)

Whether you live here or are visiting from out of town, this is one of those MUST GO to bars in SF, you don't want to pass this place up! Prost!
author: Juanita D.

description: Cool bar, cool atmosphere, cool beers, cool prices. I'm from New Orleans where everything is cheaper than it is in San Francisco and I honestly thought some of the craft beers here were at better prices than I could find in New Orleans . Had heard from lots of San Francisco locals that this was a place worth checking out and I'm happy I did . If you want good beers at good prices go here !
author: Alissa T.

description: Amazing selection of beer on tap (Pliney!!) and very nice bartenders. Just remember to bring cash!
author: Hannah H.

description:
Kind of disappointing. Big beer guy coming in from Boston (much better beer scene in SF in general), and nothing really shot out on the draft list, save for Pliny.  Got a Pliny, and I felt like the keg wasn't properly maintained or the lines were dirty or something, not quite right.  Straight from the breast at Russian River has little in common with what I tasted.  

Ambiance is divey, filled with younger dudes than your typical vibe.  Not a huge female presence.  CASH ONLY of course, which is always annoying.  Came on a Friday night, incredibly loud, which I am cool with, but always good to be aware of what you are getting into.
author: Kevin B.

description: According to my ten days research. Toronado is the best bar in S.F. Beer selection is great and prices are /
author: Janne N.

description:
Loads of people recommended this place to us, being craft beer lovers. Selection is huge and great. 4 hand pumps and a range of great local beers. Cheap too - especially by Aussie standards. 

Happy hour seems pretty great with $5 beers. 

However... The bloke pouring the beers was a total jerk and super rude. Don't come here unless you're into craft beer. Even then, be prepared to be treated like dirt. He was ok to us, but yelled at a bunch of other customers in front of us. Not nice at all. Just be nice to people dude. Sheesh.
author: Gemma H.

description:
I love the Toronado in San Diego so when I was in San Francisco I decided to give this place a try.

I went during the middle of the afternoon and expected this place to be empty (but it was packed).

The bartender had a bit of an attitude. There was a rare beer that I've only seen (rarely) in bottle and mentioned that I was surprised to see it on tap. I ordered it and another uncommon beer for my wife. The bartender much nicer now let me know he approved of my choices and flashed what appeared to be a gang sign to the other guy working there.

I don't know if it is common to need to prove beer knowledge to get good service here, but it appeared to be true for me. The bartenders were awesome to me after that offering tasters/suggestions for other rare/uncommon beers. They did not seem to be pleased with people that didn't know what they wanted.

The bathroom was interesting and I enjoyed reading the walls.

I totally understand why some people love this place and why some people hate it.
author: Thomas F.

description:
5 stars for the beer selection.
5 stars for all the awesome taps and decorations on the wall.
1 star for service and friendliness. 
1 star for cleanliness.
Overall, I will be nice and give this place 4 stars.

If you love craft beer, you will love this place. They have over 40 quality beers on tap. 

If you are bar hoping in SF, I would recommend you stop by, have a good beer, and then go on your way to the next destination.

As some people have commented, the bouncer and bartenders are not very nice. I came on a Friday night, and it must have been 90% dudes in this place. Also, it seems like the bar caters and is visited by a specific type of clientele.  I prefer more eclectic bars, the only thing I liked about this place was the beer and decorations.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Good place for tasting beer, if you like Orval beer (a really good belgian beer) you can find some here! That's cheap, you can bring some food even though sometimes it's kinda crowded, but with OK people. 

Pros : a lot of choice of beers, cheap, you can bring food, ideal place for watching a game
Cons : I havent  seen or heard the server behind me, he just started yelling "EXCUSE ME" in a very agressive way.
author: Lino M.

description:
One of my new favorites when I am in San Francisco.

First, they do not have food, but you can get something from one of the food places nearby and eat it there while you drink. We got Ike's and ate in the back room.

Beer selection is pretty good. I can't say they have a lot to choose from, but they definitely have some good choices. The bartenders are very cool and the patrons are even better.

The two times I was in here was near the middle of the day so I don't know how it gets at night, but there is a decent size crown even if you wander in around 2-5 pm.
author: Josh Y.

description: Warm beer and rude service. Took about twenty minutes to get a moderately busy bar tender's attention and once I got it was treated poorly. Asked to view the shirts on display and was charged for the shirt, when displeased and tried to switch out bartender was clearly disgruntled and threw replaced on bar. Would not recommend unless you want a warm, overpriced beer in a "local" area. Just rude, pretentious, and "hipster" without the qualifications to boast over.
author: Megan C.

description:
I had a GREAT time at Toronado. This is definitely my kind of bar! Paul was super helpful in helping me select a beer based on my tastes as I'm not a fan of IPA's. Samples were offered at every inquiry. I ended up with more than a few Death and Taxes and a gorgeous Chocolate Stout. 

Everyone was super friendly, accommodating, knowledgeable and fun. Great place for beer lovers.
author: Cheeks L.

description:
Not a fan of beer, except for the super sour ones (which I always liken to kombucha). That being said the bar staff was able to tailor to my very specific taste buds, which gave me a lot of faith in their brew selection.

I was a big fan of the grungy, jovial vibe -- felt kinda like a friend's garage or basement in the best possible way. Despite my preference for hard liquor, I would come back -- particularly since it's located right next door to Rosamunde's Sausages (which you can order to-go to eat at Toronado -- they have a very flexible BYOF policy).
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Divey dive bar in the middle of a commercial area of a quiet neighborhood in the Lower Haight.  Lots of art on the walls provides conversation if you run out, and a small back room can accommodate a larger group, as we were (9 people).  Waiting for our dinner reservation to come about, we came in here for a drink to pass the time.  The service was average to downright slow - about half our group got their drinks right away, while myself and a few others had to wait 10 minutes (standing at the bar).  There was only one bartender, but she was certainly taking her time doing everything else but serve drinks.  I felt that even with only 1 person working, the drinks could have gotten out faster (as that is the priority in a BAR).

As for the selection, it was varied - if I drank beer, I probably would be impressed.  I drink cider, which they had 2 of.  The pomegranate cider on tap was pretty good, at an average price.  All in all, nothing really stood out for me here - average bar with a decent selection of beers, but below average service.
author: Ben K.

description: I'm sure the beer would have been delicious. Only stayed for one pint because the bartender service was so deplorable. Had received recommendations from friends and had to tell them that it was an unfortunate choice.
author: Carey D.

description:
Did a quick turnaround trip to the Bay recently and was recommended to try out this place per some fellow beer aficionado buddies of mine.  I didn't have too much time to hang out there, but it was worth the visit.  

Located in Lower Haight, it's a chill place - casual, rock music, chill crowd with nice people.  I honestly thought they would have more selection, but the variety was not bad at all.  They also carry some good old Ballast from SD.  Lately, I've been trying to get my bf into craft beer and he's slowly...but surely...catching on.  So, I ordered him a Pliny the Elder and I tried out a pumpkin barleywine (which was delish for the record!).  Paid $14 for both...which was a little pricey I thought.

If you are into craft beers...I recommend this place.  If not...you might not enjoy it as much since that's all they serve there.  With the exception of ciders (but then again, why would you go to Toronado for that??)

TIPS-
-Bring your ID...you'll get carded at the door
-ONLY CASH!!  They don't accept cards here. There is an atm inside too FYI.
-It's a blue building next to a taller green one

Enjoy!
author: Theresa N.

description:
Overview:  One of my favorite bars in SF.  Definitely a dive bar with an eclectic mix of patrons.

Here is my review in "sh*t sandwich" form:

Praise: Awesome selection of beers and reasonable prices.   I personally love that they have Pliny on tap for $5-6/pint

Criticism: Cash only blows (because I never carry cash on me so I have to take a special trip to the ATM when I plan to go).  Also the bartenders are rude.  This does not bother me so much, but some of my out of town friends have been offended.

Praise: Bathrooms are clean.  Lots of seating.  Location is great with Rosamunde is right next door.  Get a sausage and then head over to Toronado to grab a beer.   

If you like dive bars, beer, and have some cash go check out Toronado.
author: Paul W.

description: The vibe in this place reminds me of Zeitgeist.  If you're trying to get yourself a beer, this has to be one of the best spots in SF.  Naturally, it's best when you can catch a time where it isn't super crowded.  They've got quite the selection, as expected.
author: Charles C.

description: Stumbled on this bar last night for the Warriors game. It wasn't too crowded, which is great. Endless beer selection. Only 1 TV though.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Of course a micro beer connoisseur's Mecca. 

I get it, you have incredible beer with an incredible environment for a beer bar... both are top notch. I love the beer, the environment but I dislike the bartenders. Be aware that you are going to Toronado for the beer and not the service. 

Pliny will most likely be on tap.
author: Matt R.

description: Rude service and cash only. There is nothing redeeming about this bar, except that it doesn't smell as bad as it looks.
author: Jason T.

description: Would be 0 stars if I could. Worst experience. Great selection, beyond below average service. Bartender and door guy were super rude and whiny. Don't waste your time.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Dive-y bar with an exceptional beer selection on tap. They have a deal worked out with Rosamunde's sausages next door, so you can BYOS (sausage); Highly recommended, killer combo. 

SF staple but always a bit loud.
author: Caroline L.

description: Cool tourist or craft beer knurd stop in SF....... Great tap selection and the doorman was awesome to let our Frenchie in, he really enjoyed it !
author: Donovan A.

description:
OK, let me break this down for everyone who does not seem to be clear on what this place is.

It's first and foremost a beer bar.  This is for beer geeks, by beer geeks.  If you don't already have an obsessive knowledge of styles and brands, then you may have a bad time. 

You are not a unique snowflake that needs a personalized recommendation.  You know why?

BECAUSE ALL THE FREAKING BEER IS GOOD.  
Why would they have such a good reputation as one of the best beer bars in a beer crazy city, even after all these years? Because they do not put beers they think are bad on tap! 
Live a little! Pick a beer at random! Most beers on the board have the style listed with them.  Typically, their list is skewed towards Belgians, sours, and limited run/lesser known beers from local breweries. They always have at least two or three IPAs, so all the dude bros won't get too scared.

How to have a positive ordering experience:
When you arrive, stare at the board till your eyes fall out.  Before you make eye contact, or hell, even angle your body towards the bar, know what the fuck you want.  Only then should you stand politely yet firmly with your eyes ready to make contact and order.  Do not talk to your friends. Do not keep looking at the board.  Don't look at your phone. Do not raise your hand.  They see you, trust me.
Just wait. Like a person.
Have the cash in your hand ready to go. Yell your order then put a please on the end.  You will be rewarded with a beer! Then tip!

Yes, it's crowded as balls on Friday and Saturday. I live a few blocks away and I don't even think about going on a weekend.  (That's what NocNoc is for)
Yes, it's a loud crowded neighborhood bar.  It does smell a bit sometimes.  There are often unsavory characters.  It's a REAL dive bar. The beer is worth it, I think.

If none of the above sounds like your bag, go to The Monk's Kettle.  They are also an excellent bar but it's much more friendly for people who can't get their act together (or want this "service" you speak of).  You will also pay an additional $2-$4 per beer, but it's sort of apples and oranges to compare Toronado to Monk's Kettle.
author: Natalie R.

description:
Great place to head for a drink after work or a night out!

Pros: friendly and accommodating bartenders, great beer selection, and entertaining bathroom graffiti. Great wall decor, complete with taxidermy deer. 

Cons: a little warm in the back section, somewhat small (but loud and fun if that's what's you're looking for!)
author: Marilyn M.

description: After all my years in San Francisco, I finally made it to Toronado. I came for the SF Beer Week Barley Wine Festival. I had such a great time. The bartenders were excellent.  I had about 15 small ounces of Magnolia's Thunderpussy, Anchor Steam's Barley Wine and a few others. I had arrived early at 10:00 am because I was told it can be a circus on BW day. By 2:00pm I needed to have something to eat. I am glad they allow outside food.  I'll be back...
author: Infodiva B.

description:
A must visit for any beer lover. It's dirty and dive-y and I love it! If you think that Budweiser and Miller a great beers then this isn't the place for you as your tastes aren't sophisticated enough to appreciate the variety of brews here. There are probably 50+ brews on tap.

We saw a few dog visitors in the bar. You can bring your own food in. Usually crowded. Cash only.
author: Erin L.

description:
You gotta love a fancy craft beer bar, dressed in a hoodie and dirty chucks. They have beer I can't find just anywhere...for about 6 bucks. Its the best of both worlds. They're one of the few places that does hand pulled pints on a beer engine. My Freewheel IPA was everything I wanted it to be. With beers like Pliny and Batch 0001 on tap, you know they mean business. 

Getting into the Haight - and parking - can be a bit of a pain in the ass - but oh well.
author: Kevin D.

description:
One of my co-workers recommended this place, since he is a beer enthusiast. Knowing nothing really about beer, I decided to trust his instinct.

My coworker mentioned the beer tasting - you can ask to sample some beers here if you want, which is awesome IMO! They give you samples in a shot glass. My friends and I ended up getting the Chocolate Beer - so good. A dark beer, which I guess I'm not a fan of usually, but with chocolate it tasted so yummy and interesting.

Best tip is that you can bring over hot dogs from next door (Rosamunde Grill) and eat them in the bar. Everyone does it. Gourmet hot dogs + beer = perfect Friday night. There is even some staff member that takes away your hot dog trays and brings them back next door!!

Also, if you are not a fan of hot dogs, there was this lady with a cart that came into the bar, selling Epanadas. They were kinda small, but great if you don't wanna go next door for hot dogs/don't wanna wait for the hot dogs. 

Place gets kinda loud though, so you have to shout. Also, it's hard finding seats here since everyone seems to come at the same time and no one seems to have the courtesy to get up once they're done. Having too much fun socializing with friends on a Friday night.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
We stumbled on this bar while on a small walking tour of San Francisco, because we drove in, and I didn't want to move my damn car when eating all the places I had mapped out.  As I researched it, I discovered wow, this is supposed to be one hell of a good bar.  Partner and I are sort of beer nerds. Poor beer nerds. And this bar is perfect.  They allow you to bring food in.  There's a sausage joint next door. 

Extensive beer and I think some wine selection.  Giants game was on, they lost. I didn't have any interaction with the staff, other than them picking up my empty beer glasses.  There wasn't much description of beer on the ordering board, but they have some pretty hard to find stuff on tap.  They'll give you a sample if you're nice.
author: Alex S.

description:
What's not to love about this place? Graffiti in the bathroom? Check. Unpretentious crowd & atmosphere? Check. Awesome draft & bottle selection of craft beers? Check. Bring your own food in from anywhere you want? I had no idea until the bartender (could have been owner) tells me to bring whatever the hell you want in as long as it's not alcohol. Awesome.

This is one of the true original dive bars and craft beer spots to exist before "craft" beer even became a term. Pliny on tap and other beers that you just won't see normally at places. Grab a sausage next door at Rosemund, bring it over to pair with a fine beer and absorb the atmosphere in all its glory.

Five stars in the dive bar category!
author: Mike G.

description: Great dive bar right in the middle of the action on Haight St.  Excellent beer selection and priced very reasonably. Our bartender was friendly and the service was fast.
author: Bill S.

description:
Just moved to the South Bay about a month ago from Portland, OR. This is easily the best tap-list we've found. A good variety of large and small breweries represented. The selections from the more well known breweries (deschutes, green-flash etc.) were the best or most unique the brewery has to offer. I got to try a Mother Earth beer which I haven't been able to find else where. Also the prices were the best we've found so far in the Bay Area! We were there early enough to get the happy hour price which made our beers $5 a pop. Just wished we'd had more time to try more beers!

Only downside was that the staff was a bit surly, but I can handle that with a great pint.
author: Emily Y.

description:
The wait staff here is very rude and the space does not have nearly enough seats to accommodate the amount of people.  There was table that had not been bused for 15 minutes and we weren't sure if it was being used or not.  In the back and the bar there was not enough chairs/stools, even though there was plenty of room for more. The night was topped off with one of the bartenders yelling at my friends, which was rude and unprofessional.  

I know it is a classic bar with good selection, but the vibe is hostile and lame.  It is a shame really, because the place really could have been great.
author: Luis R.

description: Love the beer selection at fair prices, rudest bartender I have ever dealt with who literally screamed at us.
author: Ruby C.

description:
This is the best beer bar in San Francisco, hands down. If you appreciate craft beer, good prices and a laid back environment, this is the spot for you! 

I've been here a few times and fall deeper in love with every visit. The walls are covered in stickers, everyone is relaxed and having a good time. It reminds me of some of my favorite breweries/beer bars out in Colorado. Yes, it is cash only, but that is pretty typical for SF bars and additionally helps them have some of the most competitive craft beer prices out there! I had a beer here for $6 that I got at another SF bar for $11. I mean, what a steal! 

They always have Pliny the Elder, and as a Santa Rosa girl I will always appreciate that. They keep the list pretty local but also have beer from all over the place. I'm not sure how many taps they have exactly, but A LOT. There is definitely a beer for every palate! See you again soon, Toronado.
author: Mandy A.

description: Tons of awesome craft beers at a great price! Great service, super efficient, I never waited more than 2 minutes to get my drinks and it was very busy. I wish I was back there right now.
author: Eric G.

description:
Oh my God. Pliney on tap?  Yes please.  I'm a beer nerd from Denver and I love all these Cali brews. Justin is a fantastic bartender. Very knowledgable. 

Come her if you want the best beer selection in San Francisco.
author: David C.

description:
Bouncer wouldn't let me in the other day because he was "convinced" my ID was fake.

Funny, since Toronado was actually my first bar experience ever, when I turned 21 and moved to San Francisco in 2010.

Too bad. Cuz I was really looking forward to being served a 5-star-review-worthy barley wine that night.
author: Andrew S.

description: Dive bar in Lower Haight. Zero pretension, in fact, there's so little pretension, that it kind of creeps up as the bartender's attitude when you ask them to describe a beer "dude, I don't know, there are like 300 beers, you want this one or not? Don't waste my time deciding".
author: Caro D.

description: SO.. if you can believe it in this day and age, the DOORMAN- let's not give these wimps the glory of being called a "bouncer"- tries to start an argument with a patron after being complimented.. then proceeds to gossip with the other DOORMAN/BUSSER.. after which this same BUSBOY turns and decides to retort in a very homophobic manner towards that same kind respectful patron and insults them (while not realizing he is too dumb to understand gender, sex, or perhaps even to what he is oriented, possibly because his very small head is too thick to contain even the smallest amount of brain matter). Good job, dick bags.. GFY. It's San Francisco- grow up. Remember where you are before you open your inbred mouths.
author: Jean M.

description:
Best beer bar I've ever been to.  

Seriously, this bar has the best beers at amazing prices.  Cash only, which is pretty typical of SF.  All you got to do is show proper etiquette when ordering.  Know what you want, have cash in hand, and tip $1 a beer.  Easy peasy. 

The bartenders are very nice, but aren't trying to hold your hand when they have 20 other people trying to order drinks.  

Just yesterday, a guy next to me was trying to order a few rounds for friends while it was packed, but changed his mind after the bartender had brought him his beers.  The bartender looked at him and yelled 'YOU SUCK' and moved on to the next person.  Me and my buddy could not stop laughing.  I can only imagine that guy coming on here and giving a bad review...something about how he got yelled at for "no reason."

If you want to chat with the bartender, and get samples of beer, come during an off hour when it's empty.  Plop your butt on one of the stools and you can chat/sip all day.  When it's crowded- put your order in, shut up, and pay!
author: Crandon J.

description: The guy of the door is such an awful, he is angry, he is annoying and he is so rude, is my only complaint about this place
author: Rubi N.

description: Best dive bar! I miss living close to this neighborhood and this bar is one of the reasons. Always nice people here. I need to go back soon and say hello to my favorite bartender.
author: Sara P.

description:
Great beer! Great service!! It's refreshing to go into a bar and the bartenders are passionate about the beers they sell (especially since they have an awesome selection on tap and in bottle).

Every time I'm in SF, it's my #1 priority as a bar. Thanks for continuously making it a great experience.

I'm from SoCal and super pleased to hear they have a Toronado in San Diego! I'll be checking them out soon.
author: Thanna C.

description: We all got yelled at for standing in the entrance.  We moved and got yelled at for being in the aisle.  I asked if they actually wanted us to leave and they said yes.  I wondered afterwards whether they were upset because we were not a big drinking crowd or maybe because quite a few of us were in suits. Not sure. All I can say is that if you want customers to do anything then a simple "please" and a smile is sufficient to get me to comply happily.  Bar man and bouncers were aggressive and rude for no reason.  Avoid unless you like aggro.
author: Natasha L.

description:
I personally think this bar is super overrated but if you're a craft beer hipster junkie kinda guy, you'll be in cloud nine. They have an amazing selection of craft beer on tap-from sours to stouts. I have to admit, I've discovered some of my favorite beers to this day thanks to Toronado.

There are a few things that turn me off from this place.
1. The bartenders are assholes. Not in the good, funny way either. Just pure assholes who won't give you the time of day. But the actual service is fast and efficient I'll give it that. 
2. Its always packed. T(his is probably why the bartenders are assholes)
3. The crowd usually sucks. Its not the best bar to meet people. And since its always crowded, people get their shove on.
author: Anastasia P.

description:
A ton of high quality but average beer for a good price...  

This isn't the place to go if you are looking for anything unusual or REALLY good, but kudos for being able to have so many options of good beer without having them go bad... They are clearly moving a lot of kegs here.

Also, based on my one visit, it's certainly not the place to go if you like to meet people. Based on one visit, It seems like people tend to go here in couples or groups and aren't really interested to talk to anyone outside the group (unusual for San Francisco)

Again, not a bad place if you like to try a lot of average to average+  beers.
author: Anders M.

description: Totally not my scene but this is the second time I ended up here during my SF trip. If you love beer, this is definitely a chill place to hang out. It can get really loud, so unless you have a loud voice like me, you'll have trouble communicating with your buddies. I forgot exactly what I had... it was strawberry-something beer (sorry, not very helpful!) - but it was pretty good! Beer is cheap. They let you bring food in, so I've seen people eat pizza and also food from that sausage place next door. The night I visited, a Mexican lady came around selling tamales. I got one of each: veggie, carnitas and chicken. It was GOOD! I couldn't really see the food because it was dark, but I was hungry (drinking always makes me hungry, even if I'd already eaten), and our group huddled in the dark bar, devouring the tamales. lol. Overall, the people are chill and I think it's cool that they let people like the Tamale Lady in to sell food. (Oh, and strawberry beer and tamales really go well together.)
author: Cindy J.

description: This is the most pretentious, arrogant bar I've ever been to. Smells like the fourth world. It's rare where the third world bathroom is actually better smelling than the bar. Bouncers and bar tenders are short sighted and petty- chastising people for chewing gum and for tipping less than what is expected. Tips are based on service level and when you don't get served and you cut the order in half, you won't get tipped. Stay away.
author: Kunaal P.

description: Congratulations, you have reached the holy grail of craft beer bars in California. The beer selection is absolutely second to none and this place maintains the gruff dive bar character it looks like. The back room is a little more chill if you don't feel like getting yelled at by the bartender for not ordering fast enough or not tipping 200% or by the regulars who will back up said bartender for expecting a high tip. It's a classic all right.
author: Jim G.

description: I love when clowns get all pissy because they ordered a vodka soda or PBR or acted like some kind of douche, then got tossed out or chewed out by the staff here. Listen - this place as dirty as a Tenderloin underpass, reeks of year-old spilt beer, is like a hellish bat cave that can swallow up an entire nice day, and the staff absolutely hates your guts and hopes you get hit by a MUNI bus on your way out. That's why it's awesome. That and the killer selection of beer and prices that are far less gougey than other top SF beer spots like City Beer or Mikkeller. Don't be a clueless jabroni when you come here, don't get your man bun all up in a bunch, and just stay out if your skin has the thickness of rice paper. People who give this place one star are usually people I would rate as one star at life.
author: Nick D.

description: Great beer selection. But the bartender was a piece of shit and couldn't tell us a single thing about the beers we asked about and then proceeded to make a comment because we didn't tip him bc he sucked... Soooo I guess if you are a regular this place is great. But if you are visiting, don't come here, they are extremely rude.
author: Austin B.

description:
Definitely one of the top stops for hop lovers in San Francisco for a beer crawl like I was.

The bar is dive bar lovers dream.  In my opinion, only to be slightly bested by Zeitgeist.  Plenty of stickers around the bar, retired tap handles line the room and metal is usually blasting over the speakers.

I visited with a friend (local) for a few pints on a Tuesday night.  The place was pretty crowded even at 10 PM.  We stayed until closing and enjoyed plenty.  I think one of the main selling points for people is that Pliny the Elder seems to always be on tap.  I did not see this at any other San Francisco beer bars I visited.  

If you are into good music (not that pop/r&b or clubby shit) that most places play today, know/appreciate your beer and enjoy $5/$6 pints, definitely stop in.
author: Brian K.

description:
I hate giving an average rating for Toronado since the beer selection is superb and the location is great. My first visit three years ago was excellent but last week's experience was completely lacking.

Yes, it's phenomenal for a New Englander like me to get Pliny the Elder on tap, don't get me wrong. But the cash only policy is ridiculous and the completely packed bar with a grimy fratboyish atmosphere seemed out of place in a spot with such a commitment to serving such excellent brews. 

Overall, fabulous beer variety but not my scene.
author: Emily C.

description: If you are a beer and rock lover, no frills person, this place is for you. Tons of really good beer on tap (cash only, no food - but they allow you to bring it in from every where). This is an old school place in the heart of lower Haight. Bartenders are great. Beer lovers only - no liquor or wine served!
author: Cheri E.

description:
Perhaps I just came in on a wrong day but on a Saturday afternoon this place was bananas. It was super crowded, loud, and just not my scene after walking more than a few miles that day. That atmosphere is definitely pretty divey but that doesn't bother me. You know what does, though? Super loud music with the treble turned up to 10. Oh God, I think my ears are still ringing. You know it's bad when it takes my super huge AC/DC fan boyfriend a few minutes before he identifies the sounds of Angus Young on the stereo. 

The beer list is fantastic, to be sure. I had a great pomegranate cider while the rest of my party enjoyed more beer based beverages off their MASSIVE list. The beer list alone is worth 5 stars, indeed. But for me I just couldn't get over the sensory overload around me.

My fella went back on his own later in the week during the day and he said it was much calmer and it was relatively easy to speak to the bartenders and get some schooling on beer. He was raving about it. So perhaps that's the key. Go on an off day or night. Next time, SF. Next time.
author: Annette J.

description: Great cheap and chill place. Excellent selection of beers. We came here to end the night for my bachlorette party and it was great low key place.
author: Frances Z.

description:
This place is exactly what you think it is: hole in the wall, local beers (ONLY beer! Don't even bother trying to order liquor because you will get booed out of the joint), hipster environment, etc etc. If you're looking for anything else then don't bother, but if you're looking for a tap bar then toronados SF is the best of the best. Grab a sausage from next door while you're here. Rosamunde is off the charts.

And ...  

Pliny on tap .. Enough said
author: Pat V.

description:
What a dump. A wonderful, wonderful dump.

The bartenders here don't screw around. Taplist is outstanding, and any questions are answered knowledgeably. 

Toronado is the kind of place you go to when you want to grab a pint of great beer and hang out for a bit with friends. Saying "Michael Jackson" here invokes talks about the beer god, not the king of pop. The bartender told me that that, "Pliny is all I drink anymore."

Grungy pretentiousness. That's how I'd describe Toronado. What a dive.
author: Dylan K.

description: If you are a fan of broad beer selections and casual atmospheres, the Toronado is a great option. It's a hole-in-the-wall, divey, cash-only bar with a superior list. I didn't eat here, but I was very impressed with the options on draught, and the service was great.  Our bartender was super friendly and made some great suggestions. Everyone in the place was relaxed and merry and years later, I still have fond memories of visiting the Toronado. It's a great place for a casual date, a long, lazy drinking night out with friends or even a quick drink if you're just stopping through. You will try something you've never heard of before, and you will like it.
author: Christy I.

description:
Avoid. Bar tender acts like a beer nazi. Got some attitude from him when we asked about one of the beers. He then said we should order faster and stop wasting his time. Bill turned out to be something like 12.50 and when we told him to keep the  change, he said in a snarky attitude "do I get to keep all of it?". 

Had one drink as quickly as possible and headed out. 

What a shame, placed could have been fun but our experience was ruined by a wannabe duck dynasty/sons of anarchy pretentious bartender.
author: Boudz Z.

description:
Huge selection of imports and craft brews. They had ~6 sours on the menu. Probably the highest quality beer selection i've ever seen and on tap too! Favorite of the night was seme della vida which can in something resembling a champagne flute. 

Fancy beer in an unpretentious atmosphere? This is the place. Apparently they started SF brew week.
author: Cortland T.

description:
There are great beer bars, and there are legendary beer bars. The Toronado is an iconic legend in beer-geek circles, a prime mover that has been at the forefront of the craft beer revolution over the past couple decades. I had to make my pilgrimage. 

Like many of the nation's best beer bars, it's a little crusty. It has been on Haight St. for 24 years, and looks the part. It's hard to imagine that the first time I came to San Francisco, in 1989, I walked right by this bar when it was in its first year of operation. Of course, I didn't know what I was looking at, and wasn't old enough to drink, anyway. Point is, this place has some mileage on the odometer, and was probably dive-y to begin with - so don't expect some sparkling, yuppiefied, Yard House/World of Beer-type tavern. No matter. You're here to drink beer. You're not here to see and be seen. You're not here to pick up girls. If you're a woman, maybe you could come here to pick up dudes, but you run the risk that some of them may be more interested in their beers than they are you. 

Hey, I get it. When I'm drinking a Lost Abbey Cable Car (a rather rare, expensive sour beer brewed specifically for the Toronado), I don't want to be distracted. Upon seeing it on the menu, I was beside myself with excitement. But then I tempered my expectations, figuring they probably wouldn't have it. After draining a Pliny the Elder (because if you come to the Toronado from out of state, you *have* to drink a Pliny), I went up to the bar to try to order my Cable Car, bracing myself for disappointment...but none was forthcoming. Instead, the pearly gates parted, and the bartender produced the coveted 750ml bottle, and two tulip glasses. It just doesn't get much better than that. Sure, Cable Car isn't cheap beer by anyone's standards, but the experience was well worth it. 

As tough as it is to follow Cable Car, we did so with New Belgium's La Folie, another perennial favorite sour beer that can't be had where I come from. 

This place has a reputation for gruff, snarky service, but I didn't see any of it. For what it's worth, I thought the bartenders I interacted with were pretty cool. The bar felt comfortable to me, very much like some favorite beer bars in my home state. I think that generally, if you can speak a bit of the language of beer, you're fine. That also implies, don't act like an entitled jerk-off, or ask stupid questions like "what's the closest thing you have to Bud Light?" For that matter, I probably wouldn't try to order a Bud Light here, unless I was trying to be funny. And, I probably wouldn't try to be funny, either.

Cash only, so come prepared.
author: Patrick L.

description: Good beer bar with lots of beers to choose from ! Went here for a engagement party it was fun we had the back room to our selfs and was able to bring in food from next door which was awesome ! I would go here again for sure beer went great with sausages from next door !
author: Nick O.

description:
The bar tender is a pretentious jerk. 

My friend and I went there on a Saturday. Me not knowing this was a beer only bar I asked for some whiskey. The bar tender said "beer only" and then walked away to the other side of the bar to chat with his buddy. He wasn't busy, he just walked away. 3 minutes later he came back to our side of the bar to take some girls order, not because of us. I said "you are not very kind". His response: " uh. OK" and then walked away again to get the girl's beer and then talk to his buddy again. Never asked for my order.

We just left. I was sad because the music really rocks there. We need more metal bars in the bay area.
author: Daniel R.

description:
If you're talking about a bar that you want to go to that you just don't give a crap about, but want to get drunk with some awesome beer- then there you go. It is what it is in here and let me tell you something. The service is as bad as the smell of bleach in the air. But I suppose that's part of the beauty here.

In case you didn't figure it out yet, it's pretty bad (the smell that is). I came here two separate times and both times it's been the same thing. Great beer of all sorts mixed with controversial service. I asked the bartender for a suggestion on their best wheat beer and he said "look at the menu". Okay. That's very helpful. This douchey attitude is exactly why I will not be back here and instead I will go across the street instead.

Overall this place is cool if what you want to do is grab some interesting beer in a bar with tons and tons of memorabilia. But in terms of service you fail my friend.
author: Nathan L.

description: Beer was fine but the people working there are so unbelievably miserable and unhappy. The bartenders think it's funny to be rude and say things like "are you a f-cking child who can't read" if you have any sort of question about the menu.
author: Jayme F.

description:
Great selection of beers, but its not very spacious and not a fan of how the bar is designed. The bar is in the front (which I don't mind), but its a narrow walkway to the back where the seating is at. Gets super packed on weekends so if you want a place to sit, come early. 

Huge selection of beer though. I think they have the most sour beers of any bar in the city, so if thats your thing, definitely come visit. Be sure to get a sausage next door, Rosamunde is the best in the city.
author: Cody M.

description: One of the only places I know in the Bay that has Pliny the Elder on tap. CASH ONLY but they do have an ATM in the back. Don't be fooled by the seating, there's hella more seats in a separate room in the back. They have a HUGE variety of beers, but Pliny for $6, not bad in my book! Lol, a definite must try in while in the Haight.
author: Veronica A.

description:
Five stars isnt enough.

This bar is the TRUE american beer bar. Cheap beer, good service, FANTASTIC beer selection. Amazing experience all together. I am very happy i went to Tornado.

I can't wait to come back next time I'm in SF!
author: Kevin H.

description: Greatest dive bar on San Francisco. They have so many tasty beer options, including my favorite brewery, russian river. Great spot to hang out and grab a drink.
author: Dinesh A.

description:
Part of the American beer bar pantheon
A Haight institution
Beer and attitude vie for the title on a minute-by-minute basis

Pros:
You're here for great beer, and great beer they do in spades
One of Michael Jackson's "three most important bars in America"
Beeraphernalia and punk attitude tacked up everywhere
Long distinguished bar and tables along the wall
Bring your own food as long as you clean up after yourself
Better to know your beers going in, but if you know just a bit and ask nicely, the bartenders will help you through a choice that suits you
Taps kick and rotate constantly, so the choices remain fresh
They maintain a couple hand-pull cask options too
Don't forget that, while there are taps galore, their bottle list is substantial AND you can get those to go
Crisp tv up front with the local teams on
Robin is helpful and enthusiastic

Cons:
Cash only (but there's an ATM)
Acrid smell of dishwashing tub
Paul is damn cranky; happy to hold court, but not really happy to be there
