2.  They have 30+ other awesome beers on tap.
3.  Bartenders don't take any guff from clueless customers
4.  Happy hour all day on Saturday
5.  They have Pliny on tap!

Seriously, this place is on almost every list of the Top xxx places to have a beer before you dive.  Bring cash, have an idea of what kind of beer you want before you step up to the bar and you won't have any problem.    I ended up here twice during my week long stay in San Fran and I would recommend a visit by any beer loving American that is planning a trip to SF.
author: Timothy W.

description:
Beer beer beers galore. Toronado is definitely the place to go and try your beers. This place definitely gets me excited and has become a game among friends in picking beers. Mainly because if you are just discovering you're love of beer (kinda like me), you definitely need a guide to let you know which ones are super bitter and for the true beer fanatics and which ones are just tasty and need to try.

1.) The menu is at the top. And tho they might have a bunch of beers, there really isn't a guide to what is what? At least provide an IBU or something. That would be extremely helpful and prevent the overwhelmingness
2.) The place gets crowded. So dont expect seating and be okay with standing. Theres a room in the back with some seating, but barely.
3.) The bathrooms are actually decent. Which was surprising to me.
4.) Theres an eh mexican place next door, and a pizza place on the other side. When given the choice, go with the pizza.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Of course the main appeal is the great beer selection. And the gourmet sausage place next door is a big plus. Grab a dog, bring it over to Tornado and get the prefect beer to go with it.

But my favorite thing at Tornado is the service. The bartenders here have personality -- each their own personality. They don't give you a plastic coated version of themselves; they wear it on their sleeves. Over the years the bartenders have ranged from fun and quirky to famously rude. But that's part of the appeal. These people are real and, by the way, they are real into beer. If you want some great beer, a casual, dive-y atmosphere and real people this is your place. If you want to get stroked and given a fake smile, then try somewhere else.
author: Kevin K.

description: We go to toronado often with our dog often, he is a cute pug and French bulldog mix. This evening we went with friends from melbourne, the owner was pouring behind the bar, it was cool, but then the bartender with the dark hair fuzzy beard, with gray in it, came up to me and said he is the bartender coming on in 5 minutes and he prefers that the dog not be there. We had to leave, it c was wrong as we had only meant to stay for one drink but we're given no chance.
author: Heather P.

description:
TL:DR; Dive bar, cool to go once, don't stand by the bathrooms. If you love beer, this place has 'em

AMBIANCE
Packed on a Friday night, not quite rowdy, but there's definitely an edge to the crowd. 

If you've been to a dive bar, then you know what it's like.

Still, it's more of a transient dive bar. I'm sure there's locals here, but it felt more like a destination dive bar than a haunt for people in the neighborhood.

THE BEER
This place has beers! Lot's of them. And they are priced what you would expect to pay at a place that cares about their beer. Most things are around $5-$6

The beers are craft and awesome. 

THE TIP
If you can find standing room or a table near the front of the bar, stay there.

There are two bathrooms at the back. There's a seating area with a bathroom and a hallway at the back with a bathroom. In the middle of the two is a jukebox, and decent room to stand around. There's a reason there's room there, it stinks! The smell is pretty bad, or at least it's bad on a busy night.

WHY 3 STARS AND NOT 4 or 5?
They have a ton of beers, and even "holy crap, Pliny!" But the beer selection just isn't enough for me to make it one of my more-favored bars.
author: Shawn S.

description: I love the vibe of this place! It has the quality beers you would expect from a fancy gastropub without all the pretentious beer snobs. Its a pretty kick back spot. Having Pliny the Elder on tap drew us in, all the other beers kept us staying for hours on end! So long that we outlasted our meter and got a hefty parking ticket =/
author: Alyssa O.

description: Just called and some a@$!hole told me no dogs allowed. When they clearly do like those pictures show. So screw them
author: Angel C.

description:
I am an avid fan of the Toronado in San Diego, and had to visit the original location here in San Francisco. We came on a weekend night, so it was packed like supermarket before a hurricane. 

Beer selection is awesome, better than the San Diego location, and better than most places in San Fran. They even had The Bruery from my 'hood (aka socal) so what a pleasant surprise. Also had Russian River, Lost Abbey, I am a fan! 

Somehow, with the placed full of a hundred drunk people, we were able to snag a table and I did not get spilled on, which was quite a feat. Getting beers from the bar however, takes like 10 minutes. So 4 stars in my opinion.
author: Summer C.

description: Classic lower haight spot. Divey and dark with a phenomenal beer selection. Honestly a nice spot to chill out with friends and have a casual drink though I'm sure it's a hot going out space.
author: Milan T.

description:
This is a really though one.  It should be a slam dunk 5 star review.  This bar, in my opinion, has the best beer selection in The City.  I live half a block away.  I mean, this SHOULD be my neighborhood staple. 

Lawd knows I have tried many times to make this place my neighborhood staple.  

The problem?  Pretty much every single person that works there (bartenders, door guys, whoever) are pretentious DBs... except for the pretty little Ailene (?) lady.  She's the only nice one.  If she's not working, don't even bother.
author: Kasie V.

description: I've been coming to this place for more than 10 years now. Very good beer, I mean quality beer selection and an awesome staff. You are allowed to bring  a yummy sausage from next door rosamunde  and eat there. Seriously? One of my favorite dive bars period.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
Best beer selection in San Francisco. 
The place does have a stink to it, but it should since its a bar.
author: Jon F.

description:
Was there for Stout night recently, which was last night. Been there many times before that. To sum up this review, this place kicks so much ass! 

Great selections of beers, can't complain at all. Price wise, it was inexpensive, 4-6 bucks per drink. 

Highly recommended.
author: David P.

description: 4solid stars!!Great beer selection along with super reasonable prices!the only down side was the lady behind the bar.Being a local bar she could be a little bit more friendly but as the bar gets crowded, she seems not to care much. Anyway, I would def suggest this spot for any beer lover!
author: Shulita M.

description: Pliny the elder and Alpine on draft on my visit. Paradise for craft beer heads! What else can I say that hasn't already been said? Cash bar, but there's an ATM inside. Go there. Right now. Drink beer.
author: Brian W.

description: I still feel the same way about this beautiful bar and the people who complain about it.
author: Caitlin T.

description: This is a beer drinker's bar, no doubt about it.  This was the first stop on my bachelor party and was a ton-o-fun.  Really nice bartenders, huge selection of great beers and really crowded.  But the crowded part was a positive not a negative.  When  I go to a city, I like being in the middle of it all and being sorrounded by humanity.   For sure, no question, every time I make the trip over the hill to SF we're stopping here.  You gotta get here.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Toronado is THE place in the Haight, if not in all of San Francisco to get a good beer.  Not just "A" good beer, but about 30+ different good beers on tap.  It's small, quaint, and crowded, but that is what makes it feel like a lively bar.

The servers were quite helpful and one even gave our hero a free drink after chatting with him and his drinking partner for a while and reminiscing about bars that have closed down in San Diego.

It's tough the beat the food and beer pairing of Rosamunde's sausages with Toronado in SF.  If you've never had said combination, you MUST hit up Toronado.

PROS:
- Right next door to Rosamunde's, which has some great sausages you can bring into the bar to consume with your beer.
- The bartenders are pretty knowledgeable on beer and provide complimentary tasters if you have a hard time deciding.
- Excellent selection of beers.

CONS:
- Fairly limited on space.
- Cash only.
author: Albert W.

description: Yeah! This is what I've been looking for! A disgusting divey bathroom with all the authenticity of graffiti and rage. And yet it's clean. And well stocked. With a sense of privacy and peace.
author: Fzarond K.

description:
I hearted Toronado in 2009.
I hearted Toronado in 2011 when I celebrated my birthday there.
Going to Toronado tonight and I still heart it!
author: Jen C.

description:
Huge selection of beers on tap.  Most beers are $5, and all are $1 off during happy hour, which makes this place one of the most inexpensive places to get your drink on if you like delicious beer.

Grab a sausage from Rosamunde next door, and bring it into the bar to enjoy with a pint.  Ah...life.

Pro-tip: The beers in green are organic.
author: jon y.

description: Loved their beer list and finally got to try pliny the elder! I heard they were the first bar to actually carry it outside of russsian river too. I went on a Saturday night and loved that I also was able to get a table in the back for 6 people! It's nice that they have that back area for people who want to sit and chat or watch a game, but don't expect them to come cleaning it beforehand or anything (didn't bother us at all though). Great dive bar for drinks, so if you don't mind the noise and limited service and are really into checking out a variety of beers (which I was), definitely recommend going here!
author: Janki P.

description:
As if you don't already know, this laid back hall is a beer lovers paradise.  
An amazing assortment of beers (as well as  patrons) make for a fine way to sip away a foggy S.F. afternoon.
 Service is better the earlier you go and so are the characters posted up at the bar.  Be patient and friendly, and chances are you will be rewarded handsomely by the staff. 
 If you have never been here, you are missing one of the best beer spots known to mankind.  Make it happen!
author: Lee C.

description:
I've lost count of the number of times this place has been recommended to us ... we finally wandered in on a slow Monday night.

It's cash only, there's no kitchen ( there are plenty of places to grab a bite to bring in on the block ), and don't forget your ID like the couple that showed up a minute before us.  The doorman ... okay, the bouncer ... isn't taking any nonsense.

What's inside?  Beer taps.  Lots of Belgians, an excellent selection of local brews, a smattering of other things.  For some reason, despite a long tap list the night we were in, they didn't have a single dubbel on tap.  All the beers are reasonably priced for what they are, though some of the stronger ones are served in small portions.  They have two beer engines, serving properly curated local beers on cask.

The bar staff was happy to recommend something nice when I asked for a sour beer that wasn't Rodenbach ( which they had on tap ) - ask a serious beer question, these guys know what they speak of - at least on my visit, I found the guy behind the bar reasonably friendly.

It's not a big place; there's a small back room with some table seating.  The night we were in around 9pm, it was possible to get a spot fairly easily, and by the time we left an hour later, spots at the bar had even opened up.  The crowd was pretty mellow - a bunch of couples and small groups enjoying beer.  The table next to us was a flock of programmers getting drunk and discussing coding standards.

The rumors are true - if you are into beer, you have to see this place.  I wasn't sure how it would compare to the Rose and Crown down in Palo Alto ( much closer to home for me, R&C has food, has IMO an equally awesome tap list ), but I left impressed.
author: Albert H.

description: Favorite place in San Francisco. Best beer selection, great bartenders that let you sample and great musik.
author: Kristian L.

description: great spot on lower haight for beers and just hanging out. easy street, metered parking.
author: Nicole D.

description: The "bartender" was condescending, pretentious and rude. I asked her about her IPA selections and she had no idea what I was talking about, she didn't even offer me to sample any of them. Her only job is to pull a lever and pour beer in a glass..she could barely do that. She made me feel like I was an inconvenient. I tried to converse with her on their selections and she wasn't knowledgeable on any of it. She even overcharged me..the IPA I had was priced at $5 and she charged $6. I still tipped on top of that because I felt she needed the money more than I did. The owners need to sit her down and school her on craft beers and customer service..or just let her go. Otherwise, the place itself was fine
author: JD M.

description:
By far my favorite bar in the city-- the beer is fantastic, the bartenders are straight up, the people diverse and oh, can I say again-- the beer is FANTASTIC? That's what Toronado is about, and if you can't handle a slammin IPA or Belgian sour, be humble and take the time to learn :)

Looks like I took home some sass from the bar last night. They all probably really hate that I'm posting a yelp review right now.
author: Tracy L.

description:
I can't do it anymore! The staff makes it so difficult to enjoy those delicious beers they have in that amazing bar. And, I have been embarrassed by how rude they act the last few times I brought out of town guests there and have to apologize for my lack of hostess skills. I love me some good beer, mmmm hmmmmm. But I don't think I can go in there and keep my mouth shut about how I really feel about them...which means I will probably be kicked out. So, I'll have save myself the time and go to noc-noc if I am in the neighborhood. 

As Tom Robbins said: "Just because you're naked doesn't mean you're sexy. Just because you're cynical doesn't mean you're cool."
author: Melissa C.

description:
My boyfriend loves beer, so we stopped by here to get a beer on tap.  They have a wall dedicated to their beer menu, so you know whatever you get is going to be good, but beware.  Toronado is seriously the definition of a dive bar.  When you walk in, you're slapped in the face with the stench of stale beer, piss, puke, and bleach mixed together.  On top of that, the crowd is less than friendly and I believe they have never seen an Asian before, despite living in San Francisco.  It was quite literally, the most uncomfortable fifteen minutes I've ever had to sit through.  

Word to the wise, don't go here unless you're white and look older than 21.  I was carded for just sitting at a table.  I know you're suppose to be 21 to be inside a bar, but I don't know why they're such a stickler for age requirement's when some of the bar patrons were getting high right outside the door.
author: Merisa M.

description:
This is a dive bar. It's also one of the best bars in the country. The prices are good, and the tap selection is amazing. It offers something for everyone, with the entire world represented well and some incredibly rare beers. 

Drinking here will make you never want to leave.
author: Walter K.

description:
So you have a big beer selection. So what. So does everyone other bar in SF.

 The bouncer gives me crap every time I enter the establishment for not closing the double front door and acts like I'm doing a disservice to him by just frequenting the bar. 

It takes forever to get a drink here, yet the prices are nice for someone who doesn't want to spend more then $4 on a beer, however the bartenders seem like they have more important things to do the dole out beer to the clientele. 

I would much rather go to get beer in the east bay at The Trappist or Beer Revolution.
author: The S.

description:
Oh Toronado, how I wish there was one in my city. 

While on a self guided beer tour of San Fran, Toronado was our first stop and I am SO glad it was. 

The bartender was awesome. I knew going into this place they might be a bit anti tourist and they also might be low on patience but order your beer, drink it, don't bitch, don't waste their time and your good. 

I'll be back, many many times!
author: LeeAnn N.

description: Great selection of beers. Quick service. It was a bit too much of a dive bar for me. It was kinda cold out (for San Francisco) and they left the doors open, so we all drank our beers in the cold air for hours. Otherwise, it's a great place but come here for the beer and not the ambiance.
author: Lisa R.

description:
"I'm about to dive in....." 

to this ridiculously awesome collection of beer, hoppy awesomeness. 

A pretty straightforward place. You go it, show ID, look at the wall for something to quench your thirst, order, drank, drank, and repeat from the looking at the wall step. Not much to it! 

They selection of beers are pretty impressive, covers any kind of beer craving you got, their prices are fair and the crowd is chill and not all up in your grill. A good place to grab drinks before going out, or just a place to go out to to kick it with your companieros. 

Chill place, good beer, good prices. Simple. Pleasing.

Holla to Trey Songz fo dat first review line yo.
author: Kristine T.

description: My kinda place. A terrific beer bar with an impressive and distinguished selection of west coast and Belgian beers. More interesting beers than is possible to try in a single visit. I wish I lived closer so I could be a regular.
author: Ryan M.

description: Manager ripped us a new one because we moved a stool after asking other customers around us if it would be okay. We apologized  to her and she ripped us an even bigger one. We left promptly and will not be returning.
author: Amanda W.

description: CASH ONLY!!! Great hangout on Haight Street. They have a really wide variety of beers. I got the Pomegranate Cider--it was amazing! We couldn't get a seat and the guy at the door wasn't exactly friendly, but a couple let us share their table which was really nice. Will definitely be back.
author: Dani L.

description: its so funny, i read all the other reviews and there seemed to be a common complaint about the staff... but i figured, its the internet... i mean they cant be that bad... and i swear it was just so so funny... we arrived at happy hour, sat at the bar. and i was literally treated like dirt.... i still gave a dollar a tip drink because i was laughing so hard! never have i met a ruder bar maid... i mean ever! still great beer selection.... left after one... couldnt stay! even though a new barman started his shift and he seemed more pleasant...
author: Reg B.

description:
For context, I have been going to the Toronado since 1996 or 1997 and lived down the street for many years.  Instead of the typical review, I am going to break this down into two sections, A Very Short Review and Responses to Most of The Complaints in Other Reviews.  Let's begin.

A Very Short Review:

This is the Toronado.  They were serving micro batch, high quality craft brews when 99% of the people that drink them now were preoccupied with memorizing the verbiage on the Budweiser label and were excited when Blue Moon came out.  Make no mistake, the Toronado is hands down the most famous/important (and in my view the best) craft beer bar in the world, if for nothing else simply for the relationship to the craft beer movement itself (it practically started there) and the owner's relationship with many very high level craft breweries.  There are beers that are brewed only for this bar itself - try going there on an anniversary and you will see stuff that is impossible to get anywhere else in the world.  Try going there on SF Beer Week and you will see a new keg of Pliny the Younger for 14 days in a row (yes it lasts 45 minutes sometimes but that is 14 times what just about every other Bay Area bar that serves Russian River beers gets).  I was there in 2012 for the Russian River brewery day - Vinny and his wife were both there and brought the stuff of dreams... (large format and everything).  This part was not as short as I anticipated.  But I digress...

 Responses to Most of The Complaints in Other Reviews:

"The Bar/The Patrons/The Bathrooms smell bad" - oftentimes this is true.  There is nothing like the fresh hoppy scent of a Pliny the Elder that arrived the same morning, on tap to clear your nostrils.  Have two, trust me you won't smell anything offensive anymore.  And also, it's San Francisco, a lot of things smell in San Francisco.  Lighten up.

"It's cash only" - this is also true.  Can you imagine what a mess it would be if they accepted credit cards?

"They don't serve food" - this is also true.  There is a vast selection of sausages next door and you can eat them at the bar (or anything else).

The Staff is rude/surly/mean/doesn't understand my request for a "light" beer - dude, you went to the Toronado and ordered a "light" beer?  Seriously?  We've been making jokes about you for the last 15 years but until today I did not know that you actually existed.  You're actually lucky that the entire bar didn't kick the crap out of you on the way out.  The bartender was actually extremely polite to you given the situation.  That's like going to the most famous BBQ restaurant in the country and asking for the "light" ribs.  That's like going to the most famous restaurant in Italy and asking if they have Chef Boyardee spaghetti and meatballs.  Don't go to the Toronado and ask for a "light" beer, or generally act like a jackass.

Yes it is true that when the place is packed to the gills with people, the staff does not have much time for each patron to make a painstaking decision on what beer to get.  When it's not packed, the staff is pretty cool.  If you ask intelligent questions and genuinely are interested in the beers, you'll be treated with respect if not outright friendliness.  Oh, and try leaving a few bucks tip - it works wonders.  And when it gets so busy that you can't move in there, try to figure out what you want beforehand.  That's really all you have to do for great service at the Toronado.

"They don't have such a big/long/great/extensive beer list" - yes, it is true that if you go to the Yard House, not only will it be cleaner and they may have more taps, but you're not going to find Cable Car at the Yard House.  Nor are you going to find Russian River's Toronado 2oth Anniversary Ale. It's about quality not quantity.  It's pretty easy to put 47 lager taps on your list, and I assure you that there's no difference in 98% of them.

That's all for now.
author: Michael A.

description:
This is a San Francisco staple. Everyone knows, for the best beer on draught and selection of Belgians in bottles- - it's Toronado. 

I mean come on, this place has got Pliny The Elder on tap with Blind Pig IPA as a back-up! Get tired of the IPA's? They're certainly going to have something else that suits you, just don't be afraid to ask. The bartenders are very knowledgeable in their craft and typically happy to answer any questions. 

The decor also pleases me: saloon style front door, and tap handles from years past hung all the way to the ceiling. 

Easily my favorite place to grab lunch if I'm in the neighborhood for happy hour : Sausage link from Rosamunde's + beer at Toronado = 12 bucks with tip, and me being a VERY happy man (:
author: Daniel K.

description:
It's a prototypical dive bar in every sense of the word. Rickety chairs, minimalist all around, dark. French door.

But one of the better beer selections I've come across on draft and in bottle. Bartenders were busy but friendly. Not your average dive bar. If you love craft beer and bars that look like bars, this is your place.
author: Derek C.

description: if you don't mind getting robbed blind and yelled at for great beer then this is your spot.
author: Lila C.

description:
Overwhelming beer selection!
Never ask for a budweiser!

Great staff, great beer.

A good spot to meet up with friends on your way out.

Too much beer got you buzzed, go next door for a sausage.

Look out for the friendly dogs and the over the top beer snob sitting at the bar.
author: Carlos S.

description:
Awesome.  Great, great beer ("no crap on tap"), prices, and music.

This was on my beer circuit in SF before I moved back to NYC -- it'd be great if we had something comparable to Toronado in NYC.

It's crowded for a reason (see: awesome), head in during the early afternoon.  Stay for a while, grab some food from next door, come back.  Think of it as a day trip.  Worry not, it's 5pm somewhere.
author: Steve M.

description: Come here with my sausage sandwich from Rosamunde next door. Excellent beers on tap. Staff was friendly, ambience was good. Great choice!
author: Eduardo S.

description:
I'm too lazy to talk about the amazing selection of beer they have here. And they have almost 1,000 reviews, so it's not like i'm going to be able to say anything that hasn't already been said. Basically, even writing this is pointless because I'm just contributing to maintaining their 4 star rating without adding any new or exiting information. Sorry guys.

I've been here a few times now, at all different times of the day, and all different days of the week. I think I definitely enjoy the daytime drinking vibe in the middle of the week moreso than the Friday night vibe. Even if that means having to drink with a bunch of alcoholic fat guys who have nothing else to do with their time and money than to buy beer, at least they're spending it on good beer. The staff here is hit or miss. It's mostly a bunch of snobby rude beer freaks who get offended if you ask a question about any of the beers. Unfortunately for them, I take great pleasure in annoying the shit out of somebody. It's what makes me smile inside. If someone makes it blatantly obvious that they think I'm a complete idiot for asking what the difference in taste is between the Rodenbach Red Ale and the Iron Springs Epiphany Amber, then clearly I'm going to start asking even dumber questions purely to piss them off even more. That's just how I operate. 

But once I'm done having my fun with the rude bartenders, I thoroughly enjoy my delicious beer and good company. Toronado would hands down be a 5 star in my book if it wasn't for all of the attitude that oozes out of the walls and taps here. But the more you drink up, the less it'll bother you. :)
author: Amanda S.

description: Good beers. Good metal-y music. Decent ambiance.
author: Paulo K.

description:
Im in love, the Toronado is for sure my favorite Beer Bar in the United States and I have been to many. 

They have a great selection that is everchanging with the best from all over the US but mainly focused on the local NorCal beer scene. 

Some yelpers have commented on the wait staff but I have always had the same girl when I have visited and she has been super nice, even comping me a beer when she took more then a few minutes to get back to me. 

I wish I didn't live across the country, I miss you Toronado!
author: Jeremy A.

description:
I'm embarassed to say that I've never been here even though I lived here for over a year. So happy that a fellow Yelper that I randomly met that day personally took us to Tornado (well we took a cab and met up) and their is a nice smelling weiner shop next-door. I personally couldn't be happier.

I'm loving the Allagash White and our bartender is super observant, attentive, professional and quick!!!
author: Shiho F.

description:
Cheap. Dirty. Excellent beer. Close proximity to sausage. Killer jukebox.
Love this place.
Favorite bar in SF.
Go here.
author: Alasdair C.

description:
I will always be in love with Toronado.  This was one of my first bars when I moved to SF, four years ago.  They have an extensive micro/belgian beer menu (no Budweiser sold here) and the pricing is actually really good for what you get ($5-7 for common pints, +++ for your larger/reserve bottles).  I think the bartenders are great and helpful if you ask about a specific beer.  Do NOT just say "what do you think I should order?".  They have a decent juke box and plenty of seating.  Sure, it smells a little like rotten beer (some of you think it's piss, don't you?), but it's a real brew bar.  Not a pansy a** sportsbar where their ales are only as skunky as Sierra Nevada or Fat Tire.

Go, it's an SF staple.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Best advice for this place: DO NOT WASTE THE BARTENDERS TIME. 
Know what you want before walking up to the bar. Otherwise, he'll walk away and he won't come back for awhile. I learned that the 1st time i went by watching other people try to order. 
Crowded place but honestly... who cares! I love the energy this place has. 
Excellent beer selection!!! And everything on tap with a few in Cask barrells at room temperature as well.
author: Eric D.

description: The bartender here is awful. He was drunk and belligerent, refusing to accept my ID despite the fact that I'm in my late 20s. A friend I was meeting there told be she'd seen him chug 4 beers while waiting for me. He aggressively accused me of having a fake ID and refused to serve me. When I stood up for myself, he threw me out of the bar. I went to the bar across the street and had a great time there -- I recommend you do the same.
author: Sydney G.

description:
This is a followup from my recently written review about Rosamunde's Sausage Grill next door. We came over to Toronado with our food from the grill (it's a cooperative joint venture, feel free to order your sausage on a bun and sit at the larger, more spacious tables in the bar, but be polite and order a beer while you're at it!) 

Crowded and noisy, it's a typical beer bar with an extremely large assortment of beers on tap. Check the chalkboard up on the wall to find an option for everyone, even those that dislike beer (like me). Favourite brewery was represented (Russian River holla!), and they carry kriek and a pomegranate cider, both of which were mild on the beer taste and heavy on the fruit (my preferred drink!)  A waiter will come by and pick up not only your empty glasses but also your trays from the grill next door, so no worrying about running it all back.

Only one complaint, for which they lose a star: despite having several Russian River brews on tap, they were missing my favourite (Consecration!)  I saw "Russian River" written on the menu and got a happy little tingle in my pants in the hopes I could get my favourite beer, but sadly they weren't carrying it. I'm not sure if it just wasn't in stock or season at the time, or if they don't carry it ever, but I was quite disappointed (although I'll admit that it's self-inflicted disappointment, since I allowed myself to get all squee when I saw the brewery name). I was pretty happy with my kriek, but it wasn't Consecration!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Only one friendly bartender in the whole place (the rest are just there to serve you and scowl). It smells like sour vomit in here. It's always packed and cash only.

BUT - the BEST beer selection anywhere. And it's cheap. And you can bring in a sausage from Rosamunde's next door. 

I love Toronado!
author: Celeste R.

description: This place definitely has personality. It's more of a hipster, alternative bar than what I would think is a dive bar. It's not laid back and is much more busy than a typical dive bar. Pros: They have an interesting beer list. Great decor with old beer tap handles. They try to serve the beers in their respective glasses. Cons: the place has a bit of beer snobbery to it, exhibited by the bartenders. It's all cash. No food but you can bring in sausage, food from outside. I would go here again when I'm looking for a craft beer.
author: Ami R.

description:
Finally made it here after hearing about this place for a long time. After going here Thursday night, I determined it wasn't really worth going out of my way for it since there are plenty of other places in the city that have decent tap selections, but now I can say I've gone.

One star for being right next to Rosamunde Sausage Grill which has some awesome grub btw and another star for allowing you to bring your freshly grilled sausage over into the bar and the final star going to a decent beer selection (read the current beer selection on the wall first so you'll be ready to order from the one bartender working the bar)

This place was packed. I dislike packed places where you have to fight your way to the bar to get a beer or fight your way through the crowd to get to the back.

My experience might have been better had I been there with a friend, but I was there on my own on a whim when I decided to go to the city after work from Berkeley.

Quick tip: Bring Cash! - It's a cash only bar

I may try this place out again maybe if I'm in the area or craving another gourmet sausage from Rosamunde next door.
author: Craig F.

description:
Despite having an awesome beer selection, and a grungy cool dive bar vibe, the staff here are beyond rude.

 Just because we dress a little nicer than your usual clientele does not mean we don't know our hefes from our dunkels, deserve to be deliberately ignored, overcharged (only locals get Happy Hour prices eh?), or patronized to (Oh really, you don't serve Coors? Good, we wouldn't be caught dead drinking that rubbish anyway). 
Grr! 

Especially when we had been so looking forward to going there...
author: S B.

description:
1. this place looks smaller on the outside than it actually is
2. service is fast.  i think someone said not to waste the bartender's time. 
3. great selection of beers on tap.  stone ipa :) yumz
4. not super cheap.  i'm still trying to get over the fact that dive bars in sf are still not divey-priced.
5. lots of places to sit!
6. i came tonight (sunday), and it was quite crowded!  well not super crowded, but every single seat was taken.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The devil called. He wants my soul back! Damn you Pliny the Elder! Our affair began two months ago, and here I am, 2,000 miles later knockin' at your door. Toronado's is, of course, where it all began...

I moseyed into this bar hours into my first time in SF, on the advice of a friend back home . I had just enjoyed a vegan smoked duck sandwich at Love N' Haight next door, and was in the mood for a good local IPA. I ordered a Pliny from the bartender, Morticia and sat quietly at a table hoping to enjoy the "local" feel of it and maybe charge my phone...you know, considering I was alone in a city I had never been in before with a dead phone. Not moments later, after a 20% tip mind you!, Morticia calls me out, muttering something about her generation having manners and "electricity ain't free!" 

Buh. Buh. Okaaay. I unplugged my phone silently and sat there sipping my beer meekly like a child that had just been scolded. 

A couple of minutes later a commotion arises in the bar. A young kid just slung a beer at the barwench and now everyone's on their feet.

"Well, at least I know it's not me!" I said to the Cheech and Chong character to my right. 

From that moment on I was "honey" "baby" "sugar".

Whatever dude, just give me a Pliny! 

4 stars for great beer selection. Minus 1 star for the bartender's attitude. Go back to SoCal!
author: Leigh W.

description:
Toronado doesn't need anymore reviews really. The beer selection is wonderful, the place is extremely crowded, and no what you want because all the staff is completely rude. 

My first visit was on a Friday night, which I won't do again. Its more of a afternoon place. I like to talk about beer not just yell across the bar for one.
author: Erin S.

description:
This is a beer drinkers beer bar plain and simple.  If you're coming here because your company co-ed kickball team decided to have a pub crawl in the city...well this probably isn't the place for you.  This bar is and should be for the craft beer drinker.  Pliny the Elder on tap...hell yes, Dogfish 120 on tap for $5 bucks!, oh dear lord.

Bottom line, this is a down and dirty beer bar.  If the only thing you take away from this place is that your panties got in a ruffle because you "thought the bartender was rude"...well...at least your kickball team won right?  Now move along and find yourself a Stella.
author: Chad P.

description:
Ok, I heart Toronado. Did a V Day mini pub crawl with a few friends, and Toronado was our first stop. It just so happened to be the same day as their Barley wine Festival so figured it'd be crowded, and yes, it was. There were so many varieties of barley wine (close to 100 maybe? I can't recall but the barley wine sheet was two sided). Even, the board that lists all of their beers was down to about 10 to accommodate the barley wines. 

Anyway, there were some hard core barley wine aficionados. After getting a sausage next door at Rosamunde's, we found a table in the adjacent room with empty chairs across from two aficionados. OK, so 3 hot and lovely ladies sitting across from these fellas, and did they bother to look up at us?!? UM NO! It was amazing how engrossed they were with their barley wine, sipping from their glasses, discussing how hoppy and malty each were, and ranking them on their sheet. 
However, the table behind us was a complete 180 from ours. Talk about young, rowdy straight out of college kids. They were so loud and annoying, and one girl's laugh was just so painful to hear. *And who wears white jeans in the middle of winter?!? (that's for you, Amy!) Seriously, we downed the dogs so we could get the hell out of that room and back to the main bar area! 

Back in the main area, we chilled by the front door and drank our beers. We started talking to one of the bouncers, who ended up giving us a few of his valentine cards (you know, the old school elementary school kind with the cartoon characters). I was happy to get one, even though it was a hand me down. Dude, it was a Scooby-Doo one! Love it and love you bouncer dude! It was another solid outing at Toronado! Was definitely feeling the love on V Day!
author: Gill C.

description: Great classic beer bar.  Service was quick and easy. Like so many good bars in San Francisco, this place is cash only.  Come here if you like good beer. I don't mean you that you know what an IPA and you like it. It's hard to complain about the variety here.
author: Corey O.

description:
Toronados! F--k yeah!!!

This place rocks in so many ways, it's hard to describe.

Great, great, great beer selection. Loud music cranking at all times. Sausages next door.

I am a huge fan.

5 stars for a perfect, loud dive bar.
author: Jefferson S.

description:
Toronado is the non-dive bar goer's dive bar.  Given its fame, it is nigh unbearable on a Friday or Saturday night. That said, it's one of my go-tos for day drinking for a few reasons:

1. Great beer selection
2. Great prices during happy hour (which I think is just anytime before 7:00PM?)
3. The ability to eat food there from nearby establishments
author: Andy J.

description:
Walk into this "institution" known for its mindboggling array of craft beers.

But be forewarned!  ...stay away, unless you ENJOY being mocked, laughed at, ridiculed, degraded, avoided, ignored, or smirked at.

When the greasy, long-haired, pot-bellied 30-something guy (aka, the bartender) asked what i wanted, I appropriately asked, "Can you recommend a lager?"

He replied, "Only women or first-time visitors would order a lager!"

I'm not sure if he's more unhappy about being a miserable, uneducated service employee who pours liquid from a tap ...or that he is a greasy, fat loser who knows nothing about beer.

In any case... perhaps the owner may want to send this rude, gross "bartender" to beer school, so he can learn about the fine art of crafting the OLD, highly acclaimed art of brewing fine, delicate lagers.

I'll never return, not even if they offered free beer, and an apology, it wreaked of skank and youngsters who were a bit too hip
author: Ted K.

description: Great place, we went here one night for a good beer. You can get a hotdog next door and bring it to this bar to eat with your beer (they allow that). I would suggest the rare red poppi beer if its available! The bartender was so happy that I asked for it that he even had a glass with me. I love the wide selection of beer here and the wall of stickers is always entertaining to look at.
author: Kevin K.

description:
This is the best beer bar in the world. If you don't like it, I hate you.

I'm not going to sit here and tell you that the bartenders will pay attention to you; they won't. What will happen is something along the lines of this:

1. Enter Toronado
2. Walk to Bar
3. Attempt to flag down bartender
4. Pray.
5. Train Monkeys to Joust
6. Profit!!!!!!!1 Maybe at this stage you'll get a beer, probably not.

No, it's not easy to get a beer at Toronado, but that's because it's awesome. Go drink here, go on a quiet night and talk to the bartenders about beer. It's a humbling experience.

Cheers,
Joshua
author: Joshua G.

description:
The bartenders aren't very friendly - they know that, and they're okay with it. 

Lot's of beer on tap - but don't think about what you want after they ask for your order or they'll walk away. 

Very limited seating when it's busy, and tight quarters even when there aren't many people.
author: Art V.

description:
This place is the epitome of how the growing sense of entitlement is creating a population of arrogant, condescending and basically demonic worker bees who are all too good for their jobs and certainly way too good to provide you decent customer service.

I asked the Saturday day bartender who was working at 3 pm on 3/13/13 if they had any light beers on tap.  This was after waiting a while as he served a handful of people that arrived after me.  The guy mumbled something about a Pilsner (I think) and then walked away to grab some glasses or something.  

Since I couldn't hear him the first time and he was obviously in a foul mood, I tried to lighten it up and asked him politely if he had any recommendations.  He proceeds to walk away again and I hear him say pretty loudly, "If you want a light beer, why don't you go across the street!"

I reached my limit and said, "What the f#$k is your problem?  Why are you giving me are you giving me such an attitude right off the bat?"

Immediately, with no hesitation, he yelled, "F*&k off!  Get the hell out of here!"  

The guy next to me turned to me and asked, "What the hell did you say to him?"  

"I asked him for a light beer," I replied.  

At that point, this embodiment of class and substance storms off to the back to grab some bottles.  On his way back towards the bar I tried to talking to him, but he continued to berate me with obscenities. 

"You're not getting served, get the f*&k out of here!" he kept yelling.  

"This is crazy, why are you not serving me?" I asked in a pleading manner.

He points to a sign or something, it was really all pretty surreal and a blur at that point and he yells, "See this, I don't have to serve you because you are an AS^&HOLE!  I don't have to serve AS#HOLES!  You better get the f#$k out of here or I'm gonna call the cops!"

He then walked to the phone and called the cops.  At that point, I turned to the guy next to me and said, "I gotta go, he's calling the cops."  

As I was leaving, I walked by him and said, "You're the a*shole dude, wow."  

He then proceeded to flip me off, clenching his teeth with this insane look on his face in front of just about everyone at that bar.  The guy was literally growling and cursing at me as I walked out of their with this overwhelming sense of disappointment.

Behind the bar working that day was a pretty sad excuse for an employee.  His anger and rage sits so close to the surface it's kind of pathetic.  

Based on some of the other comments on here and what I heard from some people right next door that day, it looks like it was just another day in the life at Toronado.  Management must be very proud of themselves at this fine establishment.  What a joke.
author: Pat P.

description:
Tons of good beer on tap.  A bit small.  You can bring in great sausages from Rosamunde's next door, and the tamale lady wanders in sometimes.  The bartenders aren't always the nicest, but does it matter that much?  The front door is a horse door.  This bar will always have a place in my heart.

I think this is all you really need to know.
author: Mike A.

description:
This bar has taught me many things:
1)  How to be decisive
2)  To not be easily offended by curtness
3)  To pee squatted over a toilet (toned up the leg muscles)
4)  The likability of loud metal music
5)  That it's nice to be in a bar with many men and less women
6)  Have cash on hand for impulsive Toronado moments
7)  If you go in there with 2 of your hot girlfriends the bartender will be nice and will take a picture of you and your friends if you are not a bitch to him (given he's not four deep)
8)  I love Duvel and Delerium beer
9)  Eating sausage in front of people is a good and acceptable custom
10)  Every time you look at the wall you will find a new sticker
13)  If the floor is a little sticky, it's OK
12)  This is probably the best beer bar in California, not kidding
13)  All of the bartenders are bomb if you aren't a douche
author: Erica L.

description:
If you pray to the beer gods, Toronado is your Mecca.

The bartenders can be dicks here but they own it.  They know no one can match their delicious, deep beer list anywhere else at this price so they seem to enjoy messing with people who don't follow their rules.

Only have a $100 bill? "F-off loser!"  Sick of waiting for 20 minutes for a drink? "F-You!"

That being said, it completely fits in with the dive bar atmosphere.  There is a cool thing going on and they don't tolerate people messing it up!

On any given night there is always something insanely interesting and delicious on tap.  You can frequently see special stuff from Russian River, Lagunitas and Moonlight to name a few.

It gets packed in here so prepare for a sausage-fest if you arriving in the evening.

One final word of advice: make sure to speak loudly and clearly and bring cash or prepare to feel the wrath of the "soup nazi-esque" bartenders.
author: Tyler B.

description:
I have long loved Toronado. The beer selection is jaw-dropping and the atmosphere in the bar is great.

Sadly, I have to give them 1 star due to a recent experience there. I have never met a ruder bouncer in my life. We came in smiling. I asked him a simple question (I didn't hear what he said - asked him to clarify), and he totally misread me. Yelled at us in front of the entire line at the door for being "sarcastic" and called us "douches". We left right away.

I guess we hit him on a bad night, but I'll never go back.
author: Bailey R.

description:
This place is HORRID on it's own, but when you compare it to it's sister bar in San Diego, which is one of the finer beer bars in the area, it's downright shameful. Seriously, if you ever go to SD, visit Toronado there and see what it's like. The bar tenders won't cup your balls, but they certainly aren't complete asses and will let you sample beers, ask questions, etc. They actually kind of LIKE what they do for a living (amazing, I know!). And the place has some pride of ownership instead of being a dingy dump like the one in SF.

The only thing that Toronado SF has going for it is the fact that it's one of a handful of places the City to get a wide variety of some really good, craft-brewed beers. Once the microbrewery craze becomes fully recognized in the Bay Area (and it soon will), Toronado won't be worth the time or the effort. Either that or they'll have to step up their game.
author: M M.

description: Pliny the Elder on tap, what more could you ask for. Service is terrible as mentioned in a few other posts, but tip well and the bar tender will warm up to you. The door man (same person on 2 diffrent occasions) was one of the rudest people you'd ever meet, up side is that you only have to see him on the way in and the way out. Ask for the bottle list, there are some gems on there!
author: Seth S.

description:
Me: Franziskaner

Him:  Sculpin IPA

Salute,  Sláinte, Fisehatak, Skål, Oogy wawa ("cheers" in Zulu in case you're curious)

Solid beer joint, ass-holish bartenders with almost an east coast edge.  Not offended, just sayin'
author: Athena S.

description:
My mother refers to this place as the "Biker Bar" since she was hit-on while standing outside the door, about 2:00pm on a Saturday afternoon, by a guy on a bike. I was inside buying my husband (then bf) a sweatshirt since this is his FAVORITE BAR EVER. When he lived in Long Beach and came up to visit SF this was a must-stop every time.

Three years later this is no longer a must-stop (and also never was a biker bar, Mom). Maybe because it's cash only (err). Maybe because it's too close (we live in Cole Valley) so we feel like we could come anytime..and then never come. Maybe because it's always SO packed. For whatever reason, we don't come here as often as we thought we would.

On Saturday night we came here for my friend Steve's bday. It was 8:30 so of course the place was packed. I scanned the list of beers for a non-ipa (or at least something not too hoppy) and landed on Anchor Steam. I know. So boring. But for a non-hops lover, not a ton to pick from. They do have stouts, yes, and they had two hefe type beers, and maybe it's my fault that I was being picky. But in all honesty, I wanted to be at Magnolia with a Kalifornia Kolsch in my hand. Call me a yuppie. It's fine.
author: Melissa N.

description: Good beer selection, BUT the worst service with major attitude.  The bartender I had seemed like he wanted to start a fight as I was trying to get his attention to order and then kept making issue when I waved at him.  When I had enough and took my change off the table as I was not going to reward his behavior, he started swearing again like he wanted to start something.  Looking at all the reviews, there seems to be a pattern here.  Not sure if  this guy is now a biker with no bike, but I'd find another bar.
author: Tim M.

description:
THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!! 

I came here for a pub crawl and was not disappointed. So many choices, GREAT PRICING! everyone was so friendly. It is a divey place but awesome. No food is serviced just beer but there is a place right next store that has sausages and yes you can bring them in. 
crowd was cool for a very busy Saturday afternoon. 

Cash only place, so be ready but not at all bad for the price I'm telling you :)
author: Raquel O.

description:
I have nothing bad to say about this place. Toronado is one of my favorite dive bars in the city. They have a huge selection of beers on tap including my personal favorite, Russian River's Pliny the Elder. 

Pros:
-Great beer selection
-Affordable prices
-You can bring food in to enjoy with your beer (Located next to Rosemundes)
-Lots of room to sit/watch whatever sport's game is on
-My happy place

Cons:
-Cash only (but they have an ATM machine inside)
author: Talia M.

description:
Once a year in February, Toronado hosts a week long Barley Wine Festival. It ends today, and by now many of the 53 entrants in this year's competition are tapped out. 

This is the only time I go to Toronado, and the only time all year I drink Barley Wine. People come from all over the country, aficionados of the "premium high gravity beer" circuit, and like any gathering with a following of super nerdy enthusiasts, just add alcohol and you have a rockin' good time. I'm not so sure I want you there, dear reader, but hopefully if you have a marginal interest you'll have forgotten about it by the time 2009 rolls around.

In case you decide to attend this overcrowded nerdfest, here are a few tips: standouts from this year's offerings: Gnarlywine 2006 from the Lagunitas Brewing Company and Cucupa Barely Wine from Mexicali. According to the spreadsheet they give you (I told you, geeks), we sampled a lot more than this but I, um, forget. You will do well to bring a six-pack carrier so that you can transport six 3 oz. samples ($2.50 ea) back to your table at once.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Want to meet the world's lousiest person? Go to the Toronado, and whoever is behind the bar at that particular moment...that's him!

Nice beer selection, but in SF, that train has come and gone. You can find equal or better beer selections at a number of places, and not have to deal with the shitty dicks who work there.

You're welcome.
author: Yowz A.

description: This would be my 'local' if I lived in SF. A little rough around the edges, slightly surly barkeep, bring your own food in, AMAZING draft list. Can I spend the night in your keg room? You had me at 'Pliny' but I enjoyed two more wonderful Russian River brews and a taste or two of other Bay Area treats. And I spied a sticker from my favorite tiki bar from Milwaukee which pretty much sealed it. That's it, I'm moving in.
author: Scott H.

description: Divey awesomeness....friend took me here for adter dinner beers on my last visit to SF, knowing I am a beer snob, and I had many ass kicking choices, like a kid in a candy store...except the kid is a fat old beer loving grump and the candy was skull splitting imperial stouts and, well, you get it.
author: Dave H.

description:
Excellent beer selection. 

The bartenders here can be short if you're not ready to order, but they're also super helpful if you need a beer recommendation. I came in on a post-work Thursday, was able to find a seat at the bar and even sample a few beers before my friend arrived. 

The music is a little loud out front, so we went next door to Rosamundes, grabbed a sausage and found a seat in the back. It gets crowded later, but is still a great place for happy hours and anytime you're craving a good beer.

You'll also always spot the tamale lady here!
author: Gretchen S.

description: I like the combination of good beer selection and lack of pretension, which is sadly uncommon. I miss coming here every Tuesday, but it's the type of place that's easy to go to regularly or just drop in every now and then. It gets a little too crowded for me and the seating is a little awkward, but oh well. The barleywine festival is a MADHOUSE!
author: Lisa K.

description:
If you've read the other reviews, you know the drill: order yourself a delicious sausage next door (meaty or vegan), saunter up to the bar, and worship at one of the best beer temples in San Francisco. 

All of the drawbacks are out in the open: the bathrooms are dingy, the bartenders have some snark, and  at most hours you'll be packed like sardines against the rest of the crowd. I suggest relieving yourself ahead of time, dusting off your kindergarden politeness skills, and coming during an off hour, so that you can treat yourself to one of the most diverse selections of beer in the Bay Area. 

This is an excellent place to try out varieties of beer that are absent at most other bars (e.g. I tried my first lambic here) and to familiarize yourself with new brewers from this area. At its best, Toronado is like a daily beer tasting festival. At its worst, it is a difficult place to grab happy hour brews with your ten closest coworkers. But if you love beer and want to exercise your adventurous tastebuds/liver, Toronado is worth it.
author: Monica S.

description:
Two things if you come here:

1. Don't even think about ordering Stella.
2. Don't complain about lack of seating.
author: Phuong M.

description:
This review is for the ladies of SF.   Great beer selection, and more to the point of this review, great man selection.  

So often I hear from women living in the city that there are not any single straight men in sight.  Like, "where are they all at?!" in the most exasperated, exhausted sighs.  Well, they're all hanging with their bros at Toronado.  I kid you not.  It's like a 5 to 1 male to female ratio, and many of the men seem blatantly on patrol.  Obviously this place isn't a classic meat market, and I'm not trying to turn it into one by encouraging women to flood this joint.  It seems like a great place to meet someone genuine without having to put on any airs or any heels.  In fact, bringing in a sausage from Rosamunde might just enhance your allure.  To the beer naysayers: might I suggest getting an Allagash White, delicious and palatable to even the most hardcore beer avoidant.
author: Erika H.

description:
The Toronado, like any bar in a big city, is hit or miss depending on the night you venture in - the owners and employees can't really be responsible for the type of folks who are in there on any given evening. Alas, every evening I've been in, the place has been chock full of carefully groomed wannabe bohemian types. You know the sort - look like a homeless person, but has a two bedroom in the Haight and works for Google bringing down $150k.

Clientele aside, they have a phenomenal beer selection. Excellent range of class beers you'd expect to find, as well as brews on tap from ultra-micro sources like Russian River. ('Twas here I first discovered Pliny!) and beers are served up at the correct temperature, in their correct glassware.

As I mentioned, the evenings I've been in there, the place has been extremely busy, and it took some time to get served. The bartenders  definitely had an air of snobbishness about them, and if you haven't made up your mind by the time they call on you, be prepared for a tongue lashing. Thankfully I had the foresight to look over their beer menu (note - it's not over the bar, but sort of at a 90 degree angle to it as you walk in the door, so it is easy to miss) but witnessed many a poor soul on the business end of it, when all they want to do was enjoy their night out.

Don't buy into the hype too much. Be prepared to deal with the bohemian wannabes (including some of the staff) and bear in mind it's a bit of a dump, but outside of that... a great place to check out for some tremendous beers.
author: Gary E.

description:
So many beers, I couldn't decide! I tend to stick to ones I know, like Death and Taxes, but it's a good place to branch out and ask your bartender for suggestions. Of course, at first I went for ones with the cool names that I wasn't familiar with, turning out to be all IPAs. All the cool named beers are IPAs it seems, which I happen to not be a fan of. Always too hoppy for me. 

Eventually, dude realized I wasn't into girlie beers and he handed me a double something or other - it's a bit loud in this place on the weekends, so I missed the full name. But that didn't stop one girl from camping out at the bar with a bookstand, reading a huge novel and chugging down a beer. Sweet local spot.
author: Alita M.

description: This place fits the title of Dive Bar. The place was packed, I got a table in the "cave." The bartender was a sour dude, not friendly at all. The restrooms were pretty rank. On the positive side, the beer selection is excellent, and the prices are cheap! Grab a slice of pizza next door to brink back to your table.
author: Todd S.

description: Came in here during the Champions League Final and we somehow found two seats at the bar. "Great beer on tap" per my fiancé and I had some great cider. It's a dive bar, smelled slightly of vomit, but we paid $4-6 per beer/cider during HH. Sweet!
author: Summer F.

description:
I really love the relaxed atmosphere here, no pretentious a-holes hanging out....sweet!

The coolest thing is the 'train station departure board' layout for all the different beers & their prices. Takes away all the guess work and eye squinting to figure out what beer you want to try next.  

You really can't beat the good quality beer that skips the preservatives and gives you no hangover in the morning! I kid you not, after drinking all evening here, I woke up like freakn' snowwhite from her enchanted sleep. Mental note to future self: Drink more Anchor Steam;-) 

The music kicked ass and I'm not sure what category this bar fits into...but it hangs somewhere between a classy dive bar (is that an oxymoron?) & a beer galleria.

I actually think it's really cool that they do not sell liquor. Keeps the shot slamming assholes at bay (and if I was a regular here with my girlfriends, would prevent us from becoming the shot slamming a-holes).

I probably would have given the place 5 stars if the single bartender wasn't so overwhelmed & if the music was at a lower volume so we wouldn't have to scream at each other. But the beer really did make up for those slight nuances.  

Overall, I'm glad I was introduced to this place.  Would definitely revisit on my next trip to San Fran.
author: Barbara D.

description: Toronado is a cool bar, and a good place to go if you like beer, and they say the bartenders are assholes but I've never had a bad experience there until tonight. The short, brunette female bartender, Robin, is a piece of work.  The bartender who had been on shift early on was really cool, gave good recommendations and allowed me to sample two of the beers I was deciding between.   The one after him, however, made a point of going out of her way to be rude to my whole table.  She gave me the wrong change back twice, and later actually left the bar where people were waiting on her to and harass one of my party for having idly ripped up a beer coaster, while we were still at the table!  It was a very strange experience, and at the end of the night she dared my party to write a bad yelp review, so here it is.
author: Anna B.

description:
Fantastic beer selection.  Probably the best in SF.  I especially love going around the winter holidays and in the summer when they have lots of seasonal selections.  

Yes, it can be crowded as hell.  Get there earlier or wait patiently for a table.  It's popular for good reason.  I just don't get the reviews that complain that the staff is pretentious.  They've been anything but in my experience.  They love beer and are happy to share their knowledge with you.  Any time I've asked questions, they've been happy to make recommendations and let me try a sip before I order.  I've learned to just listen to the bartender when I am not totally sure what I want - their suggestions have turned me on to so many delicious beers. Yum.
author: Heidi M.

description:
My favorite bar in Lower Haight. The only problem is that sometimes they just jammed and you've really really got to try and get yourself noticed. And of course the somewhat usual "cash only" thing.

But love the ambiance of this place. And of course the beers--great selection and they are good about seasonality. Just this weekend they had a slew of Christmas ales that I hadn't seen at a number of other places in the area.

Probably my favorite thing about Toronado is that they're open early. This is the kind of place where you can get a drink at Noon--and some days (for better or worse) you just need that!
author: Paul C.

description:
I visited my brother last weekend, and this is one of the places he took me too.  We stopped in to Rosamunde first, got our sausages, and then went and had beers here.  We went early (4:30-ish I think?), so crowds weren't an issue.  

The front bar was busy, but the back room was pretty empty.  The 5 of us grabbed space in the back room - booth seating lines the walls, and there are a half-dozen tables and a dozen chairs or so scattered around the room.

An overwhelming beer selection, and it was hard for an out of towner like me to decide on anything.  I went with a local IPA (can't remember which), that was okay.  The hops in this IPA seemed to overpower any of the other flavors though . . . 

Anyway, I liked the place (mainly due to the huge beer selection), and could see going there semi-regularly if I lived in the area, just to try all the different beers.  Bringing in sausages from Rosamunde is a plus too.
author: Ernie C.

description:
This was my favorite bar when I first moved back to The City.  I loved that it  had an extensive list of beers!

Over the years, I avoid coming because it's just too busy and now has a bit of a crusty feel to it.  When I do come here, I prefer to sit in the booth in the back but will settle for a table near the front.  I laugh to myself when I read reviews about the rude bartenders here.  I remember a night when I placed an order with a salty older lady with black hair (you know who you are).  I turned around to get my friend's order when she barked at me, telling me not to ever 'do that in her bar again'.  I stood there a little stunned...do WHAT, exactly? I guess it's rude to turn your back on a bartender?  Or maybe I'm not allowed to order for others?  Seems a little full of shit, if you ask me.

Anyway, if you are in the area and want a good beer, check this place out.  But it's gotten a little played out - there are so many other bars in the Lower Haight that don't treat you like shit and still expect to be tipped.
author: Carmel U.

description:
If you love beer, and I do, you will love this place. The place is always crowded no matter what time of day it is. There are so many quality beers here, its no wonder why there are always customers. Pliny the Elder is my personal favorite. The prices are cheap ($4-$5) and during happy hour they are $1 off.  This is a great place to bring friends who also love beer. Yes, it may smell kind of funky in here but that won't matter after youve had a couple! The people are friendly so go to Toronado with some friends and make more friends!! 

Oh and remember its cash only
author: Kevin C.

description:
I don't care that this place is dirty and tiny. I know I am in the Lower Haight. I also don't care about salty bartenders who pour stiff drinks and openly roll their eyes at you. Again I am in the Lower Haight. Shoot I am in San Francisco. That sort of b.s. is like bitching about pigeons. It's EVERYWHERE.

What I do not expect is to be screamed at ala bloody murder from across the bar because my friends managed to swipe an empty table and didn't have the chance to show a bartender ID. 

I can happily go to Noc Noc or Molotov's an arm length away and get my moody/salty bartender fix as well as skipping the re-visit to my Catholic grammar school education. Thankyouverymuch.

And if I am ever feeling masochistic and see the need to return and if the bartender can manage to get their gonads out of that vice, then have a shot on me. 
Meanwhile, here is one star for that cliched d-bag of a bartender.
author: Aileen M.

description: Holy mother of BEER. So much beer and hard cider for the kids
author: Pamela I.

description:
Let me first start out by saying that if you don't like old style dive bars with boisterous bartenders you probably won't like this place. 

From the moment you walk in you know you are in a bar for craft drinkers. They dont have bud light, coors, or millers. But no one cares. 

We sat at the bar and was greeted by the bartender who was wearing a Sf Giants jersey and a backwards hat. In his scottish accent(which my girlfriend loved) he asked what he could get for us. My girlfriend doesn't like beer and asked for a wine, which they didn't have a the moment. He offered her a cuvée rogue (sour lambic) which he let her taste first. She loved it. I haven't found a single place in las Vegas that will let you taste the beer first.  

We had got there early, maybe around 2pm. So we were on happy hour. $4/per. As the afternoon wore on it started to get a bit more crowded. Our bartender's shift was up. I will say that our experience could have been a byproduct of a mid afternoon weekday because once he left and it started to get busy the new bartenders were not nearly as talkative. But the beer on tap was amazing! 

If you love craft beer or just beer in general this place won't disappoint. 

P.s. Cash Only!
author: Anthony R.

description:
Toronado's is solid neighborhood bar with a ridiculously large beer selection.  Though I'm not a beer drinker, I can always find a special cider to enjoy on the long list of libations on tap.  

It's a pretty small place, but I usually come in "off-peak" hours (not Friday or Saturday night) and have always been able to grab a place to sit and talk to my friends.
author: Cathy Y.

description: Since I'm not a beer drinker I felt a little out of my element here. So many beers to choose from and not a single idea as to what I should order.  I told my friend who was buying me a beer to get me something like a Blue Moon and I ended up with the Allagash White (I think).  Not bad, but part of the reason I like Blue Moon is cuz of the sweetness of the oranges you squeeze into it.  This beer didn't have that.  Other than that I had a good time.  We were with a huge group of friends and got two tables by the entrance.  The atmosphere is bustling and fun.  For any beer lover, I'd recommend you at least try this place.
author: Elena N.

description:
So SUE ME. I may be what you consider the sin of sins a "Pac Heights/Marina" chick. But goddammit I like beer. I enjoy its frothy, earth, wheat laden tones and the nice little buzz that goes with it. So, upon hearing that Torondao was THE place to go for beer from a co-worker of mine (who by the way thinks I'm the shit even if I do own a LV bag) I dragged a few of my girlfriends who are also beer appreciating wenches down to the lower Haight to experience this lovely dive bar. I was very excited.

Umm..yeeeeeah. Not so much kids.

First off, we come in, smile at the patrons and make our way to the back. Now, I am all about being polite, and saying "excuse me" or "thank you" when someone does something for you. Apparently my manners are offensive to this crowd. I wait. Aaaaaaand wait for about 10 minutes before the bartender (who by the way was not serving anyone and saw me as I waved and smiled to lean and and ask for a recommendation) deigned to swagger on over to ask what I wanted. NICE. Thanks a lot bartender. You're an ASS. Luckily a kind patron who happened to be next  to me suggested the Cider and a nice Wheat based on my likes. Thank you kind sir!
After practically drowning ourselves to drink our beers, we didn't even bother to ask eachother for a second round.
We caught a cab, and made our way back to our motherland, where the girls are shallow and cheap, but at least the bartenders serve you like a queen.

4 stars for the beer 
0 stars for service which averages out to 2 stars
author: Kathy K.

description:
Awesome selection of beer, including several cask brews. Bonus points for being open on Christmas Day.

Went by to read and pass a few hours for the holiday, had a Firestone Walker Pale 31 cask, a Schneider Edel-Weisse, a Moinlight Twist of Fate bitter ale cask, and finally a Life & Limb (which is a completely different, and far better beer, on tap, when compared to the bottle).
author: John C.

description: The perfect dive bar.  Great list of beers on tap.  Lively crowd during the evening.  Nice non-sterile smell.  You can order food elsewhere and bring it in.  Rosamunde Sausage is a great complement to Toronado's beers.
author: Bob B.

description:
Yes I am being resentful, rightfully so.

I used to love this place.  The beer selection, the lower haight sun, the duck sausage next door.

But this long haired, four eyed bartender had to ruin everything for me.  He is a true hater on Haight.  I am sorry you had to work on a Sunday, but didn't I also tip you $2.00 for pouring beer?  You had to be snide to your customers--- I'll take disengaged and indifferent any day, but who these days has the actual energy to go as far as being a total asshole to your customers?  Maybe your true calling is some kind of Grateful Dead look-alike contest...  but presently, serving beer is what gets you paid.  Be nice.

p.s. you can go to La Trappe and Monk's Kettle where beer selections are just as impressive (if not better), AND (check this out) you get treated like a decent human being there.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
You can say what you like about this place, ambiance, service, tidiness...etc. Who really cares?

We came for the beer, and such beer! The place is performing a public service and is, in my not so humble opinion, a school, a church, and a bar. all rolled into one package.

Too crowded?

Too loud?

Too bad! Take your skinny jeans over to Nocnoc for a Stella, buddy boy.

Everyone will be happier.
author: Statin Island V.

description:
Toronado needs another yelp review as much as they need another beer tap handle on their wall. But they also need another yelp review as much as I need another beer. 

A must go if your traveling to SF and are a fan of beers.
author: Earl G.

description:
Pay less than you usually pay, and drink amazing beers. $4.00 for exotic craft beers with incredibly knowledgable bartenders? Yes please!

This is my favorite beer selection in the city, however it's also a thousand other peoples', so it consistently gets too crowded in peak hours.
author: Doug H.

description:
The staff may seem cantankerous, but here is some advice on ordering beer from here. 

These guys serve a lot of beer and usually have several people waiting to be served.  Know what you want and have your money ready, and tip! Stop holding up the line for the rest of us. If you have questions about the beer or beer styles get an app on beer or bookmark beer advocate. There is a wealth of information there and will answer your questions. 

With craft beer being more popular then ever these guys get bombarded with an assortment of novice questions or folks with a credit card (cash only) or in decisiveness, making it harder for us to get a beer. And they deal with a ton of tourists

I've been coming here for awhile and see where the staff surface surliness may come from. Come in a few times and each time, know what you want, have your money ready, bring up your glass when you are done with your beer, and tip! Simple. You will almost always be rewarded with a free beer and the distinction as a "regular" than newbie. 

Beer selection is always excellent, prices extremely reasonable and even better during happy hour. Beer is served at correct temperature with appropriate glassware. Oh, did I mention they have several beers on hand pump. 

Go to Monks Kettle or any other beer bar and you will pay usually $2 to $3 more per beer, and have a environment not nearly as conducive as Toronado. Insiders tip. Go on a Tuesday afternoon and get a burger next door. Taste like a burger you'd grill on Fourth of July. Tasty and reasonably priced. Now lets get a beer.
author: Joe M.

description:
I have been roaming the country recently in search of obscure IPAs. There is no getting around the fact that Toronado is the best there is.

Yet, during the 15 years I lived half a block up the hill on Steiner below Page, I went to the T only occasionally and not a single time to tie off the day as would have been good and proper. The reason is simple. This place is TOO FUCKING LOUD. 

I've never had a problem with the "surly bartenders". I see people I know in there on occasion. But if I want to talk with them, how am I going to do this? 

The place is unbelievably live acoustically. Maybe they buy super reflective space shuttle tiles from NASA and put them on the ceiling. There is a side room which is also too loud, and a "hidden" room in front of that which is only opened during Belgian Beer days.

So here is my proposal, and I would chip in for this as I bet would a lot of other IPA lovers. Open the Belgian room, combine it with the side room, and put in some soundproofing so folks can hear themselves drink.

That is it. The 800 pound gorilla in the walk-in has spoken.
author: Otis M.

description:
This is not your tourist bar. It's not very user friendly. In fact it's pretty dirty and dingy. You generally have to fight tooth and nail for a seat and it gets crowded. 

But if you arrive early enough, don't mind semi rude bartenders in a dimly lit, smelly and messy bar, then you're in for a surprise in that you'll be able to choose from a wide arrange of amazing beers at low prices. 

You just have to realize that it is what it is. And I know this will annoy people, but it's cash only. Deal with it. The prices here are so low anyway that you're getting a lot for your dollars worth. So even walking in with a $20 on you should be fine for a few pints of beer that isn't your normal beer you find in bottles or on the shelf of your local market. 

Another great thing about this bar is that you can pick up food from the places near it and just bring them in to enjoy while you drink your pint, The sausage place next door is a perfect combination for whatever you're drinking.

And let's just say you're not sure what is what. There is an easy to read board up that shows what's on tap and from which brewery it is from. While the bartender likes to get to the point, if you go in with your head in your hands and ask for a recommendation, they'll gladly narrow it down based on your preference. 

Over all, this is one of the best little hole in the wall bars in S.F. for the vast selection of beer they have to choose from. You'll find something you want no matter if you're a beer snob or just a weekend warrior.
author: Javier J.

description: Total dive bar with an excellent selection of beers.  The barman readily suggested an IPA when asked (Pliny the Elder) and even offered a sample.  Great sausages next door too!  Kinda amused that I was carded twice.  Oh, and this place is cash only but they have an ATM on premise.
author: Matthew J.

description:
Ah boys night out...and need to find a spot to hang out with the boys.  What to do...we've been to Hooters for the games and other eye candy, been to BJ's.  You can only go some many places so one of our buddies suggested Tornado's.  Sucked to find parking...but once we're in... place was packed.  Hard to find our tables...but honestly it's boys night out, so we got time and no curfew from the wives.  Good to have trust in a relationship.   Once we got our tables after scoping out a party who left..the 8 of us were able to squeeze in... but damn this place is packed.  

Great beer selection.. I went with the high alcohol content Belgium, since i didn't have to drive.  I would try to say what i got and the taste...but honestly after a while we just kept drinking...and when the alcohol kicked in...it was more like who the f cares...let's keep drinking.  We were all happy with the variety.  Even got some good conversation and drinking games with some tourist behind us.  they placed some russian game i totally forgot but seemed to vaguely recall i did ok...then i taught them some chinese drinking game using your palm but in English.  Went on for while ...you can see i'm a socially good drunk.  Also got in with some good talk while smoking outside with the other patrons.  Ahhh... this is what the haight is about...you can chat with your buddies and with total strangers... all good all fun.. what SF should be.
