Accidentally spilled because some hipster stumbled and fell on top of me.  Lucky I didn't twist an ankle, but spill their precious beer?  Don't even.

Dude, if you didn't want to mop up beer you shouldn't have taken a job in a dive bar.
author: Boots B.

description: Very loud, very grimy, music very punk rock, but the beer selection is awesome! Came here to show my friend the crazy beers.. first round was on him he bought it forgot to tip the bartender (looked like ms. daisy) and she was like: do you stiff all ur bartenders or just me?? LOL my friend had had it. gave her 3 bucks i was laughing.. needless to say we left. I will be back for the beers... but my friend.. i think hes done.
author: Frank T.

description:
I absolutely loathe Toronado. The only time I ever even THINK about trying to go into this dump for a beer is if I've stopped off at Rosamunde for some tasty sausages. Reasons Toronado is complete and utter garbage.


- Smarmy ass, shit for attitude bartenders. HEY BARTENDER, you work in the fucking service industry. Can the attitude and sense of entitlement. Nobody cares that you only drink 18th century Belgians handcrafted by monks in some godforsaken abbey. Get me a fucking beer without me having to wait a week and don't give me any lip chief.

- To fucking loud. I like to be able to talk to whoever I'm at a bar with, without having to talk into a megaphone for them to hear me. That's just not the case here. Hell, you can't even hear yourself think, let alone your buddy trying to converse with you.

- Standing room only for the most part. Standing around and drinking beers is cool for festivals and concerts, not for a watering hole.

- Sticky floors. Self explanatory, I'm up to dive bar it up just as much as the next man/woman but that shit is just plain gross.

and finally.....

TO MANY HIPSTERS!! Take your Tom Cruise risky business shades and ride your bike back to the mission (no offense to you if you have a bike, live in the mission and are not a hipster).
author: Tommy P.

description: Tornado is a dive bar for craft beer lovers.  The bartenders are a little surly but efficient.  A rude sign is displayed over the bar warning that they don't accept credit cards, but most drafts are $5. If you are wondering what beers they have available, don't rely on the list on their website. The web list gives you a good idea, but did not reflect what they has on the night (a Monday) I went.  They have open WiFI which is nice.  Tornado is great if you are looking for some local and regional craft beers at a reasonable price, but most would probably appreciate a more refined environment.
author: Steve S.

description:
There's a scene in the movie High Fidelity where Jack Black is working at a record store, and some kid wants to buy an imported Smiths album but Jack Black won't sell it to him because the kid isn't cool enough.  I always seem to feel like that kid at toronado.

Whenever I go there, the bartenders take one look at me and decide before even speaking to me that they will not serve me.  It borders on the absurd--one day, I went in there and the place was totally empty.  There were like 2 people there total.  I went up to the bar and the bartender took one look at me and then walked away.  I sat there with money in my hand waiting for him to return.  He was going back and forth behind the bar, doing busy work just so he wouldn't have to serve me.  After about 10 minutes, I thought of leaving but it was so silly I just couldn't.  I kept trying to say "Excuse me, could I get a..." and he would cut me off with a sharp "Just wait a minute!!"  So I waited.  After another 10 minutes when he figured out I wasn't going to leave, he came over and said "What do you want?"  I asked for one of the beers listed on the menu that was hanging from the ceiling.  "We're out of that," he said.  I asked for a different one.  "We're out of that too."  I asked for a beer on tap.  "I'm changing the keg right now, it will be a while."  At this point I decided I wouldn't be getting my beer and left.  

If you like hard to find beers, the best place in the bay area is the Hayward Bistro.  But it's a bit of a hike to get there from San Francisco.  La trappe in North Beach has a good selection, and City Beer on Folsom in SOMA is also great.  Not only do these other options have a BETTER selection than Toronado, they actually seem happy that you are there.  Both of these places are fairly new, and I think it's great that they're so popular.  You used to be forced to deal with Toronado because they were the only game in town.  Not anymore!
author: brandon c.

description:
Stu saved this place for us!  We'd arranged an entire vacation from PA to CA around finally being able to drink Russian River beers, particularly Pliny the Elder (as Younger is seasonal), so, obviously, we're beer drinkers.  In planning our trip, a friend who used to live in San Fran told us about Toronado and it became #2 on our list of things to do.

We spent our first night in Santa Rosa completing our pilgrimage to Russian River and then headed to Haight St for our second evening.  We arrived to a very loud and very full bar.  Two of us snagged the last table in the back room while the other two ordered beers.  The couple with us was not beer drinkers and one of them made the "mistake" of ordering a red bull and vodka to be rudely responded to with "Do you see an #I^*&^^& liquor bottles, man" as the bartender walked away.  Not a great start.   We finished our one beer and got out of there, sad and disillusioned.  

The nest afternoon, my husband and I had been at Danny Coyle's watching a Premier League game and decided to give Toronado one more try.  Upon entering, 2  well on their way guys made some sexual innuendos to me.  No biggie, I can take care of myself.  I mention this simply because Stu, our bartender today, not only noticed, but subtly took care of it w/our causing a scene.  Not expected, but appreciated.  There were 2 bar seats this afternoon which was awesome; that's where you need to be in a beer lover's paradise like this. 

I promptly ordered a Michelob Ultra, which rendered Stu a bit speechless, before I assured him I was just kidding and asked what he'd recommend.  He was super helpful and did not lead us astray.  We stayed for four pints and enjoyed both the beer and conversation w/Stu.  

Not only do they have ridiculous beers, but they are ridiculously cheap.  Apparently, service is hot or miss, but if Stu's working, you'll be treated well.  I'm so glad we gave it a second chance (though I do rec coming at on "off" time to best enjoy the place)!
author: Summer K.

description: Great beer list, BUT you can smell the bathrooms all the way by the front door. That or someone is peeing behind the bar because the entire bar reeks. I've been to my fair share of dive bars and can usually stomach a lackadaisacal attitude toward cleanliness from such establishments, but I definetely don't want the added aroma of fermenting urine with each sip of beer, but maybe that's just me. If your palate can handle the extra "flavor," this might be the place for you.
author: Romi G.

description: This place is legendary. Always excellent beers on tap, and that classic dive bar feel. If you are coming here for happy service and unicorns you are an idiot. This is a place for drinking quality beer. If you want some place classy there are lots of other places to go...
author: David K.

description: A really good place to chill and drink some of the best  beers around.
author: Camille R.

description:
Only reason that I did not give this place 5 full stars is because it is often packed and takes some time to get a drink. Other then that, this bar rules for so many reasons.

Greatest beer selection in the city hands down. They have everything you may imagine. A true beer drinker's paradise. From various barley wines to unusual IPA's, Toronado has it all. Standard pint glasses are used for the average ABV beers, with what I believe to be a 12 ounce glass for stronger ones. If you are a fan of darker, stronger ales, this is the place to explore and get really, really drunk!

Atmosphere wise, it is a bit of an older crowd (maybe I'm saying this because I'm just 21?) but it is very fun with a buddy. A seat at the bar is a bit hard to find on a busy night, but it is the way to go. Just looking up at the beer menu and the labels on tap makes this place awesome.

Happy hour ends at 6 and is awesome. $1 off the price of any is a pretty damn good deal.

Great location on Lower Haight with Molotov's right across the street. Again, the 71 will bring you right there and the N-Judah is a just a few blocks down.

Overall, great place for the beer lover in your life.
author: Zach L.

description:
Had I never been to Toronado in San Diego, I would probably give this one a four star rating. I love the beer selection but it is only half the size of the San Diego Toronado. What I did like about this bar is that it feels lived in. It has character and history. I like that about bars. I like to feel comfortable in the establishment that I am drinking in. San Francisco Toronado has that feel. Also the regulars were more than welcoming. Bryce, whom I assume is a regular since the bartender called him by name, lives in the area and chatted me up. I asked him for recommendations on other bars and restaurants in the area since my drinking partner Christina had just moved to town. 

I have mixed reviews about the bartenders. The bartender Johnny was cool. He made sure to keep the beer flowing all the while chatting up the customers. There was a shift change while we were there and two bartenders came on to replace Johnny. The woman was pretty cool but ignored me when I asked to buy a shirt. The guy with the dreads was awful. He did not even acknowledge most of the customers. Truthfully I am really not sure what his job is other than to walk back and forth behind the bar looking bored and annoyed. Thankfully we got there when Johnny was working. We decided to head out and find somewhere else to drink after experiencing these bartenders. 

Will I go back? Yeah. Will I stick around to drink if the bartender working is a jerk? Hell to the no. There are too many places in the city to spend my money.
author: Stephani S.

description:
Oh Toronado--look at you with your 600-something reviews, you slutty bar you.  Like most, I come here for the beer; not the lack of places to sit/stand/breathe (on the weekends) or the bathroom wall wisdom.

I took my parents here when they came to visit me, and it got my dad's stamp of approval, though it was weird for me to realize that they were probably the oldest folks in the premises at only 50. We stood amongst the Saturday night mosh pit and enjoyed our beverages while gazing at all of the past/present/future beer taps lining the ceiling and walls. Good enough for me.
author: Alys D.

description: Great selection of beers! Death and Taxes on tap is always a plus. This is definitely place my husband and I will be visiting again. Side note: Mythic Pizza is right next door :-)
author: Briana B.

description: A dog bar?! Yay! This bar can get crowded, but they have a ton of beers on hand AND they allow you to bring your pup! It is also a pretty dark bar (more so in the back), but not too bad.  Love going there in the daytime, but night is fun too. So go grab a nice plump and tasty sausage next door at Rosamunde Sausage Grill, insert into mouth and wash it down with one of their many beers! Great place!
author: Kat M.

description:
Admittedly, I was half-cocked when I walked into Toronado after spending a good part of the afternoon at nearby Magnolia. That said, I absolutely loved Toronado -- amazing list of local No Cal beers and a really fun vibe. Good music, good people and the surly bartender even offered to share her pretzels.

Can't wait to come back!!!
author: Andy S.

description: Great beer selection.  They always have something new that I haven't had before.  I really like this place.  Unfortunately they also have a notoriously rude staff. Fortunately,  I've only watched it and not been the focus of it.
author: Sarah G.

description:
No one is going to complain about the beer selection here.  And if you're here during happy hour, you're getting some awesome beers for a song.  As an added bonus, you can bring in any food you want so long as you keep drinking beer.

Unfortunately, I'm used to much better service.  The Peter Pettigrew look-a-like of a bartender couldn't care less if you were there.  He was absolutely no help with any of the beers.  I'm sure he knew his stuff, he just didn't give a rat's ass.

Having to walk over wet floor to take a piss is pretty lame also.  I just hope its water I'm standing on...
author: David C.

description: My boyfriend sure loves his beer, so this was the ideal place to take him.  Toronado is just what a dive bar should be--no frills, crowded tables, loud customers, and bartenders who aren't there to make friends. We were both really impressed by the huge beer selection here, both domestic and imported. We ordered a couple Chimays, and being big fans of this beer, we both really enjoyed it waaay better on tap.  It was quite refreshing!  I can't wait to come back and try a new beer. I also heard you can order sausages from the spot next door and they'll take it into the bar for you!
author: Anne A.

description:
Heard about this place from a few folks, but never had a chance to go until a friend wanted to meet up the other night.

It's fine, really - no actual complaints - but no actual accolades either. If it was my neighborhood pub, I'd definitely frequent - but  I wouldn't go out of my way to go here. Yes, there are about 100 beers here (not 1000's like some people below are claiming - sheesh, get a grip. The place is the size of a bus stop.), and most of them are interesting brews from all over the globe... but I've seen this sort of thing done better elsewhere. 

There was no beer-o-the-week blackboard and no list of brews written down. The bartender I had didn't seem terribly knowledgeable, and yet, somehow, was still arrogant - not really sure how that works. Doesn't matter tho,  even if he was knowledgeable, it wouldn't matter since we couldn't hear each other: this place is loud. Really loud. Like, if there was no one else in there but me, my friend and the bartenders we STILL wouldn't be able to hear each other. That kind of loud.

There's a lot of reviews below about how this is how a beer joint should be, not a d-bag in sight, a perfect mix of beers and friends, la la la... That's cool. Really. I get it. But, hey, if a d-bag walked in there with some sound absorbing tiles and a beer list, I'd buy him a brew.
author: Rob D.

description:
Signs you know that you're in a true SF dive bar: (1) it's dirty, (2) they only sell their top selection of various Belgian and German beer (and they yell at you if you order a Budweiser), (3) you can smell random gusts of weed aromas, (4) the bathrooms are tatted up from floor to ceiling, and (5) there's random groups of people eating food from random nearby places (mostly from Rosamunde and Mythic Pizza) having an awesome time.

This, in a nutshell, is Toronado in the Lower Haight. Their Chimay Red is delicious -- got me f'd up pretty fast. Their music is an ecclectic mix of 80's hair bands and soulful rock metal. Toronado is pretty much the place to go if you want to drink some top-shelf Belgian beers and experience the pinnacle of SF dive bars.
author: Roy C.

description:
The bouncer has a real serious attitude problem.  He likes to get in people's face about trivial issues.  The guy needs to be fired he has a very serious problem remembering events from 2 minutes ago.

The smell in the place is kinda bad as well.  Will never return to this place again.
author: J E.

description: Awesome beer selection but lacking in anything to do except for sit and talk. Rosamunde next door is nice.
author: Rohan D.

description:
dive bar , dive prices, dive service.... they have an awesome selection of beer 
but the service is so bad and surly I will never step foot in there again. 
NOT WORTH IT. many people I talk to have had bad service experiences here
author: Dylan C.

description:
If you love beer, you go to Toronado. That's all there is to it.

The service is average (bordering on surly, if you aren't quick with your order), the atmosphere nothing special, but the variety and quality of beers available is unmatched. And the prices are all pretty cheap as well (from a Russian Hill perspective at least); most between $4-6 per pint.
author: Kevin M.

description:
In the spirit of Belgian Beer month, I came here to find me a Belgian.

I didn't find one (trust me, I looked), but I did find:

a bouncer who let best friend and I carry in our gigantic slices of pizza. 
a really cute bartender who let me sample different beers. and stare.
a super tasty sour raspberry-ish belgian-ish beer ($7) (oh, it had a name?)
a hard cider ($4) that I sipped in shame (it made my insides rejoice!)
a table in an ideal spot for boy-watching.  adequate seating makes my heart beat fast.
a hangover strong enough to allow myself to be driven to Fresno at 8 am the next day.  

This belgian beer must have magical powers, because normally it takes a roll of duct tape, a gag, and 8 yards of rope to get me to visit that part of the state.
author: Janney B.

description: I LOVE THIS BAR! One of the best in the city.  If you are a been fan and haven't been here yet... GO!  They have one of the best happy hours in town, 7 days a week!  The only downside for a big night out is that they only have beer and wine (which is always fine by me, but others in your party may care).  They allow dogs which I love and have extra seating in the back.  Also, you can grab a sausage from next door and bring it in which goes great with a good microbrew.
author: Julie B.

description: SO MANY BEER CHOICES. It's awesome in that respect. But damn this place gets crowded. And they don't categorize their beers into types, which leads me totally paralyzed when trying to order. I want to know what they all are! Not all of us are beer connoisseurs. But it is most definitely the cool place to be, so if you want to be where the Lower Haight action is, or are craving a tamale from the Tamale lady, Toronado is your bar.
author: Talia G.

description:
For my 100th review, I knew that I needed to do something important - the review that I would have the most trouble with telling the whole story while keeping it relevant and honest. With this in mind, I decided that I would have to do the Toronado.

I have a long history with the bar. For the final years of the last millenium, my wife and I chronicled our evenings there on our online journal (yes, this was pre-blogging), and there was lots to blog about. We talked about the bartenders, the regulars and the invaders from the Marina who looked utterly confused when the folks behind the bar said "No, you can't have a gin and tonic" followed quickly by "No, you can't have an Amstel Light" and finally by "No, you can't pay by credit card". The Lower Haight was going through a fight for its very soul - battling against SUVs, gentrification, yuppie encroachment and the chain stores and shops that wanted to replace local establishments... and the Toronado was the point where the battle would be won or lost.

That was the late 1990s, and now in 2006, things haven't changed that much. During the days and weekday nights, it's full of regular Lower Haight denizens - and on Friday and Saturday nights, it's a battle between locals and folks from different neighborhoods (and tax brackets). Pauly, Johnny and Kirsten are still behind the bar, and Tad is still the best bouncer in the city - I mean, how many people can come up with a trivia question like "Name the three characters from MASH that were there since the first episode" on the fly? (The one that everyone misses is Nurse Kelley... she's the key to the whole series! - I think I won a beer for getting that).

So many of my life changing events - from birthdays to our going away party when we moved to Connecticut in 1999 were held at the Toronado, and while I lived just 2 blocks away in a tiny studio apartment with my wife and two cats, the Toronado was like my living room - where I went to relax and to entertain. During the big power outage when the state was plunged into darkness, the Toronado served the neighborhood beverages while Rosamunde turned on their big gas grill and served up sausages for the locals. Up until 1999, the Toronado was home.

The bar hasn't changed at all since then. The banner from the bar's first serving of Aventinus on tap is still there, and aside from the growing rack of empty 3 liter Duvel bottles on the wall, the bar is exactly the same.

The problem is that even though the Toronado hasn't changed in the past decade, I have.

I still love the beer - 46 well selected taps (though I wish they would rotate some of the taps more often - I love De Koninck, but there are other beers that should occasionally take that slot) and a bottle list that is beyond compare in this city and possibly in the country. I've gone there with judges from the Great American Beer Festival and been able to stump them with flavors they couldn't attribute to a specific beer style, let alone a brewery. I love the fact that Dave leased the space to an ex-Bartender to start Rosamunde. The festivals (Barleywine, Strong Beer, Belgian Beer, Oktoberfest, Fresh Hop and many more) are always amazing - the barleywine festival becoming one of the seminal barleywine events worldwide.

But as I get older, the music starts to quickly get too loud - and even though I used to be there two or three times a week in the late 90s, now that I am no longer a regular, sometimes I feel like a stranger. Certain new bartenders throw more attitude than necessary, giving non-regulars the stinkeye before reluctantly taking an order - which is a shame for a beer bar that beer lovers make pilgrimages to from all over the world. I'm not saying that you need to be nice, but you need to be respectful of your customers up until they make assholes of themselves.

Yeah, I don't wear t-shirts and ripped jeans any more and I live in a SOMA loft, but the Lower Haight is still in my heart, as is the Toronado.

Still, I would love for them to install a drain in the bathroom so I don't have to wade through the piss on the floor when I have to take a leak.
author: Avery G.

description:
Paul 4rm da hood"

Woke up quick, at about noon
jus' thought I had to be in Toronado soon
I gotta get drunk before the football begins
before folks start bitchin bout another 49ers win
about to go, 1st stop Thai Times
fillin up  on noodles, now my stomachs fine
grabbed my money clip
jumped back in my brothas whip
"Yo Bo, let the alpine play...
pumpin classic shit by NWA"
cruisin down the street, towards Fil'mo
lookin for parkin, avoidin the 5-0
a car pulls up, who can it be
"yo don't I know you, you AKA G"

Cuz Paul from the hood is always hard
you don't know yo shit,
he'll pull your card.
knowing nothing in life
but to make them tips
don't quote me boy
cuz I ain't said shit!

50 taps!!! They outa control
wrapped my lips around 6, still wanted some mo'
I looked at a liter and said to my brother
"yo kill that by the half I'll buy you another"
I asked Paul to get me a Stella
"What you can't read the board G, don't be a dumb fella"

Paul from the hood is always hard
you don't know yo shit,
he'll pull your card.
knowing nothing in life
but to make them tips
don't quote me boy
cuz I ain't said shit!
author: Jamal G.

description:
This is the best place in the city to get a beer!  It's just beer damn it.  Not that stuff you see sponsoring the SuperBowl, or the stuff with stupid bullet trains in the commercial.  This is the real deal.  

If you don't know anything about beer, then the staff will let you know it and you probably won't come back again which is great for the real beer drinkers.  If you want a Pliny the Elder and want to listen to the Trooper, then it's phenomenal.
author: Duchess B.

description: Back for Barley wine festival!  Didn't have as many great selections as last year, but still a fun experience overall. We stayed clear of grumpy bartender from last year.
author: Vonda R.

description:
I wanted a lot of good beer with minimal bullshit, so I headed over to Toronado. It's been a rough week, and sometimes a girl needs a fiendishly good I.P.A in a place where everyone leaves her to her own devices

I've been searching high and low for a gnome and was seriously envious of their little pointy hated friend shooting me a mocking smile from high above the bar. The wall is littered with photos, some aged and from what appears to be like decades ago.  "Behind blue Eyes" played, and my severely mopey countenance and increasingly inebriated ass identified with the selection, in a way that made me think these were my people. 

My musings were briskly interrupted by the questioning yell of "Steve?!? Nick?!?" The half door by the entryway makes the ideal platform for Rosamunde, the hot dog joint next door, to try and pinpoint its wandering customers. The "no dogs allowed" sign is entertaining in an ironic way, given that there were two furry critters taking turns at emitting piercing howls. 

Beers on draught are proudly marqueed high to the left of the bar. In addition to their list of draughts, they have an extensive bottled beer selection. Unfortunately, the available selection differs slightly from what is advertised on the website, so you may have to hope the beer you've had your eye on is still there. But overall, their selection is pretty goddamned decent, and almost all of their seats were taken when I popped in at 1:30pm on a weekday. Apparently everyone else had the same great idea of extending their lunch hour to down a few pints, although my guess is no one there really works standard nine to five hours in business casual. 

I got extremely excited, I mean sexually, by how many hot scruffy dudes populated the place - and were genuinely nice. I had serious thoughts of blowing off the rest of my workday and my income, but I figured that wouldn't be the wisest or most appreciated use of my time. Another charming touch was the dude sitting on a barstool, burping his ABCs as his dog yelped in accompaniment.
author: Kristen H.

description:
I've had nothing but a good experience time after time here. Sure, there are plenty of beer snobs who frequent this place. (I may in fact be one of them, depending on who you talk to.) But I've found that asking someone what they're drinking leads just as often to a conversation about what I'm studying, or biking in San Francisco, or traveling and exploring new cities (just to name some recent examples) as it does into microbrew minutiae. Which is to say the beer nerddery is there for the taking, but it's not the only thing on the table. 

Also, I'm not sure where these complaints about bad service come from. Sure, it can get busy and crowded at times but that's par for the course. During the Octoberfest celebration last week it was nuts--but the bartender still was courteous enough to answer questions about the beer on tap & provide tastings of a more curious brew (Moonlight's Artimis Gruit, for those wondering--made with wormwood in place of hops!). Plus, at the end of the night my buddy came home with a liter stein--courtesy of the bartender--even thought they had run out of them during the earlier promotion. What a night!
author: alejandro p.

description:
Great chill bar to go to at any time of the day or night. Has a good amount of seating so it's good for groups, and they have an amazingly large selection of beers. 

Staff is friendly, and I've always been pleased with any beer recommendations I take them up on. Also, bringing in hot dogs from the rosemunde's sausage next door is an added bonus.

Finally, location is great. There are tons of other bars nearby, in case you feel the need to explore a different scene after a few hrs of beer-filled awesomeness. Although I'm not sure why you would.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Met some buddies here before a show at the Fillmore.  I'm not really much of a beer drinker, so I felt a little like an atheist in church.  But it has a great dive bar feel to it and is appropriately rough around the edges without trying to be.   I did actually check out some of the reviews before going and was prepared for the asshole bartender treatment.  SInce I don't know shit about beer, I thought how perfect, I can test this out with some really dumb-ass questions.  

The place was packed on a Friday night.  I met my friends and we found seats at the far end of the bar.  "Waddayawant?"  So far so good.  Service is speedy.   I briefly considered asking him to tell me about each of the over 100 beers they have, but quickly decided against it.   "I don't know a lot about beer but I have enjoyed a good Hefeweizen now and again.  Can you tell me which of yours is the best?," I asked.

At which point, he slowly and politely  told me which of his Hefeweizens was the best.  I ignored his recommendation, and ordered the cheapest one, which was quite nice.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Update, almost 1.5 years later. Aug 24, 06

My second time at Toronado. First time I get yelled at, branded as a yuppie, and asked to go to a bar in Hayes Valley or the Marina. I  vowed never to show my face again. Gil, last night was finishing a pizza there and I offered to meet him outside. He offered me a beer and I walk in. Ohhhh shit! I had a collared shirt and a sport jacket on. Immediately, I was prowled on, Gil's beer taken away, the whole bar formed a mob - all ready to beat us up. Gil asked for an explanation of why we were being kicked out and had a few dollar bills thrown on his face.

We walked out. I'm never ever going here again. Even if they offer to do my wedding here for free!

-------------------
No shit that the bartender wants you to go to another bar. Steve (I think thats what his name is) is the fat bartender who is a total idiot. Total with a Capital T. The first time I went there was directly from work (I had meetings so wore a collared shirt) and had no idea it was cash only so offered my credit card, and Steve almost ran after me for a block. He had this furious and hostile look on his face I will never forget.
author: Sav B.

description:
a dirty, grungy pub without redeeming features, and on top of that parking is always horrendous.  the bartenders are *never* pleasant and it's always a hassle to get a drink here.  impressive list of beers to be sure, but they are usually out of most of them.  i've always dreaded going as it's always a tribulation from finding parking to elbowing one's way to the sticky, dirty bar, but i'd let myself get dragged here on occasion until a recent horrendous experience with the bartender.   

completely unprovoked, he treated our entire group like dirt and essentially refused to serve us. i still am not sure what provoked this episode - it was a relatively quiet evening and we were well-behaved.  customers should never have to beg to get a drink in a bar just because the bartender is in a foul mood.  in case management reads this, the bartender in question is the one with greasy, stringy dark hair pulled back in a ponytail (as if that narrows it down at all), and as far as i am concerned there is ABSOLUTELY no excuse for treating customers like dirt - this is one of the rare occasions i left a bar feeling worse than when i walked in.  

speaking of management, before posting this review, i sent a detailed email providing specifics and feedback about our experience and... never heard back.  not a word.  there are plenty of bars in sf, and an establishment which cares nothing for its customers and treats them like garbage will eventually run itself into oblivion... and that is exactly what toronado deserves.  when the next guy takes over i look forward to returning just to have a drink over the grave of this horrible, dirty, unpleasant, unfriendly establishment.
author: lois j.

description: Good beer selection and good vibe, but please get off your anti-establishment high horse and start accepting cards.
author: Justin M.

description:
Allow me to throw my two cents in about this place...

1) A good selection of beers from all over the map.

2) I brought a Belgian friend in here once, who recently moved to SF, and even HE WAS IMPRESSED with the selection.
author: NirvAnna M.

description:
The best thing about this place was the cute little scruffy dog who sauntered around the bar like he owned it and occasionally remembered that we were eating sausages up at the front and would beg from us.  
I am not a huge beer girl, but I live with a beer-obsessed Wisconsin boy who is in heaven with a beer and a sausage in front of him.  So I can appreciate the enjoyment he gets from this loud, dark and sort of smelly bar.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I have a theory. Each SF neighborhood has it's own smell. Some are good, some are bad, and many are somewhere in between. I contend that each neighborhood has one establishment that is the symbol of it's smell. 

Toronado IS the smell of the Lower Haight, both literally and symbolically.

I've been coming to this SF institution for nearly 10 years.  What can I say about this place that hasn't been said before? .This is the best beer bar in the world as far as I'm concerned.
author: Dustin E.

description:
I'm generally one of the only girls in here, it kind of smells, and generally has bad music, so why did I use to come here all the time? 

Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer 
Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer 
Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer 
Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer 
Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer 

That's how many beers they have on tap. 46!

I won't write out how many varieties they have in bottles. That would just be obnoxious.
author: Michelle B.

description:
I luuuuuuuuuuv you!

It's too bad you don't have Lagunitas IPA on tap because I'd luuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuv you even more!
author: Lara H.

description:
I love this place when I can get a seat (and love it even more when I can get a sausage from Rosamunde's to go with my beer). I've always found the bartenders to be friendly if you're friendly to them, but if you're expecting a song and dance or 5-star service you're definitely in the wrong place. 

Tips:

-Don't order a lame mass produced beer here

-Don't come here on a date, unless they're a hipster and are all about being "authentic."

-Don't expect to NOT get beer spilled on you (either by yourself, when you end up trashed while drinking 9% ABV beer...or by that 21-year-old screaming about last night's party standing close enough to make out with you)

-Do ask the bartenders for recs (they're really helpful)

-Do take that pole out of your ass, loosen up, and have a good time
author: Britt M.

description: San Francisco beer mecca. If you like beer then look no further. Maybe the best selection of taps in the city. Very busy on the weekend. Good luck sitting down if that's what you had in mind. Tamale lady makes visits and sausages next door and they don't mind if you bring it in. Have fun.
author: Zachery H.

description:
Yum...BEER! 

If you like beer, especially good beer, then you'll love Toronado. They have great stuff on tap and it's next door to Rosamunde's (the sausage place). There is seating along the front, a room in the back with a couple booths and tables and another room in the far back that I just discovered during the Barley Wine Festival last weekend. 

There's also three bathrooms and the one in the back room is pretty large.
author: Jackie G.

description: Been here a couple of times now and it is a great place with a great selection of beers!! The bartenders were helpful and nice. Really love this place :)
author: K S.

description:
If I were a bar in San Francisco,* I would be Toronado.


*Plagiarized from Amy W.'s review of Tunnel Top
author: Kathryn T.

description:
Beer SNOB heaven. And I lust for they key to its Pearly Gates all the time. Toronado is the equivalent of a wine bar for beer lovers of course. Bar has a slummy feel. Not pretty in any manner. Random posters, stickers and signs thrown up. Darkly lit interior. Plenty of seating. Wood tables and stools. Man heaven is awesome.

Walk in through a half of a door. Not sure of the proper name. Kind of like on a barn or some old country farm house. Bouncer stands behind the half of a door (as we can CALL it!)., nicely takes your identification. You are immediately greeted with a giant sign above the bar area, listing all the beers. Think I injured my neck from staring to long and being indecisive. Fan of hoppy beers so opted for my favorite Hop Stoopid and tried a new one Denogginator by Drake's. Hit the spot. 

When ordering a beer or many beers. The wait time can be a bit long if it is crowded, and the bartenders are not the friendliest bunch. KNOW what you are going to order, or they will move along. But they are more than happy to recommend something or offer a taste. In that area they EXCEL. 

Plenty of room to SIT. You might have to come a bit earlier on a busy weekend night to score a spot. Toronado though is best enjoyed on a week night though with some close friends.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Best beer selection in...the country? Very likely. At least one of the most adventurous -- lots to choose from, always changing, and with a seasonal bent, too. Some of the servers have attitude, but they're decent folks -- ask for a taste and they often give it without a hassle; ask for an opinion (when it's not crazy busy mind you) and ditto, if they've had it they'll give the lowdown. Rockin' rollin' juke too, nice plus. A favorite for lazy Sundays and any other day, really.

2007 Update:
It's a bummer to have to write this, as I have loved the Toronado for years, since it opened in fact. Amazing beer selection, for that this place has no equal. I've also put up with the surly staff--another case where this joint has no equal. Recently though I witnessed a case where one bartender really crossed the line, tossing a poor guy out on his ass for no reason. Fake-punk dude with lots of tattoos and an  angry-frat-boy attitude. The kind spoiling for a fight. Now I don't mind surly--hell I'm surly most of the time--but when did the Toronado's trademark surliness cross the line into anger? And I mean dangerous anger. This place is now downright scary. Dave, is this really the kind of place you want to run? Time to consider cleaning a little house.
author: Canby T.

description:
My friend brought me here when I was in town for the weekend and I had a great time.  It was Saturday night, the place was loud and pretty cramped, and I think they had a pretty good selection of classic rock if I'm remembering correctly (a big if).  The bartenders were quirky but seemed nice enough, I gave my guy a couple of bucks tip when we ordered our first round and he looked me in the eye and said "hey, thanks a lot."  Don't know about what kind of crowd comes here, but there weren't any particularly egregious assholes or anything, which is always a plus.

The real draw of this place was the beer.  I think I ordered a Pliny the Elder for $5 or something?  Wow.  Seriously, I'm used to bars charging that much for a Bud Light.  So yeah, if you and your friends are currently or would like to become beer snobs, this is a good place to go.  Not sure the place has any particular draw if you're not a beer drinker.

Oh, and it says it in the info up top, but they don't accept credit cards.  This is made up for by the fact that they have an awesomely-ghetto cash register.
author: Brian J.

description:
Toronado has a ton of beers on draft, yes.  Its actually one of the best selections in the city.
Toronado usually has more men then women who drink beer in the bar, yes. (which for a straight woman, isn't usually a problem)
Toronado however does NOT have the space for all of these people who come in and drink the beer, no.
Toronado does also NOT have the proper number of bartenders to pour said beer for all the people who come in and want to drink it.
So, do I suffer waiting too long for my beer? I tend to.
Do I come back because of the location as well as the selection?  Probably.
Is it my most favoritist bar in the city?  Definitely not, but you will probably find me here again...sooner than later.
author: Lauren F.

description:
If you are a beer snob, you will LOVE this place.  If you want to order a Corona, the bartender will laugh at you.  For a "dive bar", Toronado has some high standards on what is real beer and what isn't.  The walls are decorated with all sorts of cool paraphernalia advertizing beers around the world.  I usually get Two Rivers which is a pomegranate hard cider which they have on tap.


5 stars for the beer selection (if you didn't want a Corona or Bud Light!)
3 stars for the crowd
3 stars for service
Overall: a cool, unique bar on Haight St - stop by when the crowd isn't there.
author: Laura W.

description: Fantastic beer selection. I come in here almost every Saturday afternoon (when not at Monk's Kettle) for some serious beers. Taps change out often so there always seems to be something new to try. Currently I've been indulging in Blind Pig IPA, Rodenbach Grand Cru, and Red Rocket Ale on hand pump. Ambiance rocks, jukebox is killer, but it can get a little smelly towards the back on warm days. Great sausages next door to bring into the Toronado and Memphis Minnie's is across the street for some BBQ. One thing I'll agree with other reviewers is the fact that the staff can be quite surly, but can also be quite helpful if you follow normal bar rules, like not waving your money in the air or shouting for the bartender. Be chill and make eye contact and you will get served.
author: Scott L.

description:
They do have a good selection of beer but it's a bar.  Shouldn't that be the norm?  Ok, ok, they have a stellar selection of beer.

We came here after Capsule on Sunday because some of us wanted sausages from Rosamunde and others wanted to watch basketball.  Unfortunately, Rosamunde was closed and I wasn't drunk enough not to be annoyed by the unpleasant bartenders.  

The other patrons were cool and we were able to get seating so it ended up being ok.  Still, without Rosamunde, I don't know that it's worth returning to.
author: Seong P.

description:
We got some sausages from Rosemunde and brought them over to have a nice beer with them.  I ordered some kind of crazy double IPA, and my buddy ordered a Miller Lite.

...scrrreeeaaatcchhh.

The juke box went silent and some guy grabbed a barstool and smashed it over my buddy's head.   There was an all out brawl and we both got chucked out onto the sidewalk.

...

I'm using hyperbole here, but when my buddy ordered his macro-brew, the bartender was a complete prick and basically told us to leave.  My buddy got some pilsner, we finished our sausages and went over to Molotov's across the street for some Mickey's malt liquor.

I like a place with attitude, but there's no reason to be an all out prick.  I won't be going there again, and I'm sure I won't be missed.
author: Rocco B.

description:
I loved this place. Definitely the place for amazing beer on tap in San Francisco. I should note that I have only been once...and I was already drunk. BUT! Not drunk enough to forget its awesomess.

I really cannot understand all the "Haight" (get it? See what I did there? No? Okay...moving on) for this place here on Yelp. Your bartender was a bit of a jerk? Well you were probably a jerk first/didn't know what you wanted/didn't know what kind of situation you were getting yourself into. When you go to order, KNOW WHAT YOU WANT! Especially if the place is busy. Have some common sense people. I knew what I wanted, ordered, TIPPED A DOLLAR PER BEER and I had zero problems with the guy who was working that day. In fact he was very cool. 

Also, I don't remember the exact time I went (7pmish?) but the entire time we were there it was happy hour. 3 bucks for all different kinds of amazing draft beers? Uuumm hell yeah! 

Anyways, loved pretty much everything about the place. Cant wait to go back!
author: Jonathan T.

description:
A couple of years ago, Brian and I hit this place up after bein' awake for a lot of hours, a little over 24 or so.  We were bein' troopers since we had  to kill a couple of hours before meeting up with our friend Miles over in the East Bay.  If you have any taste for good beer, then rest assured this place is a little slice of heaven in the city. 

There are sooo many amazing beers on draft at Toronado!  It really makes Southern California bars laughable.  The only bummer is that when the place is crowded the floor is sticky and the bathroom is terrible.  Realllly bad.  The worst.
author: Sarah V.

description: I am originally from Philly which is a huge craft beer city and have lived in San Francisco for three months and finally decided to visit Toronado today. They do have a decent selection but the bartender was awful. I believe her name was Robin and every time I ordered a beer she seemed confused and looked up at the menu on the wall for assistance. When i ordered bottled beer to go she doubled back and said "ok let's do this one at a time" and had to take the bottle menu with her to retrieve each beer one at a time. She clearly had no knowledge of the beer she was selling. In addition to that she was rude and impatient. I can deal with that, it isn't an upscale bar and doesn't try to be, but a craft Belgium beer bar should employ people who know beer and train them on the beer they sell. I didn't even bother to ask her about the beers i was unfamiliar with and just looked them up on my phone. i must be spoiled by Philly because Toronado's "extensive" bottle list included less than 100 beers and any good Belgian beer bar specializing in sours and barrel aged beers will have well over 500 in Philly. That being said and since we are in SF and not Philly, go to monks kettle our church's key if you want better choices and more knowledge staff
author: Drew S.

description:
I love beer. I love new things. That being said, I hate going to Trader Joe's and staring at the beer aisle and saying... "I wish they had some weird beer I've never had." This is why Toronado gets 5 stars. There is ALWAYS a new beer to try here! 

Also, the bartenders are sooo awesome. I love it when they are nice. One night my friend and I stopped here (she's a cider fan and they have a pomegranate one she had never had) and sat at the bar chatting with them about how drunk the girl falling off the stool next to us was. Eventually they told me all sorts of things about beer I didn't know and let me taste all their favorites and stare at all their kegs. THEN, the best part, they gave us both 2 FREE shots of these weird drinks (kind of like fernet - which i love). I need to go back and get the name. Apparently it's made of herbs and not considered hard alcohol (they don't have a hard liquor license) and calms your stomach. It was gross and new and fun and free. 

And yes, if you didn't catch that up there... THEY DON'T SERVE HARD ALCOHOL. So don't complain when you get there cause beer is AWESOME. And if you don't like it, then you don't like me. And that makes me sad.

Also... They DON'T SERVE shitty american "beer". So if you can't go a night without your Budlight, I'm sorry. They only serve real beer here.
author: Ali R.

description:
Thank God for Toronado and its relatively vast -- for San Francisco -- and cheap -- for San Francisco -- selection of beers on tap.  It's like a smaller, hippier version of Zeitgeist that is closer to my house and next to Rosamunde's sausage.

If you're sampling the lesser known brews, beware of the hops!  Other than that, happy drinking abounds at Toronado.
author: Erin L.

description:
I stopped by Toronado Friday night to experience a double header extravaganza of Rosamunde's sausages and interesting beers I've never tried before. 

It was pretty packed on Friday night as should be expected.  I was able to get a drink pretty quickly even still at a packed bar, I first sampled the Damnation from Russian River Brewing Co.  It came in a strange "fruity" glass as one of my coworkers commented, usually the hallmark of a strong beer.  I was happy to discover the Damnation did not have a ridiculously strong bite which I hate, It was really smooth and tasty, I really liked it.  

After cleansing my palette with a Rosamunde sausage, I sampled Barney Flats Stout.  It was smooth rich and very balanced.  I was surprised to find my two random choices were rewarded with two brilliant beers.  But credit must go to Toronado for putting together such a great menu, I hope to be back to try some new beers.
author: Eric L.

description:
Belgian Beer Month in April.  

Chimay Triple on draft.  WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAH!!!!  let me say it again, CHIMAY TRIPLE ON DRAFT.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Well, the beer selection is fantastic. The best. Who would dispute that?

And the inside is great. It's exactly the kind of place you want to spend the last few pennies of your paycheck slowly getting drunk on a Friday afternoon.

But the staff? Well, I'm all for a take-no-shit attitude but really, do you need to be belligerent to me because I asked a question about one of your beers? I'm not an expert in beer, true, but I didn't know I needed to be to hand you my money and be a customer.

Two stars only. I would have given you five, but I can get my drunk on somewhere else. Enjoy your anger.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Good beer selection. (belgium, microbrews)

Cheap Beer, average draught price about $4.00
There bottled beer selection is good but a couple dollars too expensive, i don't recommend buying a bottle from this place.  For good bottled beer (selection and prices) I recommend going to Monument Liquor (Concord) Trappist (oakland) EJ Phair (Concord) Albatross (Berkeley)

When I was at Toronado (Thursday night)  they played Rock (60's-today's) and Metal music. (No hip-hop, rap)

Comfortably accommodates groups up to 12 people.  
However seating fills up from 9:30.

They allow you to bring in outside food.

Chick bartender (brunette between 30-40 years old) is nice.  Australian dude bartender is intimidating, he can't hear well, and he says offensiveness comments. 

I will never make a trip to SF to go to Toronado.  I will only return to this bar during the day time or if I am in within a couple of blocks of this place and am craving a good beer.
author: Emerald M.

description:
I wish I had a neighborhood bar like this in the South Bay! 

Pints were only $3 during Happy Hour and there were at least 20 beers on tap (from around California and Europe).

I had a peche (peach) beer and a hefeweizen from Belgium. The peach beer was very peachy, but tart. The hefe was refreshing and easy to drink, with a slightly fruity finish. They were both served in their appropriate glasses!

The bartenders were super chill and nice (will give you recommendations if you ask), the Red Sox were playing on the flat screen, and ... *best part ever* ... Rosamunde Sausage Grill next door! 

Brats, beer, and baseball? Best Friday things.
author: Christine N.

description:
Toronado is awesome, but it is not for the faint of heart. Here is what my first experience was like:

My brain: OH HOLY CRAP TOO MANY BEERS
Me: Umm...
My brain: I CANT EVEN DECIDE WHICH LIST OF BEER TO LOOK AT
Me: Hey, uhh, so what are you getting?
Ben: Why don't you ask the bartender for advice?
My brain: BECAUSE I WILL SOUND LIKE A SHIT 
Me: Okay. Good idea.
Surliest Bartender Ever: What'll you have?
Me: Umm...umm...can you recommend something?
My brain: OH GOD LIZ YOU SOUND LIKE A SHIT
SBE: (seethes and walks away)
My brain: NOW WE HAVE NO BEER AT ALL ASSBAG 
Me (to brain): It's not like you had a better idea.
SBE: (returns with a sample) 
My brain: JUST ORDER WHATEVER IT IS AND BE POLITE
Me: Yes, this is fine, thank you sir.
SBE: (serves beer, resumes seething) 
Ben: What are you drinking?
My brain: I HAVE NO FUCKING CLUE
Me: Uhh...uhh...erm...it's good! Try it!
author: Liz G.

description: The owner doesn't tolerate disabled patrons. If you go and are, beware. We came with a group of 11. Many who WERE regulars. She decided to focus on a patron on crutches just out of surgery on two ankles. She very arrogantly informed her that she was sorry she was injured but she has a business to run and she was in the way of paying customers. Well, she had 11 of us all around her and paying. The witch caused my daughter to hobble out in tears. Yes she was just drinking pelagrino, but come on. When I challenged her she rudely kept on her attitude.
author: Brian Y.

description:
Without a doubt they have the best beer in the city.

Yes, the bartenders are surly. Suck it up and deal with it. You're over 21, so you should be able to deal with minor crises.

Yes, the bathrooms are dirty and need to be repainted. Just hold your nose and get out as soon as you can. They're slated to be painted again in 2011.

Yes, they play the same Rush song on the jukebox every night. Just ignore it. I usually do.

Regardless I love the place.

Here's some tips for newbies:

(1) Don't ask asinine questions. No one likes asinine questions especially bartenders at an extremely busy bar. If it's a slow night they'll be willing to answer for you. 

(2) Be patient. The service is horrible, but it's worth the wait.

(3) Try something new or something you haven't heard of. If you don't like it, then that's okay.  It will still make you feel good.

(4) If you like dark beers, try the Maredsous 8 or the Aventinus. If you like Budweiser or other pissy American beers, try the Radeberger. It's a nice, light pilsner that will make you happy.

(5) If you're from the Marina, dress in a ratty pair of jeans and a t-shirt. Blend in. I know this sound really snobby, but the truth of the matter is that you're less likely to be served in a quick manner if you are dressed like you're a member of the Yale rowing team. When in Rome and all...

(6) Close the friggin' door when you go in and out. You weren't born in a barn, were you?

Follow these tips and you'll have a great night.
author: Mark G.

description:
Sweet delicious mecca of beer. I swear, I have never seen such a beautiful selection of beers. I've heard plenty of stories about the callous demeanor of the bartenders here - but honestly, I've never had a bad experience. I've seen them be a little short with people, but understandably so! This place is regularly pretty packed, and they have a lot of beer - it's a recipe for indecisiveness. If you've gotten their attention, you better know exactly what you want, don't clam up and start second guessing yourself, make up your mind and just order. Or at least narrow it down to a couple and get their input. Do this, and I doubt you'll have any complaints about the service!

Best thing ever: Rosamunde is next door. They will let you take your sausage in here. Amazing sausage + amazing beer = happy Ben. Unless you're a very, very strange person, this combo will probably make you happy too. If it doesn't, let's never hang out. Deal?
author: Ben Y.

description:
So I've been here a few times, and I've usually had a pretty good time...I went for the first time the other night during a weekend night, and I was pretty surprised at how packed the place was...but you don't come here for the people, or the service (a bit gruff to put it nicely), or even to really hang out with your friends.  You come here for the beer. 

And yes, they have a wonderful, fantabulous beer selection.  It's fun to come here and sample beers you've never heard of, or to come back for your favorite hard to find beer...highly recommended for the beer connoisseur!

Update: I've lowered it to two stars, based solely on the beer snobs who go here often. I mean god damned, I like quality beer too, but do you have to be such an asshole about it? This goes to the people who think they're the best shit ever just because they like some damned Trappist ale from Belgium. 

This douchebaggery is on display by, "Brewbacca", who even bothered to write my g/f about her review, telling her to "go back to the marina" because she ordered a fucking hard cider. Also, if it's not cool to order it there, why the hell do they pour it? Asshole.
author: Matthew S.

description:
I stopped by on my cross country road trip some Austin TX to Seattle WA. A two hour detour that all my friends told me was worth it and that I had to go.

After spending 30 minutes trying to find parking I showed up on a Monday at 1 pm and the place was jam packed. I wouldn't want to show up on a Friday evening as it was hard enough to move around while I was there.

The space it self is cool but I didn't get a good vibe from the people there. No one seemed very friendly.

The tap list was pretty good but I wasn't overly impressed. On the up side they had a nice bottle list and I got to buy a Cuvee de Tomme and Older Viscosity to go with me.

If I ever end up back in San Francisco I'll probably try to swing by again but I won't be going out of my way to come back. I might have just hit it on a bad day.
author: Joshua S.

description:
So here's the drill.  

You go to Rosamunde, the sausage place next door, and order lunch from their great variety of sausages and condiments.  They'll ask you if you're taking your sausage to Toronado.  You will reply:  "Yes I am.  Oh yeah.  You bet I am."

You take your sausage to Toronado and make your selection from the fookin' ginormous variety of beers on tap, including more than half a dozen hoppy IPAs and a dizzying selection of malty Belgian ales.  

(Warning:  Don't walk up to the bar and act like you can't make up your mind owing to the vast array of choices.  The barkeep will typically treat you like a diseased cur dog if you stand there giving him a blank Lithium stare.  So when asked, "Whaddul ya have?" you'll need to promptly respond, "Racer IPA" or whatever.)

You'll sit down with your amazing sandwich, overstuffed with the grilled goodies you selected with your sausage, and wash it down with pint of malty, hoppy goodness.  Man, I can't wait for Bay-to-Breakers so that I can go here for lunch the day before.

Extra star for having Supersuckers and Drive-By Truckers CDs on the funky old jukebox.  "I don't mean no harm, I just like to flirt....but most of all I like bulldozers and dirt."
author: Buzz F.

description:
Touch me I'm sick....
GD amazing beers. Hand pump, room temperature goodness. However staffed by the biggest, pinkest dicks in the city. Wonder why it smells like your brother's high school jock strap when you walk in the door? It's a dick house, that's why. I had a friend who was refused service because he was wearing a suit. Cute. I like beer. I hate it when it is served by dicks. Oh, and the jukebox blows.
author: Jimmy T.

description:
Perfect place for a pint in San Francisco, especially during the day at happy hour prices.

Atmosphere is casual, with plenty of quality beer memorabilia on the walls. Nice open access to the street for that perfect Northern California breeze to sweep inside.

Selection and prices are hard to beat, ranging from the hard to get West Coast beers to outstanding Belgians. On my visits the beers were served in proper glassware, unlike some other top rated BeerFly places that used the standard 16 oz. pintglass.
author: Albert H.

description:
This is the best beer bar I have came across in San Francisco. Large selection of beers from local breweries including Russian River, Lagunitas, and He'Brew. Good selection of Belgium beers as well including beers from Chimay. Pliny The Elder is poured there! There are draft and bottle menus. They sell 3 liter bottles!

Prices are very reasonable. Pints during Happy Hour are $4 dollars. After Happy Hour pints are $5. Prices are much more reasonable compared to the Monk's Kettle.

The bar allows food from outside to be eaten at the bar. Lots of food places nearby so you can grab a pint and eat at this place.

The crowd is cool. Gets very packed! Easy to spark a conversation among the crowd. I met several folks in IT who I exchanged contact info with. Seems to be a good place to network with IT folks.

When I visit San Francisco I'll definitely visit again. Good selection of beers and reasonable prices. And, its very close to Union Square and SOMA. Decent walk from the hotel to there.
author: Matthew V.

description: I'm not giving this place another dime.  They treat their customers like shit.  The female bartender has issues too.  She was yelling at a customer saying "go fight your mother!!" after I saw the guy politely try to order a drink... WTF??  The poor guy was just as confused as I was.   Then the bartender proceeded to act as if the guy was crazy.... ummmm, I think we all know who the crazy one is.
author: Evan K.

description:
This is a dive bar? Why? Bc its small? Hmm I thought it was just a bar.

Anyway, I am not that into beer - and they have ALL kinds here so I am bound to like something. 

The reason I go: SAUSAGE FEST. HELLO?!!! There are guys here AND I AM SINGLE. 

Yep. That's pretty much it. There are other bars nearby if this one has lame sausages inside.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Toronado is legit. They have one primary concern & it's not to serve dorky yelpers who want to "go out on a limb" to see what an IPA tastes like. The primary concern is beer.  Accordingly, their selection is astounding. When coupled with a delicious sausage from next door, you're confronted with an undeniably amazing meal.

If you like your PBR with an orange slice and pleasantries as bland as your beverage - go elsewhere. The atmosphere here is gritty, the regulars can be hostile, and the service isn't always with a smile. But would you want your beer and sausage any other way?
author: Kevan M.

description: The place for beers in SF, great casual atmosphere to hang with friends and enjoy Big Daddy's incredible selection of on tap drafts.
author: Jon I.

description: I was having an awesome time watching the World Cup with my dear friend Yumi Sun.  The first bartender was super cool, giving me some recommendations from the absolutely huge list of artisan beers.  Then I was confronted by a really unpleasant bartender. He demanded that I move my stool down the bar so that there was more room for others to sit at the bar.  The problem is, there was absolutely no room at the bar.  I looked at him like he was crazy, but he gave me a "hey, I'm a tough guy" look game.  So, I had to squeeze down the bar, causing the guys to my right to make "hey this is San Francisco" gay jokes. So, why are some bartenders so power-hungry.
author: Daniel F.

description: If your'e a beer lover you'll have to go .You will enjoy yourself.OK you may not care for the overly loud music(I put in my trusty  ear plugs- have to preserve my tinnutis ridden ears as best I can.They were traumatised years ago at CBGB by the Ramones).The place is almost comically grungey and its really not a good place for a conversation.The costumers are a fairly seedy looking crew but where else are you going to get the selection of draft beers you find here ?Maybe at the Gingerman but this place has more "character'.And customers take no offense,I prefer you to the businessmen yuppie types at the Gingerman or even DBA.Also I like the idea that you can bring in a sandwhich from the next door sausage shop.
author: John K.

description:
Why didn't you guys tell me this place existed?  Oh my god, talk about a beer selection.  Whether I'm looking for something from the North Coast Brewery or prefer to explore non-local beers, Toronado is the place to be for beer-drinkers.  

And I love the way they display their beer selection, up on the wall with prices and very well organized.  So well organized, in fact, that you're bound to drink more than a few pints, whether you're inclined or not.

Just by being in Toronado, you're inclined to drink beer.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
Toronado gets more like 2.5 stars, right down the middle of the road. 

On one hand, yes, they do have an outstanding selection of draught beer. But on the other, the bartenders tend to be the biggest pretentious pricks, without provocation. I do love that you can hit up any of the nearby eateries and bring your grub in with you, but what good is bringing in food and drinking some beer if there is nowhere to sit?

I'm sorry if the bartenders think they're better than me while they make minimum wage, yet I continue to come here and support them because what they hell else am I going to drink with my sausage? 

(If you don't mind paying a few more bucks, your time and money could be much better spent at Monk's Kettle.)
author: Miranda R.

description:
Oktoberfest is a particularly stressful time of year to be a bartender.  Let me give you an example:

Poochie M. (in a calm submissive state):  I'll have a liter of Spaten.

Bartender (at the top of his lungs):  WE DON'T HAVE ANY LITERS.

Poochie M. (In a calm submissive state):  I'll have a 1/2 liter then.

Bartender (at the top of his lungs):  WE DON'T HAVE ANY LITERS OR HALF LITERS.

Poochie M (in a calm submissive state):  I'll have a pint of Spaten (a pint is almost the same as a 1/2 liter...).

Bartender (at the top of his lungs):  WHAT KIND OF SPATEN?  WE HAVE 4 KINDS OF SPATEN. MAKE UP YOUR MIND...

Poochie M (at the top of his lungs):  A PINT OF SPATEN LAGER!

When someone asks for Spaten they usually are referring to plain Spaten, i.e., the lager.  If I wanted Spaten Oktoberfest, I would have asked for Spaten Oktoberfest.  Don't ya think?

Take lots of deep breaths.  It will all be over soon!
author: Poochie M.

description: Dirtiest bar I have been to in quite some time.  But look at the beer list!  It's massive.  And you can bring sausages from next door.  This is a king daddy of dive bars.  I don't remember what it is called, but they have a very solid Hefeweizen.  Also, the bathroom is really gross.  And the clientele can be just as filthy looking as the bar.  I did mention you can eat sausages from next door, right?  Right?  RIGHT?
author: Jeremy G.

description:
The ambience is not for everyone.  The juke box is usually too loud.  Seating can be hard to come by.  The back room is dark and musty.  Most of the bartenders are gruff on their good days.

That being said, no one has a better selection of beers on tap in the City than the Toronado, especially during the winter months.  

Look for the bows on the big board to identify their seasonal ales.  I start on the left and work my way through the bow-ed beers.  Usually takes me a couple of visits.  Then I drink the best ones again and again until those little bows disappear.

If you're a serious beerman, go for their annual Barleywine Festival in February.
author: Daniel S.

description: If you want to be treated like a complete ass, then go here. It's too bad because the beer selection is good and prices are fair. We tried to order from a print out of select beers (which was on the bar in several spots) during beer week and were told by the washed up bartender that she "didn't give a shit what's on the print out and order off the damn board like all the rest of the people who know how to order a beer in a bar." WOW, is all I have to say after going here. I would only go back if that bartender insisted she had taken her meds for the day.
author: Brian M.

description:
Walking inside this place from outside in the sun:

Bartender yelling: I NEED TO SEE YOUR ID!!! 
Me: *looking around waiting for eyes to adjust to the darkness*
Bartender yelling again: I NEED TO SEE YOUR ID!!!!
Me: *eyes finally almost adjusted. I see the bartender.*
Bartender yelling yet again: I NEED TO SEE YOUR ID!!!!


Damn lady. Hold your horses! It wasn't even loud in the bar so I have no idea why she was yelling. 

Impressive selection of beer. No food sold but they let you bring food from outside in. Not in any real rush to come back here.
author: Jen D.

description:
A bar should not rely on their beer selection alone...SERVICE MATTERS.  I wasn't sure which beer I wanted.  The female bartender told me to, "read the board and figure it out".  

I can certainly "read the board" somewhere else.  When you work for tips and your the owner's wife you'd think that you would want people coming back to your bar.  The bad taste I had in my mouth when I left was not from the beer.

My advice is take your fantastic Rosamunde sausage  another place.
author: Christine S.

description:
My kinda beer bar.  Not quite Blind Tiger in NYC, but a good west coast substit\ute. 

Food:  I have not idea.  I couldn't tell if they serve food, or if people were just bringing food in.

Decor:  Lots of beer schtuff.  It basically was my idea for a man cave decof makeover.

Service: The bartendress was great.  I was there for a couple of hours and I had 2 free drinks.  She made thoughtful suggestions based on my likes and dislikes, and was all around congenial.

Beer: Obviously with a place like this, this is what it's all about.  Again, I'm an east coaster, so what do I know about what's rare out here.  Had several Rusian River beers which were new to me and quite tasty.  Also had an old German favorite Adventinus on draft which was servered a little warmer than I'm used to, but what I suspect was just right.  It tasted better a little warmer than used to.

I'm always ln the lookout for models for my future bar.  While I still place Blind Tiger at the top of my list, the Toronado is in the running.
author: Mike R.

description:
Dear God, 

Thank you for introducing me to IPA.  

I will never go back to tastless, crappy beer again. 

Thank you also God, for introducing me to Toronado, a bar with a lot of IPAs and a lack of tastless, crappy beer. 

AAAHHHHMENNN.
author: Claire C.

description:
If you don't love beer more than your mother, you'd better be damn good at pretending you do if you plan on stepping foot in Toronado.

For the 45 y/o man with a 35 y/o beer belly, a prominent 'stache and a penchant for 'kraut on his bratwursts, this place is home.  For all others, it's a beer mecca that frankly can't be bothered with hygiene or class, and that's why it kicks ass.
author: Christine M.

description:
To Danny G.,

You poor mislead, self righteous, asshat....your review pretty much sums up why we don't want you there, please don't ever come back.

Toronado IS the best bar in the city because we don't have to deal with your stuck up bitch gfs or with your "we are so good looking attitude". We go there to drink beer and talk to our friends about beer, not about our clothes or our hair or what Britney is doing. Thank God for the best beer in town and bartenders that know the difference between a saison and a lambic and will straighten your ass out for no charge if you don't.  I will be there celebrating my Bday this Sunday the 6th of April. Say hello to the guy in the Strong Beer fest shirt and buy me a beer if you feel the same way.
author: Robert B.

description:
I saw some of the largest, toughest looking women I've ever seen in San Francisco in Toronado.  Automatic four stars.  

You grab a sausage from Rosamunde's next door, grab a beer, and life is that much better.  Great lunch stop.

I like how the bartenders yell at you if you're out of line: for example, if you order Fat Tire.    I want to go to one of their beer tastings, but it's so intense and packed, it's tough.  Haven't seen a fight here, but it seems like a good place to plan one.
author: ed y.

description:
Toronado is to beer what Blondie's or Escape from New York is to pizza.  It's a tiny place that focuses on one thing and does it well.  In this case, that one thing is beer.  That's what you come here to do.  Everything else is secondary, including finding a place to sit.

The dozens of available beers will yield some gems for just about any beer drinker.  For instance, I finally found the elusive Double IPA on tap.  (Word to the wise: drink Double IPA at the beginning of the evening, not when your mouth is already leathered from three previous dark beers).  They also have a delicious-sounding Pomegranate Cider which I will have to come back for.  And if you want to try something that's just plain awesome, grab the Deschutes Brewery's 19th Anniversary Ale.

Oh, and if some glasses-wearing, ponytail-sporting, sudoku-playing hippie dude by the front door asks for your ID, don't be weirded out--that's what bouncers look like in these parts.
author: Wes M.

description:
Toranado is a beer drinker's paradise.  With a large selection of real beer from all over the world - this place delivers to beer lovers.

As you walk in, you are greeted by an interesting combination of beer geeks, hipsters, European tourists and expats, and bikers.

Walk next door and have a sausage to complement your beer - hell, bring it in with you.

Cash only is a bit annoying but it is what it is.   Best spot in the lower haight - no question.
author: Moe J.

description: Went for a beer with folks.  The beer selection is terrific and they even have some hand pulled beers.  Prices are reasonable.  The place is fairly small though and we weren't able to sit, even on a Monday evening.  It was also very loud, not just from music but from voices - it's amazing that so few people can make such a volume of noise!  But the variety and quality of beer definitely make up for any shortcomings!
author: Graham H.

description:
Brew selection is hands down the best in the city meriting 6 stars, if it were possible.  Generally I don't take issue with brusque/dickhead customer service.  Hell, I prefer the realness over some bullshit smiley la dee da but the bartenders here always seem to make it a point to throw mad 'go fuck yourself' attitude my way.  The last time I went it really fucked with my head so 3 stars at the mo', but definitely open for review...

UPDATE:  maybe i have 'chump' written on my forehead in an invisible ink that only the bartenders here can see with their amazing dick-o-vision.  the haggard, acid tongued woman that tends bar was in rare form, hassling myself and thirsty pals for ID even though we were all clearly of age (my hairline don't lie).  i don't give a fuck if you wanna see it, but talk to me like a person.  ZERO need to demean or condescend, especially to a perpetually pleasant and well adjusted motherfucker like myself.  dear toronado:  nice beers but go fuck yourself.  i'd rather drink natty ice w/ high school kids.  PS:  i'm slightly comforted to know it's not just me getting shade thrown at them.  still, that shit was just inexplicable.
author: beltrand a.

description: Walls well decorated with bumper stickers and other things to read.  They have a butt loads of  beer but no Guinness, they did have another stout that tasted similar.  Very grungy, just the way I like it!
author: Ashley C.

description: I came here during the SF beer fest and this place was packed!!!! Woowee! They had  tons of beers to taste (around 40) and they were all pretty delicious! It gets really noisy but it's a fun place to just hang out with friends or what not. It's not super nice inside but to come here for beers makes it worthwhile indeed!
author: Heidi K.

description:
When did the Toronado become a frat-boy bar? I mean not the customers, can't control that, but the staff. Tattoos do not mean anything anymore, dude, except that you're as mainstream as if you were wearing Dockers.  

Now I wouldn't care what you wear, except the attitude here has gotten out of control lately -- being a jerk to customers who want to know what's what on the big beer board? Man that's just plain dumb. (Probably it means you don't have a clue, either, but that's beside the point.) And now you're tossing angry threats at unsuspecting customers? Something's changed in the Toronado vibe--something darker and more violent. 

We come here cuz we like beer, and we like trying new stuff. And we like an unpretentious place to drink. Jerky attitudes, man, I can get that from the phone company.
author: Geddy L.

description:
Major cons: Asshole bartenders (at least one of them), scuzzy digs.

Major pro: Epic selection of beers on tap. Including.. "girly beer" (framboise). 

Generally whenever I force a fine beer on the wife she makes the "beer rape" ugly face*, followed by a tortured sip, followed by a "hmm, not so bad" obvious lie, followed by the return of said beer. But she loved the framboise straight from the get-go -- fruity, sparkly, fragrant and crisp, without being overly sweet. Thanks for the suggestion Miri!

*still somehow inhumanly gorgeous
author: Tom L.

description:
My oh my, what a fantastic selection of beer.

If you want to go to Toronado for anything other than the huge selection of beer-on-tap, save your money and buy some atmosphere someplace else, because if you don't come for the beer, you're really just wasting your time.

Actually, I can think of many reasons you wouldn't want to come here;
The bartenders aren't going to be friendly towards you if you ask for something that's not on the menu, it's loud, it can be a bit crowded, it's certainly not that clean...

However, if you subscribe to the philosophy that variety is spice of life... well, Toronado is that spice.
author: Adam M.

description:
Expectations
1) Crazy mad selection of beer
2) Total prick bartenders/ shitty service

Reality
1) Good ass selection, but not unsimilar to my hometown spot.  I did enjoy the thick feel of history. I do realize that this dive bar is actually a cultural  landmark.   I am glad I for the one night's experience at the famed Toronado Bar.  But....I prefer my kick ass beer spot.  Hamilton's in South Park San Diego. Check it.

2) If you are not ready or aren't paying attention, the bartender is on to the next guy.  I mean you got like a 2 second window.  And I LOVE that.  When I went to order a beer,  never waited longer than 3 minutes. They are not pricks, they are just very busy and concentrated on getting good beer out to the quickly packed bar.

If you are in SF and enjoy beer nirvana, a must.
author: Mike D.

description:
Tons of great beer.

Laid back, chill customers who wouldn't know a "name-brand" if Louis Vuitton slapped them in the face with a Prada handbag (that is soooo a plus).

Super cool bartenders.

Me, drinking beer and slapping people with my Prada handbag.  (Prado, to be exact 'cause mama needs a sugar daddy something fierce).
author: T-Bag S.

description: Good beer selection.  Check out the Red Chair on tap by Deschuttes (from Bend, Oregon) if you dig IPAs.  The service is "meh" and the bartenders are perpetually trapped in Scowl-Face mode.
author: EJ S.

description:
This is hands down the best bar in the city for many reasons. First, you aren't going to find a better selection of beer in the city or anywhere near it. Second, the prices can't be beat (esp. during happy hour). Third, the bartenders don't take crap from yuppies. Fourth, you are surrounded by great food. Fifth, the Barley Wine festival is something to look forward to every single year. 
And people need to quit complaining about the bartenders. All you got to do is go up, order something on the board, get your beer, pay, sit down and enjoy. The bartenders aren't there to entertain you they are there to serve you a beer. This aint the Marina people
