author: Robert H.

description:
WORST BARTENDER EVER!!!

yes the toronado has an excellent beer selection; yes they allow you to bring in outside food; yes they are generally awesome and YES, THE "OWNER'S WIFE" IS A CRACK SMOKING PSYCHOPATH!!!

i've been habituating the toronado for a long while and have had to suffer many an unjust minutes waiting in line for sweet sweet beer, i've even had to deal with "her majesties" craziness and obvious bitchiness towards her fellow females...
but tonight tops them all.

for no reason at all the owner/bartender/psychopath flipped out on me, cussing me out, telling me she was going to kick me out, yelling at me all the while pouring my beers and paying no mind to my astonished and bewildered face.  everyone around me agreed that it was her psychosis and nothing i did to provoke such an outrage...(even the barback apologized to me and said he knew it wasn't my fault.)

i've never experienced anything like this before, she was insanely mean and making nonsensical comments about me giving her shit and finally learning my lesson for it.  this lady is fucking psycho. 

BEWARE!!!!!!!!!!!  

*also my friend who had been drinking with us the whole evening was denied service for not showing her id, even though she showed her valid cal id, and was made to feel like shit simply for trying to buy a beer.

bullshit.
we're not assholes, we're not pretentious fucks, we're just fucking sfc locals trying to have a beer and hang the fuck out.

i'm over that place.

post script
she kept leaving her post (as the only bartender), to go to the restroom for long periods of time returning with a white baggy in hand.  (i'm not saying she's a crack smoker...oh wait...i am.)
author: Lady L.

description:
This place is in my neighborhood so i get dragged here sometimes, but it sucks. If I could get get back all the time that I've spent waiting at the bar to get a beer at the Toronado, I'd have enough to knit a few sweaters (that includes learning how to knit)

This place needs to get over itself, it's not that cool.

The only reason that it doesn't get one star from me is that one time I got in a car accident on my way to meet a friend there, and she spent an hour sitting by herself getting hit on by a weird guy and it was kind of funny how relieved she was when I eventually arrived.
author: Josh K.

description:
This place doesn't do much for me.  

Sure they have a great beer selection, but it's so freaking loud and crammed with a motley crew of sports nuts, pot bellied jocks past their prime and never enough seating, that I feel like I'm being crammed into a sweaty, aging locker room.

On top of that, the service is curt, to put it mildly.  So how much is one of their beers really worth to you?
author: Laura K.

description:
This bar has a lot of beer.  Lots of it.  So much that you've probably never heard of most of it.  And if you have heard of something, you feel guilty about ordering it because "there are oh so many that I haven't tried."  Usually there is a reason that you haven't tried it.  I've had a fair number of beers here and none have been that great.  

Also, I came in one Saturday afternoon during the NFL Playoffs with my sausage from next door.  I saddled up to the nearly empty bar, ordered a beer to go with my sausage and politely asked the bartender if he would put the game on the TV for me, instead of the close captioned sci-fi channel monster flick, currently occupying the screen.  Well, the bartender looks me in the eye and says, "We aren't a sports bar."  He did in fact, change the channel for me, but not without a degree of hostility that I didn't appreciate.  Yes, you aren't a sports bar, but you are, in fact, a bar.  

Oh and don't bother coming here if you want liquor, as they have none.

The only reason they don't get one star is that you are able to take your mouthwateringly delicious any-animal-of-your-choosing sausage from next door at Rosamundes and wash it down with a beer.
author: matt c.

description: Beer Valhalla.  That's about it.  If you have an appreciation for good full body beer, do yourself a favor and belly up for some of the best day drinking you will ever experience in your life.  If you are a bud light person, don't even bother to make the trip.  Also, the best conditions for appreciation are during the day.  By night, the happy hour expires and all the lower haight hipsters clog the line.  And don't order a mixed drink here or anything other than the beer of choice with no special instructions.  You just might be asked to leave.  Especially if you're wearing a blazer.  Simply a 'please' and a 'thank you' will endear you to a friendly, but firm staff.  Just don't be a douche. Or princess will kick you out.
author: Dan J.

description:
I love beer.  I love beer and a good sausage (which you can get next door and eat here).  What I don't love is attitude from the beertending troll behind the bar.  Uhh, it's just beer dude get off my out of town buddy's back for asking for a Budweiser.  He's from St. Louis for crying out loud.

Despite that, I'll be back, but truthfully it is because of the sausages.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Usually frequent the Upper Haight (i.e. Kezar Pub) but this place is cool.

If you like exotic unique beers, then this certainly a place to consider.

Surprisingly, finding parking wasn't too bad.
author: Francis M.

description:
No way jose. Brunette bartender is scary and mean and selectively insults people at the bar for no reason at all, then refuses to serve them. 

I really WANT to like this place, but just can't with that kind of treatment.
author: N S.

description: a simple place for great beers.  pliny the elder, aventinus eisbock, roog rauchweizen all great in their own way.  serbice is solid too.  a san francisco gem.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Great beer, great beer selection, fun area. Bartender was a bit a prick. Btw stay away from the sour cherry german beer.(ECHT KRIEKENBIER
from Brouwerij Verhaeghe) Smells like vinegar. Tastes like ass. Could not keep a sip of it down. Tried to swap it out for a diff beer, but the bartender just commented "What? You dont like sour beer?" So instead he got another 4.00 of my $$.
author: J V.

description:
If you love loud 70s Rock, ugly men with long hair, and "blonde's" with beautiful big bangs, you've found your spot. If you don't like any of this (like I do), they have a plethora amount of beers on tap. You can even bring food into the bar. But man, oh man... Even beer goggles can't fix the atrocity. There was even a pirate sipping on a pint. Arrrrrr.

Note: The website beer menu is not up to date.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
This is a premier destination for connoisseurs of quality beer. There are 40-50 different beers of all types and origins are available at reasonable prices. (Another yelper told me that Toronados reputation as a beer mecca means that breweries are eager to have their beer sold here, giving the bar a lot of leverage when purchasing.)

I suppose this is also a premier destination for connoisseurs of stickers and grime, though the bathrooms are uncharacteristically clean.
author: matthew r.

description: Fun joint for a laid-back night.  They have a very impressive selection of beers.  They have many varieties of Chimay and other Belgian beers, many different IPAs, and other beers.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Sausage from next door & quality beer. The Supremes that played after some punk rock was a nice touch as well. 

I can't think of a better place to bond with a dancer who ALSO likes to drink. It doesn't happen that often, let me tell ya. Or maybe it's just the dancers I know.
author: Alexis B.

description:
The beer.  Mmmm.. Beer...

Good times at this bar usually turn into blurry memories where all you can remember are snippets: stumbling through Lower Haight looking for cigarettes.  Almost buying street art off some artist two doors down.  Keeping pace with the rounds.  Bringing Mexican food in from next door and eating like there's no Tomorrow.  Drunkenly ignoring the sad state of the bathroom because, goddamit, when you have to pee, you have to pee! oh my god, how many beers have I had already? How many hours have I been here?  Nooooo~..... 

Minus one star for the loud, mind numbing music that turns your fun time out with friends into a screaming match so you can be heard.
author: Dianne d.

description:
On the plus side this pub has a great selection of beers, probably the most extensive I've seen in the city. It even has a small number of draft (ie non-fizzy) beers that are pretty good.

On the downside this means it attracts a lot of beer snobs and sundry hipster types. The bar staff also have a bit of an attitude over poor beer selection.

Worth checking out if you're serious about your taste in beer, but not a great place to hang out.
author: Iain T.

description:
I think this place is somehow related to Rosamude sausage place next door.  Perhaps people pick up a hot dog and come here for the accompanying beer?  Considering that hot dogs are among my favorite food, I should probably love this place.

I must say, the beer selection here is top notch.  There is even a beer here called Pomme, which I assume has an apple flavor.  I should probably give an extra star for this.  There is a bar in Berkeley that gives you a stamp for every beef that you have tried.  I would be here every day for a year before trying every beer!  I hope they give out a coaster for every beer you try.

Great concept.  I will be back here to try more beer, especially that Apple one.
author: apple r.

description: Awesome! .. Friendly and a great selection of beers.. love the monday session down there!
author: Valentino B.

description:
Great selection of beer for cheap! Ask for the extended menu of special beers - the variety is amazing. Warning: better know your beer before ordering. If it's crowded, you'll get no advice from the staff.

Place gets crowded early, but thins out early as well. You can be elbow to elbow on any given weeknight but still manage to get served in a relatively timely manner. Music can be loud and is mostly rock but it usually doesn't interfere with conversation.

The tenders are not there to make friends, but to do their job. So if you are looking for warm and fuzzy service, this is not the place. That is not to say they're rude, just busy! Good tipping is greatly appreciated and may be rewarded.

So, pick up a sausage or slice of pizza, bring it in with your dog and enjoy the locals. Don't be shy about sharing a table with people you don't know. You might just make some new friends!
author: Gina G.

description:
This is the way a bar should be. Cut the out the fancy dj's, the trendy decor, and get right down to beerness. 

Totally laid back with great high tables and chairs in the front and plenty of bench seating in the back, Toronado is a perfect place to chill with a few friends any day of the week. Weekends are definitely more crowded, but the place never feels claustrophobic.  

Awesome selection of beers. My new discovery: Schneider-Weisse. It's on tap. Cheap. Go for it.
author: simone H.

description:
Wow, people seem to expect A LOT from this bar. You go to a bar like Toronado for good beer, you don't go to make friends. Why do you feel that the staff ought to be especially friendly? Do you even know what it's like to serve pint after pint to jerkoff after jerkoff? Drunk people can be very unpleasant, make for unpleasant people that aide in the drunk. Deal with it. I know Paul, he's just misunderstood, he's really nice and Johnny is the rad, of course.
Come here, try new beer, have an idea because they don't feel like giving you Hops & Barley 101. Your best bet is to figure out a beer or five for yourself, get a sausage from Rosamunde and enjoy. If Rosamunde is busy they will often just take your order and bang on the wall when it's ready. That's service!
author: Colleen B.

description: FOOD!!  You already know:  good dive bar and great beer selection. Now, what to do about food. Fantastic sausage sandwiches next door to the right and wonderful pizza next door to the left. NOW, you have everything u need!
author: Vincent N.

description:
How could I not award five stars to a bar that's got a Michael Jackson Commemorative brew??! 

Five stars. No brainer.
author: Victoria D.

description: I had visited Toronado many years ago when I lived in the bay before and the beer selection is still pretty amazeballs. The space is super hole in the wall with a dive bar aesthetic, my favorite! The shitty '90's music (ie Pearl Jam) wasn't great, but the sweet sweet beer drowned out the suck.
author: Lauren Gayle S.

description:
Ok, excellent beer choice does not make up for condescending bartenders. (I can't believe all the 5 star reviews) It's improved recently, but they still have a few bartenders I'd like to reach over the bar and throttle. Having said that, this bar has consistently been the best bar for beer choice in the city, especially Belgian, so, I avoid the urge to pummel and return every so often to enjoy the excellent beer choice. (been doing that since the 80's) BTW, in case ur wondering, I've been to Belgium several times in search of beer, so, I'm not ignorant, but, in Belgium, they encourage questions and interest in their "faire". I wish I could say the same about this place. Attitude, attitude. Get over yourself. You're a bartender, you schmuck. At least have the pride to not be a snotty a**-hole when I ask questions about the bar's (not YOURS), excellent biere menu.

Update: over the past year I've been back half a dozen times and haven't run into any rude bartenders. The good beer choice has never been an issue. Its a great beer bar. I hope things continue this way. So, in the name of honesty...Bumping it up to 4 stars.
author: Rich M.

description:
Best line ever here (bartender not named to protect the innocent):

"Dude, could I get a Bud Light?"
"We don't have that...but if you'd like to order a REAL beer, we have one of those."

The Toronado is this:  a sticky, grungy, somtimes dirty, always edgy, never compromising, beer shrine.  Fifteen years in SF taught me this:  when you step into this sometimes intimidating mecca, remember how lucky you are to be living in the city you do.  There are maybe 10 bars in the US that can even approximate this place.

Response to two previous reviewers:

An IPA heavy rotation?  Last time I was in there, I counted 12.....of 50 odd taps.  I guess the 38 non-IPAs was not a high enough percentage?

And the Seattle "beer pretentious" dude?  I live in Seattle now.  There is only one place that can even hold a candle to the Toronado: Brouwers (but...too sanitary and....no Rosamunde).  I guess all the bars up here with Pyramid Hefe, Mac and Jack's, Manny's, and Alaskan Amber are "beer shrines?"  Microbrewing started in San Fran in the 60s (Fritz Maytag when he bought a near-bankrupt Anchor).  I guess when NWesterners are inside as much as they are with all the rain,  they start getting delusions of grandeur.  VITAMIN D...I NEED VITAMIN D!

Visit the Toronado, take the atmosphere for what it is, and really indulge in some beers outside your comfort zone...you will not be disappointed.

P.S. My review was recently edited due to my revisitation of my four favorite Seattle beer establishments.  Honorable mentions go to Collins Pub, Beveridge Place, and Coopers, though none of those approach 30 taps.
author: Eric M.

description: This place holds a close spot to my liver. I have been coming to this place for a long time. They always have a great selection of brews and are always adding some new beer to their repertorie. The bartenders are so tender with the pouring of the beer. Great place to chill out....
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
I've got mixed feelings about Toronado. On the one hand, it's a great place for hanging out with my friends and I've spent several nights kicking back and having great conversation (by the way, the smaller room in the back is better for conversation because you're shielded from the crappy and uneven sound system). I like that you can bring in food from nearby and that they are (usually) dog friendly. I also enjoy a bit of attitude in my bartenders.

But... it's all beer and I'm just not a beer drinker. Nope, I'm a good old-fashioned queer boy who believes that alcohol should come in mixed drinks with trendy or funny names. And while their selection of beer with trendy or funny names is admirable, I inevitably gravitate to the cider option because it's the only thing that isn't beer.

True story, on one visit I was lucky enough to be the first patron to order after the bartender had just bitched out some other guy who wanted a mixed drink of some kind. Seeking to balance the wheel of karma, or just because we were polite, the bartender decided to buy us our drinks.

On another occasion, I arrived just after there had been a fistfight involving another beligerent customer and a bartender. The bartender in question showed back up at the bar about an hour later with a nasty cut on his mouth that had been treated at the ER.

So at least it's rarely boring.
author: Jere K.

description:
It's 12 noon on a Tuesday. What are you doing right now?  

I'll tell you what to do today:  head over to the hole-in-the-wall sausage place next to Toronado and order their Tuesday special $5 cheeseburger.  Okat, now walk (or jog) next door to Toronado.  It will be their happy hour, a home to over 40 delicious draft beers for $3.  Reality Czech? Hunter's Point Porter? Racer 5 IPA? Blind Pig IPA? Drake's IPA? Jonbonet's dead body? Are they serious? I believe they are.  Enjoy the best beers of your life with the best burger of your life.  Thank you.
author: Scott G.

description:
To the beer lover, Toronado rivals the Hanging Gardens of Babylon and the Colossus of Rhodes in its historicity and cultural relevance.  It is, after all, one of the original purveyors of the ultimate celebration of the hop, Pliny the Elder.  But I digress...this review is about Toronado!

Pros:
1.) Beer!  Toronado served Russian River, Drakes, Bear Republic, Sierra Nevada etc. long before these Bay Area breweries improved their distribution.  Toronado is a testament to the vitality of craft brewing in the Bay Area.
2.) The barleywine festival rocks your socks off.  Just get there super early.
3.) The bartenders are very friendly, as long as you know your elbow from your asshole and you don't act like a dipshit.  This is not a lounge, it's a bar.  Be respectful to the bartenders, tip, and you get your beer.
4.) No food.  This is actually a good thing.  I don't want to belabor the point, but Toronado is a bar; if you are looking for a brewpub, go to the breweries themselves.

Cons:
1.) Toronado attracts hipsters.  If you love beer as much as I do, you have to bite the bullet and just ignore the Che Guevara t-shirts and nut-hugger jeans.  Years ago, this type of clientele would be persone non grate at Toronado.  To quote the immortal Bob Dylan, "The times, they are a-changin'".
2.) Seating can be fairly awful, because of the reason above.
3.) The glassware needs some updating.  I'm not really a hardass on this issue, as long as the glassware is clean (which it is), but the snifters are pretty beat up and need replacing.

If you love beer, have an ounce of patience, and can put up with the hipsters, Toronado is a must.
author: Daniel F.

description:
If someone is making a list of best place to find microbrews on the West coast, they ALWAYS include Toronado.  You know, the in flight magazine, the men's magazine, that kind of thing.  When you walk in the door, you'll know why. The list of beers available there is pretty impressive.  

The place is homey, well homey if you live in a dump with a couple of alcoholics who like to display beer bottles on the wall.  OK, that's not very nice, but decorum plays 3rd fiddle at Toronado.  There recently was a Yelp thread about dumpy bathrooms in public places in SF, and I just about nominated at least two of the bathrooms here.  People just seem to like to drink beers and write stuff on the walls in the can at Toronado.  I wonder, do people say to themselves while they are getting ready: "Cool pants and shirt, check.  Cool shoes, check.  Wallet, cell phone and keys, check.  Permanent marker, check.  OK, let's go."

Your best bet is to take the bus or a cab here, as the lower haight is always a difficult place to park at night, and hopefully you'll get to round two or three while you're at the bar.
author: Nelson W.

description: I think I might just get my mail forwarded here since I'm here more than I'm at home most of the time.
author: Joshua W.

description:
There are plenty of places with beer like Toronado.  But no other place with as much discussion about the bartenders.  So we went to drink beer with our cell phone videos primed for shooting something that would go viral on youtube.  

The dream scenario, a fat red faced tourist from Alabama versus a gay leather clad bartender from the Haight.  Red State vs Blue State,  It never quite happened, but we got close.  Over my left shoulder comes in a one percenter in a suit from France (not like the French have an attitude or anything.)  He orders 4 glasses of beer, 18 bucks and leaves no tip.  Unfortunately the bartender kept his cool and blew it off.  "I took one look at him, knew he would not tip, and moved on."

Dang, no drama at all.  

The first guy behind the bard might have been more likely to provide fuel for a review.  Just as the shift was changing at 4pm a glass dropped between them and the first guy, going off shift, muttered some stuff about how lame it was to be serving beer in wine glass and no wonder they broke when you dropped them.  

Our guy had the bar alone with 50 people in the place.  He was faster than any bartender I've even seen.  At one point he took 4 ones, a guy's change, and flicked them about 5 feet.  The 4 ones hit the glass and dropped perfectly.  

While we were there it was happy hour.  Every thing is a dollar off.  Most beers are 5 dollars, so during happy hour you order a beer, give the guy a 5 which includes a deserved dollar tip, and they don't push the button on the trap door below your barstool.

I imagine you could go into this place and get abused, but in my experience you will have deserved it.  

Did I mention they have about 40 different beers so if you can find a few beers here you like it is your problem.  And, if you ask in a normal way for a small taste of something it's no problem.

It's a BART and MUNI ride from where I live so I won't be frequenting this place, but I would definitely go back.
author: Rudyard K.

description:
The atmosphere is super funky and SF-like.  They have HUNDREDS of beers to choose from.  I ended up having two of the pomegranite beers. I wish I could remember the name, but I'm sure they'll know what you're talking about if you say pomegranite beer.  

We came for Happy Hour on Friday and it was absolutely packed.  The bartenders are great though, and as soon as they saw us, they walked over and took our order.  It was SUPER loud inside which made it pretty difficult to hear my friend.  We finally found some seats in the back, but then a huge party came in and took over with the noise level again.  Oh well. Pretty cool spot in the Lower Haight. It's pretty chill and right next door to Noc Noc.
author: Jenny W.

description: Bartenders are a bunch of arrogant sons of bitches... Need I say. Don't waste your your time or money.
author: Tobie C.

description:
Beer beer and more beer!

Don't ask to order a mixed drink here, especially something fruity and pink or you might be ordered to Get The efF Out.  

Do ask the bartenders what they recommend and try something new.  

Recommended:
-Abby  - Belgian Ale
-Bitburger - light easy smooth great glass
-Any wheat beer - big glass
-Famhouse Ale - ala Blue Moon Blond ale
-Whiteknuckles - She's stacked (have no idea what this means but that is what the drinker felt.) 
-Racer 5 - amber light
-Edelweiss - (a beer haiku) "Amazing and Fresh, Babbling brook in my head, I need to get laid" (this was not me, the writer of this review who had this beer!)
-Death & Taxes - meal in a glass, order this beer and gain massive respect at the bar.
- Spaten Mieback - don't remember
-mini chimay - fun
-Boonts Amber - need food!

Thank goodness you can get sausage sandwiches next door.
Toronado rocks in more ways than one.  No frills, loud music, good beer.

Cheers!
author: James M.

description:
Four things NOT to ask the bartenders here:

1. Do you still have the gnome beer (that would be La Chouffe -- sorry Mr. Bartender for not remembering the name of the 8th beer I had last time I visited -- I was a little too drunk to recall)

2. Do you have PBR/Bud/Coors, etc. (I thought the bartender was going to slap my friend for asking)

3. Can you make me a strawberry margarita (said by some bimbo girl to tough looking lady bartender, who also looked like she was going to slap the girl).

4. What beer is good (answer -- everything).

If you can safely avoid these questions, you should have a fine, enjoyable experience. This is actually one of those bars that like much better during the day... something about eating a vegan sausage and drinking two or three or more cold beers while the sun is shining and I'm busy wasting away in a bar is appealing to me. Good god, I sound like an alcoholic.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
When I was a kid my family spent some time living in Belgium, so whenever my dad comes to San Francisco this is where he wants to go. That is the reason for 5 stars in and of itself. I can get drunk with my dad here and he loves it. Anything that makes him happy makes me happy.

Great beer selection, even my mom (who doesn't drink beer) had a drink (Kriek).
author: Laura D.

description:
Framboise means raspberry in French.  It also means deliciously-tasty-Belgian-beer-that-is-conducive-to-me-drinking-gallons-of-it in Jillish.  Jillish is similar to drunklish except that it is an even more convoluted dialect associated primarily with a drunk and blowless Jill.  
Thank you Toronado for enabling me to exhibit my fluency in another language.  Even if it is one that very few people speak it still counts as being bilingual!
author: Jill D.

description: Greatest beer hall I've ever seen. I've read the low reviews. If you want the best beer, you go here. I dunno what you are doing here if that isn't your purpose, but myself and the owners of the bar don't want you if you aren't here for that purpose.
author: David B.

description:
It may not look as divey as a lot of other dives, but Toronado is the only place in the world where a dude like me would be called "prettyboy". It really happened. Just last night, actually. And my head is still spinning under the spell of this gravity. Granted, it was uttered as a backhanded compliment -- or maybe an openhanded insult -- by a douchey gentleman who had been attempting to school a cute friend of mine on bitters. Not being the kind of guy who lets douchebags have their way with his friends, I decided to cameo in the role of Game Killah. In his defense, I deserved a dash of ire. And I WAS wearing my swanky new $7 blazer over a nice flannel, so yeah, I can see how it could work. Anyway, last night made me realize something: Life is amazing & hilarious, & the smallest thing (like gamekilling on a douchebag & getting called prettyboy) can make my week.

Toronado is an Everyman kinda dive bar. No pretention, no fancypantsing. It's a place where a bunch of grouchy people can sit around, drink beer & talk shit with each other (or the bartender) about fixie hipster jerks, sports, the price of a decent haircut being oftentimes ludicrous, or anything really. As long as you're complaining a little bit & enjoying yourself doing it.
author: Pete J.

description:
Toronado carries an eclectic selection of libations that are well tuned to introduce both the casual and the seasoned beer/ale fan to many non-mass produced beverages.

It's tactical placement immediately next to Rosamunde also is most fortuitous, for what better companion to a world class ale than a equally delectable sausage?

While crowded, it is an inimical part of what it is to be a late night beer/snack joint.  While I'm far more partial to low-key, spacious venues, the combination of these two little venues right next to each other is enough to draw me consistently.
author: Ferdinand H.

description: You can't fail to find a great beer here. And with Rosamunde right next door (be sure to grab a sausage and bring it over), this is one of San Francisco's best.
author: Eddie H.

description: Awesome diver bar with a killer, affordable beer selection. What sets this bar apart is its amazing patrons. We sat down with a local and were serenaded with tales of San Francisco's heydays. Do not miss this place on your trip!
author: Josh T.

description:
Best beer selection in the city blah blah blah...

Yes that is true, but selection does not makeup for consistently rude waitstaff and cavernous darkness (and drafts... the wind type, not the beer type). Oh and good luck finding a place to sit.

In my opinion, Toronado is worth it only if you crave some super hard to get beer, or if you want a drink to go with your sausage from Rosamunde Sausage Grill next store. The fact that they encourage you to bring in your sausage is kind of cool I will admit...
author: Trey F.

description:
Came here with an ex colleague. The selection of beer is FABULOUS. Probably the best in San Francisco. The crowd is chilled out. The bartender is friendly

Minus one star for a lot of reasons: 
No food here. 
Theres nothing else to drink but beer.. so if you are going with someone who is not a beer fan, this is not the place to go.
Also the parking is horrible in this neighborhood... 

You can get your own food from the neighboring Pizza place. I'd come here again for the selection of beer!
author: Brijesh K.

description:
There isn't much to be said about Toronado that hasn't been a million times already.  Yes, the beer selection is outstanding.  The bartenders can come off as surly, but they've always treated me respectfully, and that's all I care about.  In fact, I'd rather they WERE belligerent to YOU, so I won't have to wait in line as long when I visit (that's a joke, kind of).  

Oh yes, there is some decent heavy metal on the jukebox too.  It warmed my heart the first time I heard Ronnie James Dio's voice float out of it, singing "Catch the Rainbow," from Rainbow's first album.  

I don't think of Toronado as a "dive bar," though.  It sticks in my craw a little bit, reading other reviews calling it that.  I think people call this place a dive bar because they think it gives it a dangerous glamour, which somehow translates into personal bravery.  So if you think you are "slumming" by coming here, kiss my ass.  

Aside from beer-loving regular people, Toronado is often filled with the young and well-scrubbed who seek the same.  You won't find a gaggle of Sarah Jessica Parker wannabes in a place overrun with the toothless, yellow-bearded, glossolalia-babbling  weirdos you often find in real dive bars.  But it might be fun to witness that....
author: Chris K.

description:
5 stars for the amazing beer selection, -1 star for the lack of anything else.

If you just want to enjoy a good beer, this seems like the spot to me. There aren't any gimmicks, activities, or anything else to speak of -- just a bunch of beers on tap and a few places to sit (most of which are usually occupied). I really like it because it's super laid-back. On weekends it can get busy, though, so be prepared to get aggressive when you want to order drinks.
author: Derek S.

description:
I've been going to Toronado for years now, probably 3 or 4 times a month.  I've learned to deal with the not so friendly staff (the english bloke who works some days is about the only one who makes any effort to make you feel welcome), and even have respect for most of them, being a bartender myself.  After the BS attitude and verbal abuse I received from one older female bartender the other day tho, I'm beginning to question whether it's worth my time to come here anymore.

The crazy woman (owner's wife, apparently?) poured my first beer, and all was fine.  When I returned to the bar for a second round, she proceeded to ignore me for ten minutes, while helping even new customers who had just walked in before asking me if I wanted something.  She looked me straight in the eye several times, and didn't say a word, but returned to stocking glasses from the dishwasher instead.  Finally, when she was right in front of me, getting a beer for someone who had clearly come in after myself, I said something.  I just said "Hey hun, when you have a chance can I grab an el toro deuce?"  She proceeds to lay into me, saying "you know how bartending works?  I ask you what you want to drink, and you tell me, and I get it.  I haven't asked you yet, so wait your turn!"

She also mentioned how she had been bartending since 1979 in NYC, blah blah blah.  I let her know that I was born in 1979, and was a bartender myself, and that had she completely ignored me.  Long story short, I got my beer, and I tipped her 2 bucks for the outstanding service.  

The beer list is piss poor right now as well, half the spots on the board are empty.  Toronado, you need to get your shit together.  I always thought the fact that I love beer and know a fair amount about it would preclude me from saying this, but for the first time I was TRULY offended by the staff here.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
I don't know how you edit fucks put this in the category of DIVE bars because this is beer heaven...hands down.
I lived in the lower H8 for seven glorious drunk years and many a day and night were spent at the T bar. Not only was this a great place to study while I was in college,  it was also the perfect office for my career as a weed salesman. Alias the 90's are over but they were rocking good times before all you dot com yuppie scum fucks came and ruined a perfectly good city. Thank Buddha that the Toronado still survived.

R.I.P Armadillo   R.I.P Midtown  R.I.P..  Spaghetti Western

The beer is great, the bartenders rule, and it is motorcycle friendly.
If your some silly pansy boy or Nancy girl, you will not like this bar.Go  to the marina and catch some disease, Stay away from the best damn beer bar in the west coast, if not the world
author: Mr.Lucky K.

description: A craft beer icon...but it's dirty and the service sometimes sucks.
author: Andy A.

description:
I think this might be my favorite bar in the city.

First off, I'm mostly a beer drinker, and I'm tired of going to all the hipster dives where everyone just settles on Pabst or Tecate, not that there's anything wrong with those beers (if you like piss water). I am a big fan of all the Russian River brews on tap. It takes a while to get them to remember you there, but once they do, they are super friendly. It might look intimidatingly busy there at times, but wait a few minutes and it will clear out and you'll have a table for sure. 

Also gets points for location. Once I've had a few, I want somthing to nosh on and there's something for everyone on the same block! Awesome. If you haven't been to Toronado, do yourself a favor and go right now. Go on, I'll wait...
author: Oscar M.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I am a beer connoisseur. It is all I drink. Needless to say I find the Toronado's wide, HUGE, variety of beer extremely enticing. Did I mention they rotate beers and let you taste them before buying? They always have one to two good Porters or Stouts on tap, which is rare, and the high alcohol content of many of their delicious beers is enough to knock you on your ass. 

Other perks include the half door that greets you at the front, the hours of entertainment provided by reading the bumper stickers on the wall, the eclectic and often good looking crowd, and the bartenders who remember your names and drinks of choice, even if they can get a bit rude from time to time. 

Tip: If you haven't already the Barley Wine Festival hosted by the Toronado is a MUST.
author: Alicia J.

description:
Hipster to weirdo ratio = 1:1
Man to woman ratio = 5:1
Beer to human ratio = 25:1

Very strange assortment of characters. I sat with my friends next to a group of people must have been playing King's Cup or something, they were so loud. One of the girls kept telling one of her friends, "You HAVE to try the Francis Conner. Try the Francis Conner !". Could she have meant Fransizkaner ? And, all those beers and you just want a Hefeweisen ? Okay... so not everyone's cut out for the amazing IPA assortment or the Belgians or a nice chunky stout. But good choice on the Franny.

Guy in the corner had two stoutish looking things. He was wearing a waist purse, I think, and just sat there for an hour drinking alone. A few hipster circulated around us. The one-time hipsters now in their late thirties populated the main room near the bar, which is lined with Duvel magnums. They talked loudly about whatever it is they talk about (having real jobs ? How that last Cure tour was so bad in comparison to when they saw them in '87?). Hmm...

The bartenders are best described as, well, surly (to borrow a friend's word). But they're good to you. So instead of surly, I'm going to say acidic. Like a Costa Rican coffee: hard to appreciate at first, but it grows on you until you love it. There was an awesome barback with a hangover (at 4pm ?) who admitted to drinking earlier in the day (me too, buddy !). 

Oh, and I guess they have beer here or something ? Yeah... I love that they have Lindeman's lambics on tap. I overheard someone saying that a chocolate stout and a framboise lambic mix (kind of a fruity black & tan) was a good drink, but I wouldn't dare try that at Toronado.  I love how they get the random New Belgium special kegs.  I love that they do special nights to taste a particular style or brewery's offerings. Stuff like that is really cool, and now you can tell I'm a beer nerd. 

This is a place for people and by people who love beer, operating under the guise of a dive bar. But it's the beer that counts. Why else would one sit by themselves, inside a stuffy, crowded bar, on a lovely Saturday afternoon ? Why else would I consider buying a Costco pallet of disinfectant, cleaning the bathroom, and moving in ? 

Sign me up for that liver transplant...
author: Shannon C.

description: I'll start this review by saying if I could give this s*&# hole of a place negative stars, I would. The incredibly surly/bitter "bartender" chic couldn't be bothered to wait on me or my friends since she was far too busy text messaging while we waited for her to take our order at the bar. This place is AWFUL! AVOID AT ALL COST!
author: Paul M.

description:
I've only been here once, because I live on the opposite coast. But, so what? I had a good time here. Then again, I had a good time everywhere I went in SF.

Whatever. If you're a tourist or visiting friends, like I was, Toronado is a good time. It's dark and funky and they have some decent beers, but it's not anything special. Although, honestly, I've been to better beer bars than this, so don't go just because someone was like, "yo, this is the best beer bar EVAR!!1!one!!"

If you live here, I can see how it would be annoying when a place that used to be cool turns into frat fucker central, so perhaps if I moved here I would start to get pissed off at this place. But, yeah, that won't be happening, so I'd come here again when I visit my friends.
author: Jonathan G.

description: This is a busy beer house, with lots-o-choices at reasonable prices. I think I would prefer to go on an off night, as opposed to a Friday where there are LOTS of guys and it's super loud, and the bar tender is super alpha male/scary.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Beer and loathing in San Francisco...

I have a love hate relationship with this place. Torn between my quest for amazing beers and the not so amazing atmosphere, service and lack of seating I loathe, I always return. Yes, the beer always wins.

Probably the best place for geeky beers on the west coast outside of O'Brien's in San Diego.  Their tap and bottle selection is vast and extensive.  Bottled beer is available to go.  They don't server food but I can't think of any other way to eat than next door at Rosamunde's sausages (but that's another review entirely).  Talk about a symbiotic relationship, beer and sausages. mmmmmmm.

Some highlights from the beer list include: La Folie (one of the only places in California where this is on tap when available), "The Duchess" (on draft yay!), Any IPA such as the world famous Pliny The Elder and other IPAs (especially on hand pump) such as Green Flash Green Bud, or Moonlight's "Bombay by boat".  Their bottle list contains my favorite labels such as Cantillon, Russian River, Fantome, Lost Abbey, and a few others.

Toronado etiquette aka tips for success:

1) be prepared to stand
2) be prepared to wait at least 10 minutes for service (order two beers to make it worth your while)
3) know what you want to order when they get to you.  any sign of waffling and you're last in line again
4) do not ask for wine
5) do not, and i repeat do not ask for Bud, Coors, Corona or any other macro beer -- you will be asked to leave

Bonus tip for the adventurous: 

Here's a San Francisco original for you to try. Ask for the "Damn Foggy" - Half San Francisco's original Anchor Brewing's Old Foghorn blended with Half Russian River's Damnation.  You're hearing it here first directly from the creator. If it's not "damn foggy" up in sf at least you can have it in your glass!
author: Matthew S.

description:
What's not to like?  If you enjoy beer, this may be your heaven on Haight. Not convinced?  How about Happy Hour everyday from 11:30am-6pm - $2.50 for most beers?  Three clean bathrooms too - yeah, they know what pints of beer do to folks and they are well prepared!

A great pub with a great selection of draft beer and some in bottles (to go!).  We really enjoyed checking out all the beer handles that are part of the decor.  Plenty seatings - take your pick at the bar, the pub tables across the bar or the lounge like area in the back.  A good mix of patrons from young to old and light to dark.  

We got here about 12:30pm after getting our grubs (a dog from next door and some BBQ from across the street).  The bar was mostly taken but we needed a table to spread out our food so we took a table across.  $7 for 2 pints - that's crazy but we are not complaining!  There's no better combination - cold tasty beer and good beer food.  

There are plenty followers of this joint - we saw at least 4 patrons in the pub's tees and hoodies.
author: Gloria H.

description: wild beer selection, with a lot of harder to find stuff or maybe thats me having been out east for too long.
author: Misha T.

description:
The toronado is an SF institution...the first on my list of must see beer bars in the city...really, in the country.  

The selection here is sublime.  With forty-something taps, there's nothing lacking in terms of selection.  From mysteriously unpronounceable belgians to the freshest Norcal brews - all bases are covered.  It's the only place in the city where Russian River brews can be found with consistency (though Monk's Kettle is working towards it).  

 They've got cask conditioned 'real ale' on tap (one of two locations in SF - the other being Black Horse), and prices hovering between $3.75 (the majority) and $7.50 (for the more rare/foreign treats).  For the most part, beers are served in their proper glassware, and the more boozey beers are served in smaller servings to keep your slur to the later slice of the evening.

The Barleywine Fest (in Feb) is the best way to find warmth in the fog, and the Wet Hop Fest (during the fall harvest) showcases "wet hopped" beers redolent and rearing with volcanic hopttitude which have been brewed with hops no more than 24 hours off the vine.  The 'nado is also quick to showcase a particular brewery's best on a random weeknight with little or no advance notice.  Their website is updated rarely and inconsistently, which makes it challenging to find out when creative pourings are going down (better to check Beer Advocate or the Brookston Beer Bulletin).

You can bring food in from elsewhere (Rosamunde's sausages a favorite).  Finding table space is a challenge on weekends, once you've got it, you're in for a solid session.

The only real drawback is the in your face attitude, which eminates from behind the bar and is cold, abrasive and poorly played.  I've seen a couple thrown out of here on a busy night because they couldn't pull their ID's out quick enough.    

All in all, it's a dive with high shelf taste in beer.  The ambiance and attitude are trumped by the cheap quality on tap and it's remains a favorite and in the top three for a proper pint in the city.
author: bryant g.

description:
Love love love this place! It's so local and chill... Get your beer (which is b*tch cuz there are sooooo many options.) and hang out. There isn't a lot of seating and the bathroom isn't the best (but it's the city... what do you expect??). The bartenders are great at helping you choose a beer, very knowledgeable!! 

Great place to go and catch up with friends. There is a bomb sausage place next door and a yummy pizza place on the opposite side. (Ask for burnt crust at the pizza place... yummy!)

Enjoy!
author: Nikki T.

description:
Was in there last night and both bartenders were less than warm and accommodating.  I'm not going to break it down or get into the drama, but I will say the owner needs to reconsider making these guys the face of his establishment.  Also you could smell urine half way out the bar from the bathrooms.  Funny, the bartenders seem more like janitors...

Great beer selection.  

Cuco's one block East and across the street is a must try.  Get the plantain burrito and enjoy the warm, friendly folks that run the place.
author: Matt R.

description:
Unbeatable beer bar. Some say that Lucky Baldwin's in Pasadena is better, but I disagree... Anwyay, yeah. Its great. 

My favorite thing about this place is when the Marina crowd comes in... Watching some overly white yuppie folks come in, stand at the bar, ask the bartender for a "cosmo", watch the bartender's expression when they explain that its only a beer bar, then see the Marina yup ask for a bud light, and watch the bartender walk away. That shit is classic.
author: Adam L.

description: Had one really good experience and one really bad experience, I guess they cancel each other out.  Their selection of beer is really good, sometimes their staff gets a little bit "high horsey" as I like to call it.  Cash only, so if you're one of those debit/credit only peeps, go to an ATM beforehand. Gets packed on the weekends and evenings, but if you're an afternoon drinker like myself, it's a good place for a sausage sandwich from next door and whatever kind of beer your little heart desires.
author: Jess C.

description: I would give this place zero stars if I could. Scratch that - NEGATIVE STARS. If you told me that I could either *never* in my whole life have a beer again, or come to this place for a beer, I would go sober. And I freaking LOVE BEER. The service and attitude at this bar is more heinously despicable than any place I have ever been. I think in Lower Haight and think the fact that Toronado is allowed to operate is a complete blight on the neighborhood. The people who would here are not only rude, unfriendly, discriminatory and TERRIBLE at knowing how to treat customers, they go beyond that by being physically aggressive to people who are paying THEM money to use their establishment. I can't get over how terribly this place treats their customer. Only go here if you feel like flushing your hard earned dollars down the toilet and being treated like sh*t in return.
author: Jenni R.

description:
Luckily, I didn't have to encounter the surly bartenders, but this is one of the best dives I have patronized...  From what I can remember.  My friends and I consumed three 9 liter bottles of beer, with very high alcohol content.

The staff was very accommodating, given that we had a large crowd of drunken people with us, including me.

I only wish they had a restroom that men and women didn't have to share.

Did I mention that we consumed 3 large, 9 liters large, bottles of beer?
author: Annalynn C.

description: Awesome bar! This was my first time in San Fran and of all the bars I made it to, this was the best. Great selection of amazing beers and a great local feel.
author: Zach C.

description:
I don't drink beer. I don't like it.

That said, I spent the last 30 minutes of 2006 and the first 2 hours of 2007 at this bar. I went with a friend, as it happens to be her favorite bar in the area. I didn't really want to go, not liking beer and all.

Well. My friend and the bartender (Stu) were actually able to find me a beer that I really enjoyed. And it only took two tries. Not that I didn't enjoy the first one, but the second was even better. Surprise surprise!

So kudos for that. Never thought it would happen.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
As long as you know what the hell is going on especially ordering a beer from the so called *MEAN* bartenders, you are good to go here.

The bartenders are not mean, not at all. There is so much selection, how can he pick and choose for you? Learn from my friends and I. Try them all or come back the next week for an all new selection! 

Came here last night, 4 dudes who felt like drinking. At the end of the night, that's 12 different beers we all tried together. We calculated how much ALCOHOL % and it comes down to this. The large glass of beer is around 2 shots 40% Alcohol by volume. Med is around 1 shot.

Drink 3 large glasses and you are good to go for the night. Right next door to the Sausage Factory and a pizza joint. Yes, you can bring in outside food and drink your cold beer.

Overall- all 2 bartenders that helped us were friendly, nice and asked us if we wanted more. Maybe next time, it will be different service. Straight up strong beer with a kick. My new kick it spot!
author: David L.

description:
Go back to the marina you pansies!! You don't even drink beer, you order the lamest thing there, fucking pomegranate cider!! please, come back when you replaced the flabby piece of flesh you call taste buds, with something that has some actual use. 

Otherwise this is the best beer bar known to man. no bs service, order beer get food if you want, smoke weed, and get drunk while watch night of the living dead and talk shit with your neighbor about the stupid fruitcakes from new York and LA, go home you cell phone copulating douche bags.
author: Brewbacca W.

description: To make it simple, this is the best beer bar in the San Francisco.  Great beer. Amazing Jukebox.  Maintains some of the atmosphere from when the Lower Haight was a bit edgy and not crammed to the gills with tech bros. Great sausage dogs next door.  Bartenders are just surly enough to be fun but are easily won over.  One of the few places in SF where people are friendly without being scary.
author: Russell I.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet.....  I've been going here a few times a year for about five years.  This is definitely one of the premier places in SF to grab a brew.  Prices are good and the selection is great but unfortunately you HAVE to be a regular to get decent service.  The owner's wife has started to recognize me and the dude who looks like he's straight out of a Dr. Seuss book has lightened up on the attitude on my recent visits.  I have some friends who are brewers in various local brew pubs and showing up a couple of times with them has helped in the service department.  If you like a great brew and want to down it with a great sausage this is the place to go.  Order your food next door at Rosemunde sausage grill and enjoy a beer or two at Toronado while you wait.
author: Neil A.

description:
I was hard pressed to rate this place 4 stars, but I did anyhow. The reason? I almost always get lip from the bartenders here.

Donned in a shirt with a llama on it, I went up to the bar to request a drink.

"You have a llama on your shirt. Llamas are mean, they spit." the bartender informs me.

"Only if they are angry, but they are soft and fuzzy otherwise." I reply back, thinking she is being flirty.

"A llama kicked and almost killed my sister." the bartender snapped, stomping off.

And so I ended up in some sort of customer penalty box for liking llamas. I had to wait 10 minutes for a drink!

And so, Toronado, you lose 1 star for a bartender who hates llamas, which is a shame, because you have a 5 star beer selection. Also, the bathroom was shockingly clean.
author: Mark B.

description:
"Did you get yelled at by the bartender?"

"No...but I got yelled at by EVERYONE here".

Seriously. So. Effing. Loud in there.
author: Shereen R.

description:
I do not know how I can surpass Avery G.'s review,  but what I know and this is true I simply love beer and I love Toronado. A friend introduced me to it and I think that's the best thing he's done so far.

I will see you soon.
author: Adrienne H.

description:
Quirky regulars and droppers-by.  Big beer selection - presented big board-style.  Half the fun is just reading all their names.

Gets pretty busy weekends and holidays.  There's a scary and dark alcove in the back if it's full in front.

As casual as casual gets.  It helps to be here if you've got knowledgeable beer folk with you.
author: Don B.

description:
Beer is my comfort food....so declares a sticker on Toronado's wall. And for those that feel that way, going to Toronado is the ideal Saturday or Sunday afternoon. 

You can bring in the delicious sausages from next door and they have one of the best beer selections in the City. When we were there on a Saturday there was some kind of happy hour and our rounds for three beers were like 7 bucks.  Kind of has a Zeitgeist feel - similarly surly bartenders, and similarly tough crowd.  Put on your dirtiest sweatshirt and fake handlebar moustache, and go.
author: Sara A.

description:
Best beer bar in California. 

So good.  Try the Moonlight Reality Czeck: they always have it on draught and it's one of the only places you can get it - one of the finest beers in the world.
author: sloe j.

description:
This place sucks.

I give them one star for having most beers at $4 and another star for having a good selection.

But the bartenders are elitist beersnob types, especially the wierd al lookalike who's a little too irritable to be a good bartender.

If you're looking for a bare bones bar experience, this place is worth checking out.  The jukebox is half-way decent.

I'm only going back when I'm forced to.  There are so many cooler, more comfortable bars on this block that are worth checking out.
author: L J.

description:
I had a great time catching up with my friend here, where we ended up hanging out for the whole evening.  The beer selection they've got really makes you feel like you just stepped into a special corner of Beer heaven.  Almost like someone secretly stole a few kegs from select brewers and decided to share it with you.

You'll want to try beer X, and then ale Y, and then stout Z.  Which of course we did.  The atmosphere was totally dive-ish the minute I walked in.  I believe I saw someone with his laptop also.. why I don't know.

Hurry up and snatch a seat, because it goes from lightly packed bar to an almost fudge packin' crowd.  Cash only!
author: Alfred Y.

description:
Yeah, um...yeah I know everyone who is cool and all is supposed to like this place but I just wasn't impressed.

If your goal is simply a large number of unique beers, many of which you've probably never heard of then you've come to the right place. 

But, I'd change their 50 or so beers any day for a place with 10-20 beers that has a friendly bartender, that takes the time to explain what kind of beer I might like, that has decent seating, where the back room doesn't smell like puke...OK, I'd settle for one of those things.

Yeah, I like beer but from the menu you can't even tell what beers are the darkest or of what persuasion to make a good choice. Choosing a random beer doesn't work out too well for most of us.

Don't get me wrong the crowd is usually pretty cool and laid back, but the place is usually way too crowded to really talk to much other than the people you came with.
author: Mike T.

description: Toronado falls prey to a recurring Haight theme, which is: we have good stuff, therefore we are incapable of being nice. Actually, I don't need smiles and fake personality when I order drinks, but you don't need to go so far out of your way to feel like an accomplished beer pourer. Stop fitting right into the stereotype of brooding, aging, punk revivalist with tattoos who wants nothing to do with anyone. We all get it. You're scary, great, where's my beer?
author: Sherry G.

description: The most chill bar in Haight Street San Francisco. This was my first time here at this location. I've been to the San Diego location a few times.But I think I like this location a lot more. The bartender was super cool and friendly. They have TONS of beer selection. We were there during happy hour. Dollar off beers! $3 for Blind pig?! Awesome! They even had Port Brewing Old Viscosity! If you are looking to enjoy a good craft beer, Toronado's is the place to be. It's not fancy or trendy at all which I like. The decor is grunge which is sick. I will def come back here if I ever find myself in Haight St San Francisco.
author: Mary Ann S.

description: I'm not sure when/what the happy hour is here but apparently I visited during that time and was able to grab a Damnation and a Saisson for only $7 total.  These went great with the sausages my friend and I got from Rosamunde next door.  I was very impressed with the beer selection and always enjoy a place that has an official bar dog that roams around.  I will defnitely be back the next time I am on Haight.
author: Scott G.

description: Awesome place for a craft beer. Make sure you have cash because they don't take credit cards.
author: John M.

description:
I like the beer selection at Toronado--but the bartenders are horrible.  Last night we took a cab across town for the "Russian River 'Tion Fest" in honor of SF Beer Week.  

Russian River is currently my favorite brewery, and they had the brilliant idea to tap out ALL of their beer at Toronado last night.  This is extremely rare.  That said, this event drew a spectacular crowd, which was handled shiteously by the bar staff.

We arrived at the 6pm happy hour and were able to snag a table in the front.  We really wanted to sample some brews that have not yet been bottled for sale, as did many of the patrons, so one would think it imperative to 1) have enough staff on hand and 2) have a "system" to get beer distributed to customers as quickly as possible.  I used to bartend myself, so I like to think my opinion counts for something.

My husband and I both stood at the bar, 3 people deep, for a solid 45 minutes before reaching the forefront.  He managed to get served and then I stayed on, cash in-hand, for another 20 minutes before I was served.  There were only 2 bartenders working, both of whom catered to the "Locals", who all seemed to receive service within 5 minutes upon arrival.  I guess I should have picked up that fake eyebrow ring at Claire's before heading to the Haight.
author: Hannah A.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars in the city; it's dark, sketchy and the bathrooms leave much to be decided, but that just adds to the charm of this beer lover's haven. 

Their selection of beers is unbeatable, the prices are totally reasonable, and it's awesome to grab a sausage next door and bring it over to wash down with a great brew.

It's totally not my usual scene, but I am in love with this bar. Not many places get five stars from me, but this one does, without any reflection.
author: Kara A.

description:
Please, this is not a dive bar. It is a beer hall. Dive bars have little atmosphere and even less presence.

I love this bar. All the beers on tap, the bartenders who will describe what a particular beer is upon request, and the general friendly vibe of this place are all worth the 5 stars. Plus, they played Pink Floyd's Animals in its entirety, which would get any bar 5 stars in my book. I love that album, especially when 3 sheets to the wind.

I wish I could be both funny and cool here, but I had such a good time that I am a little too drunk to do either right now. And by drunk I mean "this bar is the best."
author: Josh R.

description: The brews here and the brats next door is like crack to my taste buds. If I lived in the neighborhood I'd be 10 pounds larger and regularly knocked out from a food/booze coma. Nice bartenders, cool pub-like spot, and a ton of beers. Also worth mentioning the best bathroom quote of my life: "fuck burning man - your mom." If you enjoy a fine selection of beer and the smell of pub and grease, this bar will definitely be high up on your "to do" list.
author: Alex H.

description:
A great welcome to SF experience here last night. An immaculate beer selection and practically everything is 4 bucks a pint or less. If any scenario begs the question: why the hell do people pay 10 bucks for a glass of cabernet when they can have 2 pints of double IPA that's stronger, fresher, and better for your heart attack when chased with a Rosamunde's sausage or two from next door?

I happened upon Toronado becuase I heard it was Stone Happy Hour night and they had a selection of Stone brews on tap that included a few I had never tried, namely the Russian Imperial stout (delish) and the Rumination double IPA (double the pleasure, double the fun). 

Good, attentive bartenders who didn't leave me hanging for long, if at all. Toronado, I look forward to the next time you endrunkenate me.
author: Andy S.

description:
...and the clouds parted, and the sunbeams shone down upon Toronado, and a chorus of angels sang...

Is this beer heaven???
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This place is awesome! You know you are in an awesome beer bar when you see the following events unfold: 

Random guy 1: "I haven't seen this beer on tap since I was in Germany!" 

Random guy 2 "I haven't seen this beer on tap since Nepal '67!" 

Random guy 3 "Do you have Bud Light on tap?" 

Random guy 1 and 2 then grab Random guy 3 and beat the shit out of him and kick him out of the bar. While they are outside they decide to grab a sausage from the sausage place next door. 

OK, I made up Random guy 2 and 3 and the beat down that proceeded. Nevertheless, Toronado is a great beer bar. One of the problems though is they have sooo much beer on tap you will have a hard time choosing which beer you should try! 

Why does this place only get 4 stars? Mostly cuz the clientele is not so easy on the eyes and you will likely be the best looking person at the bar that night.
author: Brian A.

description:
A NIGHT AT THE TORONADO

This spot is literally a no frills bar where you come hang with your friends to do none other than drink. However, the list of beers available is so vast that for some - you'll be staring at the list with your eyes glazed. It gets even better when you and your friends have come up with beers from the menu and it's your "round." So you'll go to the bartender, say the names of the beers and he'll tell you, all annoyed, that he's out of those beers ... and it's back to the list you'll go.

Or, you could meet up for a drink with a friend you hadn't seen for awhile before you meet up with other friends after. That's what I did! This is what a night like that is like - 

Round 1 (for me)
Me: Sorry I'm late.
Him: What took you so long? I can't stay very long, but I'll stay and have a drink with you. 
Me: How many have you already had?
Him: This will be my third.

Round 2
Him: Fuck! I have to go! But I'll go after this beer.

Round 3
Us - drinking beer like water. Third round beers larger than the first two. Us, talking and talking.

Round 4
Him: What is that you're having now? Can I try some of that? [Proceeds to help me drink half of my glass.]

At the end of round 4 
Me: Let's go out for some air.
Him: Sure.

We head out. We talk for a bit more. He's talking about what I'm up to next. And then he's suddenly like - yeah, catch ya later! And he bolts off. I'm going - what the hell...!?

I reach my friends at a hookah bar. I'm ready to chill out, have fun. And then the hookah bar's feeling warm, and I can't breathe and ... oh shit! The beer finally hits me and - I'm fucked up. Suddenly I know why my friend split.

So, kiddies - the moral of the story is - beer is NOT water! And don't meet with a new group of friends after hanging at the Toronado (that is, if you don't want to ruin their night by having them take you back home early. Sorry guys! You're the BEST!).
author: Lorraine D.

description:
I had a nice, mellow time here on a Tuesday night, after eating at Indian Oven. I'm not a big beer drinker, but I tried the pomegranite cider, and it went down just fine! My friends who drink beer, however, tried it and thought it to be somewhat reminiscent of cough syrup! Well, everybody's different...

The bartender was super nice and quite patient with our indecisive group. I enjoyed the vibe, and the roomy back area was perfect for talking and hanging out. I probably would have gone to the Noc-Noc if it had been completely up to me, but hey, introducing you to a new place is what friends are great for!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Yeah, they've got a lot of beer here; Hoegaarden & Duval just to name a couple.  Despite the fabulous collection, the place is always packed with dorky yuppies, which really ruins it for me.  I feel like I'm in the damn Marina.  

Anyway this place does have one saving grace, and that is  Tony "the Dude".  

Tony "the Dude" practically lives here, and he is one of the most metal motherfuckers I know.....well, the most metal motherfucker with dreadlocks!  If you see him, buy him a beer and praise the almighty metal merchant.
author: Larry A.

description:
Loved it.  

If i lived in SF I would be here lots.  So many different beers to choose from.  Nice bartender.  Interesting crowd.  Next door to Mythic Pizza...yummers.
author: desiree n.

description:
I'm almost ashamed I'm giving this place a 4 because I love the concept: rare beer, rude bartenders, random crap splattered on the walls as if it were 'art.'

Unfortunately, the smell of piss, beer rotting on the floor, and industrial strength Mr.Clean ruin the sweet aroma of my Belgian draught.  The place is always crowded, which I enjoy [otherwise, I would just drink at home], but there isn't any sort of attempt at crowd flow.

Call me a creep, call me what you will, but taking credit cards would be a nice little treat.  Make it a $20 minimum, I don't care, but that's the crowd control I'm talking about.  There's none of that.

Often 25+ beers on tap, selectively chosen and rotated frequently.  Gets crowded, smelly, cash only.  Go.  Have fun.  Just know what to expect.  A real "San Francisco treat."

Auf.
author: Dave K.

description:
Amazing selection of Belgian beers you really can't find anywhere else in the US (with any reasonable effort), on TAP, with reasonable prices considering the market.

And it's divey and there is crappy food nearby and they don't care if you bring it in there to eat it. Bonus.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Dear Yelp,

I like beer, sure.  For the most part, I stick to Newcastle.  However, the beer selection at Toronado is so immense, I feel like a kid in a bar whenever I go there (given a choice as a child, I'm certain I would take beer over candy any day).  Also, because they don't carry Newcastle, I get a chance to try a whole bevy of beers.

If you don't mind your friends calling you an alcoholic, I recommend going here during the day.  The people are friendlier, there isn't much of a crowd (unless it's burger Tuesday, in which case the place gets packed), and the best bartenders are working.  Plus, there's always a dog or two lying around in case you're in need of companionship.

If you're curious about a beer, the bartenders seem more than happy to offer a recommendation and even a small sample.  If you're hungry, just grab a sausage from next door, they let you bring food into Toronado, and they'll even return the basket for you.  What a place, what a place.

I give Toronado a fantastic score of 5 out of 5 stars.

Love,
James
author: Cheryll M.

description:
Toronado has an excellent selection of beers.
The staff can be a little brazen, but they just don't like to take shit.
I'm sure it can get pretty irritating to have people ask you for bud light all night when you work with wide an awesome selection of local and imported beers which are delicious and different.

I used to live around the corner, and the staff was always VERY nice to me.  Gave great customer service, and the occasional comped beer.

It does get packed on weekends, so get there a little early to ensure a seat.

But as far as dive bars go, it's on of my favorites.
author: C B.

description:
Every time I go to Toronado, I love it more.  The beer selection is unreal (they have several beers that I have never tried let alone heard of!)  The staff have an apparent obsession with good beer and doing things right, confirmed by the fact that they have all the glassware necessary to keep the Belgian beers real.  I also love the fact that they let you bring in food from neighboring restaurants without a second look.  What validated this place was the fact that my brother, a beer aficionado in his own right, was blown away by Toronado.

Perhaps the best part?  There is no Bud, Coors or Miller anywhere in sight.  Walk on, phonies.
author: Louis M.

description:
Wow - the yin and the yang of this place!  Best beer selection in town, no contest.  Pliny the Elder on tap, 3+ cask ales, and a beer menu extraordinaire.  I'll even credit them for being located next to Rosamunde.

However, the fat bartender (owner?) is a jackass, the place is a dump, and half the bar smells like the toilets.  I hope it's the toilets.  The crowd is the usual Haight street too-cool-for-school (too-cool-for-teeth?) bunch, who look at you like you like you like they just found a warm turd in their pockets. 

Update: Mad Dog has totally been redone - now it's wicked fancy.  Nice, but fancy.   

If you want to drink a good beer in a good place, check out City Beer Store - not the range of beers on tap, but a great selection, and check this out - the people are all nice.  Even the ones that run the place!
author: Pete G.

description:
Toronado is not a bar.

As I've read in some publications, it is technically an "Alehouse".  I know I'm probably splitting hairs here, but lets take a step inside.  On entry the place smells like the floor was mopped with beer.  Only a few steps in, the enormous beer menu looms above, beckoning you to try any of the excellent varieties.  A glance to the right and hopefully your eyes admire the variety of glasses, none of which are for show but used and properly matched to the style of beer you order.  The walls are covered in beer signs and memorabilia including the rear of the bar which has walls covered in various tap handles some looking a least a decade old.

Yes, you've reached a small sub-division of beer drinker's heaven.  

Some bars in the Lower Haight are sometimes reviled for their lack of a license to sell hard alcohol but when you've got this many varieties of excellent beer to get through, you soon forget about that shot of Jameson or Gin and Tonic.  The selection is unique with Death and Taxes, Lagunitas Sirius and Anchor Old Foghorn all on tap, not to mention a great variety of German beers and favorites from the Northwest region.  If you're bored with the beer selection at your favorite bar, give this place a visit and you may come back more than a few times.

I don't know why the bartenders are aloof.  We could speculate on it eternally.  Yes, they can be reiminiscent of Seinfeld's illustrious Soup Nazi (No Lager for You!!!) if you ask the wrong or too many questions.  The only advice I can offer is come prepared.  If you have a question, try to mention a comparison to another brand so they think you know what you're talking about and always have a back-up in mind.

Yeah the space kind of sucks and if you want to sit down get here early but I think the crowds are just a testament about how great it is to be able to go somewhere and actually have a huge array of beers not easily found elsewhere in the City all in one location.

My roommate will give me unrelenting hell for giving this place such a high rating given his disdain for the bartnders but gee...  just look at all those beers...
author: Steven R.

description: If you are looking to grab a few great beers with friends, then this is your spot. It hands down has the largest selection and the prices are reasonable. The thing is that it can get pretty crowded, but snagging a seat or an area is generally not a problem. Get a sausage next door, come over, grab a seat at the bar and enjoy. Then repeat.
author: Shanna T.

description:
This is a beer bar for non-beer drinkers and/or people that have spent a lot of time over seas. The premise is good (lots of foreign beers on tap), and it makes a lot of people pleased. 

I'm in to trying different beers, but basically, I don't want guff from my bartender. It's just beer.
author: doug d.

description: This place is an old dump, but what a beer selection! The Toronado has one of the best beer selections in all of San Francisco. Stop in next door and get a sausage at the Rosamunde Sausage Grill while you're here.
author: P K.

description:
Fantastic, fresh local craft beer selection.
It's crowded, loud, cash only...don't be a dick to the staff.
Also, if you wear a scarf indoors and drink Miller light or PBR, go back to Union Street, pansy.
author: Alex F.

description:
Yeah the bartenders are usually inattentive dicks, ( except Princess)
but this place has a legendary beer selection and holds some of the best beer related events on the West Coast. 
You have to just laugh when it takes ten minutes for my hot girlfriend to get a beer, but its got to be hard to work battling constant acid flashbacks. You don't go to Toronado for the service, you go for the beer.
author: Sean K.

description:
As good as it gets...yes that about sums up Toronado.  I don't mean to be misleading, Toronado does not get 5 stars in every category, but for being the best in its class it gets 5 stars.  

Toronado has by far the best beer selection in California, if not the United States, and depending on your tastes, possibly the best in the world.   This bar housed the birth of Northern California beer culture and debuted some of the greatest beers to the world.  For years it was the only place you could get Russian River, and it continues to draw costumers from hundreds of miles.

The service can be brash, but like any other aficionados joint, you have to earn respect here.  If you don't know what you want, don't try to order.  If you don't know what 'hoppy' means, do a little research before coming to Toronado.  And for fuck's sake, don't try and order wine!  If you want to talk with the bartenders and sample different beers, come by in mid-day when they have the time.  You are not special, and they don't want to hang out with you during their 100 beers an hour evenings.

But if you know what you like, want some of the best beer in the world and an amazing sausage from next door, come to Toronado and experience 5-Star beer transcendence.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description:
This place is dark, crowded, loud, and a little rough around the edges.  If you are in the mood for getting a good round of beers from all over the world though, you have come to the right place.  Sure the bartenders can be a little rude, skip over you when you are called on and your mind isn't made up, even talk down to you when the occasional rookie asks for liquor or soft drinks, but once you get the beer of your choice in your hands, all is forgotten.  

I recommend the Delerium Tremens, the most expensive beer on the menu sure, but also the one that is gonna knock you on your ass the quickest, just ask the guy in the corner passed out with two glasses in his hands.

All in all, go here if you want a good selection of beer to throw back.
author: Steve H.

description: Great beer selection, OK atmosphere, extremely rude bartender. You know the older lady with black hair and I've had a sh*t life so f*ck you sort of attitude? I won't be coming back.
author: Brian H.

description:
Excellent beer selection including many California micro-brewers' beers.  Rotating List.

Friendly crowd and bar staff although make sure you tip well when they are busy.

Defintely a Dive Bar atomsphere and they do it well.  Good place to catch a game if you can get a seat that has a good view of the small TV.

They have authentic Cask Beers and serve the beers in their proper glasses- that means alot.

Hopefully next time they'll have an English Ale served up in an Imperial Pint Glass- that was the one thing missing during my visit.
author: Peter H.

description:
Can you say.... "The Bizness?"

If you can't, go away and don't even try it. Nado's is on some other level brewery-stewery....

Good beers, shidday service which don't matter because the beer is what u come for, not the service. If Howard Stern is rude to you, who cares. As long as he gives you beer!!!!!!!
author: Gordo M.

description:
Great beer... like beer you dont even know... old kinds, dark sweet and all sorts. Mothers milk really.

thank you god, thank you toronado

(-1 for crowd and wait at times... immediate gratification being my driving goal at all times)
author: Ken S.

description: If you could only come here and have the beer without dealing with the rude, arrogant  owner/ bartender!  No wonder people complain about the service!  The bathrooms are disgusting too.
author: Susan Y.

description: This is the greatest beer bar in California! Try anything from the beer engines, last time I was there I had a pint of Sierra Nevada's Hoptimum, there is nothing like a hoppy beer at room temp. The complete flavor profile is exposed and you can truly taste the beer for what it is. Prost!
author: Matt R.

description: 4 stars purely for the beer selection.  There is nothing special about this place except the beer and the sausage store next door.
author: Matt P.

description:
mmmmm, beer!

Yet another thing I felt deprived of while on my ten week trip to SE Asia: GOOD, FRESH, DARK, TASTY BEER!!!
Asians can do spices, they can NOT do beer.

I had my first sip of Sierra Nevada only hours after i got off the plane.  DAMN!  forgot how good this shit tasted!!

and Toronado has, i dunno, about 200 different selections of awesome beers from all over the planet.

If you love beer, you'll LOVE Toronado.
author: Shayna N.

description:
Wanted to watch our beloved Worst Team in the MLB last Thursday and after my two male compatriots complained VERY LOUDLY all the way down Haight St. about how much they hate Kezar's, we ended up down on Lower Haight, thinking Mad Dog would be a good option.
