However, I had forgotten that it was trivia night, so after watching a couple shots of Lincecum looking REALLY stoked (and adorable) in the dugout, we ventured out to find a place where we might sit while drinking our beer and enjoying the game.

Now the few times I'd been in Toronado before it had been nice, but kind of crowded.  But I realized as we pondered our options that I had never noticed if they had TVs in Toronado.  We figured it was worth a try, and we wandered in.  It was a bit crowded in the front as usual, and there was a TV above the bar.

All of a sudden I remembered there was a back room.  We check it out (during which point my two male friends apparently have to stare down some guy who's staring me down - being in bars with boys is AWESOME) and not only is there ample seating in the booths in the little back room, but there is a decent-sized TV mounted on the wall.  I hold the booth, my two lovely gentleman grab the beers, and then we settle in and watch more shots of Lincecum looking stoked(dorky/hot.)

Beyond these felicitous circumstances, the bar itself is one of *those* beer places that has a "really amazing" selection of international beers.  I like me a good beer now and then, especially when it's a GOOD beer and coupled with some sports.  It's a small bar with a lot of dark wood and a bit of wear and tear around the edges.  I wouldn't call it a dive so much as a "local" in the English tradition.  They don't serve their own food like English pubs do, but why not grab a delicious (VEGAN) sausage from Rosamunde next door?  

Beer : Sausage :: Wine : [nut] Cheese :: Coffee : [vegan] Donut :: Your mom : ___

ANYWAY I was very happy to discover that this pleasant little fancy beer hole has televisions and TWO of them at that.

Beer : Sausage :: Me : Tim Lincecum.

Now if you'll excuse me....

o_0
author: Ashley B.

description:
The biggest selection of beers on tap I have seen anywhere.  Toronado's choices are truly encyclopedic.   You want a Hefeweizen - they have 6 different ones on tap, and so on.

Service is just OK, long lines to get a drink.  Vibe is fine, nothing special.

Cash only, so bring some green to get your brews.
author: Aaron T.

description: I used to like this place because it had good beer selection, but who cares...so do most bars in sf without ahole bartenders.  This place just pain sucks and I don't ever really give bad ratings...And by ahole bartenders im not talking about like zeigist ahole, where its kinda funny.  I mean like howard stern looking aholes.  I hope this place burns down and they just expand the rosamundes.
author: christopher h.

description:
I don't even like beer for the most part, but I actually had some I could get use to and the atmosphere is great - TVs and jukebox noice!

Death + Taxes = the blackest coffee you'll ever have a hangover with
Aajit = winey beer or beery wine
author: Charm N.

description:
You can't go wrong with $3.50 pints of really good beer. What sold me was the partnership with Rosamunde next door. I can drink beer and eat sausages at the same time?!? Not so good for my wannabe healthy lifestyle but not so bad on my wallet.

As far as my favorite bar in SF, mine it is not, but it is a solid bar to get some pints and a sausage from next door. I can see myself coming back very soon.
author: Defne A.

description: Toronado's amazing draft beer selection and happy hour special ($1 all drafts) overcomes the occasional lack of seating. The best tip I can give if you want to guarantee a seat is to avoid stopping by during Giants games. Toronado is hands down my favorite place to grab a beer after my imaginary work day.
author: Jordan Z.

description:
Pros:
-Deeee-licious beer
-Super tasty sausage next door, which you can bring into the bar!

Cons:
-Hard to get a seat

Bottom Line:  I don't mind standing!  I'll be back!
author: Liezl C.

description: I swear, I didn't know the large was going to be a 24 oz. mofo.  When she set it in front of me all I could do was just laugh and start drinking.  The guys next to me starting making cracks.  One said it was a hot tub of beer.  The other one said it was an aquarium.  At one point, he started singing Aquarium a la "Aquarius" style.  I sure do like a place that can provide me with entertainment.  The bartenders were all really nice despite the fact that they were swamped to the gills.  And the male to female ratio was definitely a plus for M and me too.  We'll be back.  Oh, and for the record, I did finish the whole thing and ordered another one... the small.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
A great neighborhood beer bar with lots of domestic and international beers on tap. Plus with Rosamunde next door, you could never go wrong. I mean how can you beat a pint and sausage lunch/dinner?
 
It can get a little crowded, but so can every bar.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Good dive bar.  Good.  Sit.  Stay.

Good selection of beers.  Classic dive bar atmosphere.
author: Rob H.

description: Great Bar! Friendly atmosphere, great beer selection and fair prices. This will definitely become one of my regular haunts.
author: Logan C.

description: The best bar we hit up on our most recent visit to San Francisco.  Great beer selection. Amazing jukebox.  Love the vibe. It was dog friendly and then the icing on the cake was asking a lady who walked in with a baby in a stroller to leave. No place I'd spend more time if I lived there. The bartender was nothing but nice to us.
author: Kurt D.

description:
A five star dive bar if there ever was one.  The tap list is, in my opinion, the best on the west coast - maybe the country.  No american mega brands or Euroswill here - just the good stuff!  Mostly west coast and belgian beers.  The bottled beer list is surpassed only by my personal stash - no other bar or restaurant I've visited even comes close.

If you are looking to break out the credit card and have your ass kissed - forget about it here.  Cash only and the bartenders will get to you quickly enough.  Relax - the service level is directly related to your level of patience and cooperation.  The place definitely has "character".  Great sausage is right next door.

I usually stop in here for a few on every trip to SF.  The festivals are worth a special trip!
author: Steve D.

description: On our recent visit to San Francisco, my husband and I popped in here on the recommendation of a friend.  Great selection of beers at great prices.  Friendly crowd.   It was a little crowded when we went even though it was 3 p.m. but we quickly found two seats at the bar and chatted up our neighbors for local beer recommendations.  Fantastic place to throw a few back.
author: Abby S.

description:
I'm actually relieved that so many other people have had the same RIDICULOUSLY RUDE service that I had when I went to Toronado.  I thought it was just me.  There is no need for that kind of attitude.  Craft beer is about enjoying beer and the beer community, not about being exclusionary jerks.
   It took me about 30 seconds to check out the taps, which was a great selection, and the pony tailed guy was making all these impatient faces and rolling his eyes at me.  
   I know beer.  I work at a brewery.  I was from out of town and had never been to Toronado.  I wanted to check out the selection.  Give me a minute man!  The guy wasn't even busy!
   I don't believe in establishments that take pride in jerky service.  I'm not sure if this is Toronado's schtick but it sure seems like they let it keep happening based on the reviews. 
   I LOVE beer.  But my sense of justice is too strong to patronize or recommend a place that allows such unkindness to proliferate.
author: Justin T.

description:
At the suggestion of a colleague, who said that though he brewed his own beer down in So Cal, would always visit Toronado every time he is in the City, my other colleagues and I ended up at Toronado as an after dinner escape. 

This dive bar, of which I hold in great esteem, made me consider beer as something more than a chaser.  I lost count of how many different beers on tap I tasted and the bartenders were master storytellers spinning tales behind every beer we tried.  Yes, the seats, tables, walls, and anything else you touched were sticky, but that says something about just how much beer is consumed in the place and how long this place has been around.
author: Kieu L.

description:
I learned a valuable lesson within the first ten minutes after I arrived at Toronado: Nothing pisses off the bartenders more than an indecisive patron.

It takes elbows of steel to wedge your way to the bar... if you haven't had a chance to review the giant beer board in the time it takes you to reach the bar, take a step back and let someone else go first. Some dude got all the way to the front and when the bartender gave him his attention the dude turned and looked up at the board and called out a brew. Smart bartender simply yelled back, "I can't hear you when you're looking away" and helped the next dude.

The bartenders are amazingly helpful and cool, even with all the yelling and screaming going on. Once they've given you their attention, they'll listen and give you small tastings if you ask.

So yeah, in one night I had beers that tasted like pomegranate, chocolate, coffee, yeast, and old leather shoes. Nice selection, folks.
author: Davey G.

description:
Like this place needs anyone else extolling it's virtues, but whatever...

   If you love GOOD beer, this is the place for you. It fills my heart with joy that I live within walking distance to a great bar like this. They have a great rotation of local craft brews from the likes of Speakeasy, Bear Republic, Moonlight, and Anderson Valley, and some nice Belgian beers as well on tap and in bottles. And they get access to some special brews that only go out in limited quantity, like Sierra Nevada's Torpedo Ale, Bear Republic's Racer X, and Russian River's Pliny the Younger. 

   But their special events and festivals are what really sets them apart. Belgian beer fests, barleywine fests, Special "Featured Brewery" nights, and more. Always new interesting beer to try, even for someone who has tried quite a few. 

   My favorite time to go is weekend afternoons. Grab a beer sausage next door, settle in at the bar or one of the tables, and enjoy a lazy day.
author: Brandi K.

description:
I have but one question for you. How much do you like beer?

I like it so much I dream about it. On vacation I drink it with every meal of the day and generally before, after and in between said meals. Hell, I'd even bathe in it. 

If you're like me, and I hope you're not, or if you want to go to a relaxed, divey bar with the best beer selection in the world go to Toronado. It is also next door to the tiny, evil, delicious sausage house that beckons me to it more than I'd care to admit. 

Only one complaint, like so many of the Haight street bars it is cash only. Other than that I have nothing but embarrassingly gushing praise for Toronado.
author: Evan O.

description: Great selection of on tap quality brew! and a super delicious sausage joint next door. cozy for an afternoon pitcher, but it can get a bit overcrowded at night.
author: Laura W.

description:
AMAZING beer selection. They used to carry a lot more imports, but recently decided to put the focus more on local beers to keep prices down. Happy hour at this place is the best. Also, they allow you to sample any beer you'd like before you buy anything.

The bartenders aren't always friendly... in fact, sometimes they're complete dicks, but I don't go to bars to be buddies with the bartender so it's okay.

You're allowed to bring in sausages from Rosamunde Sausauge Grill next door, which is motherfuckin' badass to say in the very simplest of words.

The BIG problem is seating. Very limited, it fills up very quickly. I went by myself the other day and STILL had trouble finding a place to drink my beer.

When it comes to atmosphere, I love nothing more than metal music and stickers all over the walls. Lucky for me, Toronado has both of those departments covered. Not a place to go drink if you wanna hear Britney's new single, or even if you prefer hip-hop when you drink.

Cash only, like most every private business in SF. There are like 3 ATMs right on the street with $2 fees.
author: Ramsey D.

description:
One million bottles of beer on the wall, a million bottles of beer ...

Me and a girl friend went here on a rainy Saturday, on the last day of their Barleywine festival.  At first I marveled at how many people were crammed in such a tight space with sticky seats and floors and curt bartenders, but after 2 pints of good microbrews I was willing to overlook this.  We got there a bit late as they were all out of the barleywine festival winners... thus, I fell back to Pliny the Elder, which I find is always a fine choice when available.  Maybe because it smells like pot.  Or could that have been the drunken white rastafari seated around me at the bar?
author: Marjorie B.

description: Beer, beer, beer, beer and more beer. One of the best selection of beer in the city. I'm not talking about big corporation, mass production beer, but all the local micro-brewery. I've been here several times and loved it. It gets quite packed during peak drinking hours but is well worth it. They have selections of beer you never heard of and some has names you might scared of. This is a total dive bar with plenty of locals, true flavor of the city. Occasionally, they have barley wine special, which means VERY strong beer. Price are very reasonable but parking might get a little troublesome. One Saturday night, it took me about 30min to find parking but if you don't might that, come here for the beers.
author: Peter L.

description:
Fantastic beer selection.  Bartender who is one part Howard Stern and one part Soup Nazi.  Cash only.  German sausages next door.  What more could you ask for?

Of course, most of the beers are quite high in alcohol, so pace yourself a little better than I did last time I was there.  For your own sake.  Great place to get a drink and relax over a beer you've never tried, though.
author: Geoff K.

description:
Yes, they have an amazing selection of beers.

No, they are not nice... AT ALL.

Went there last night (Sunday, December 20th) and the brunette lady bartender was more than rude to me - She was full on mean.  I just don't understand why someone who is so horrible at working with people is in the service industry??  People like this lady should be working in a factory or lab, far far away from customers who want to be treated with a smidgen of respect and decency.

So, if you really want a wide range of beer and are OK having a bartender be completely rude to you, then go to Toronado!
author: Nicholas C.

description:
Yeah, there is a lot of beer, but Zeitgeist has tons of beer too, plus a cool outdoor area.

The floors are sticky here.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Um... I feel terrible about giving Toronado a three-star rating, when really I think THEY should be giving ME and my friends a minus-one!

Location: Middle of the street, on Haight, by Fillmore.
Parking: Not too bad, but not good either.
Beer Selection: Outstanding
Alcohol Selection: Makers What?!
Seating: Crowded, None
Restrooms: About as clean as the ones in Falluja
Bartenders/Bouncers: They'll get no criticism from me.

I was attending the birthday bash of a friend, and our crew of between 10-15 people consumed three 9-liter bottles. Yes, you read that right - they have them, we drank them. Unfortunately, that much beer also means lots of breakage and upchucking. This tends to upset the bar staff who are less than pleased by the outcome, so I don't blame them for being surly (as many have commented upon). The solution is to let them know right away, get rid of the breakage, and ask for someone to come mop up. When you do this they tend to be rather happier with you, and even invite you back.

Definitely a dive bar, really not planning on going back unless I'm in the neighborhood. Not because of anything they did or didn't do, but just because I'm not a big beer fan.
author: Maxx L.

description:
I'm not sure what i can add to a place that already has 248 reviews...so I'll keep it brief. This place has a lot of beer. Some of it is fantastic, some it is average or boring, and some of it so vile that even the snobbiest of beer critics can't swallow the brewed crap that has come out of the tap. In my two visits here, I've had an example of each. I can only respect them for enabling me to have those diverse experiences.

The last time I was went was a special night for the Russian River  Brewing Company's "'tion Night" where they had $3 versions of all of their crazy-ass beers on tap. This was cool - they head brewer was there as well. Some beers were good, and some were just plain wierd with strange micro-organisms in them. Still - I'm loving the opportunity presented.

Lastly, as everyone on here has already mentioned - you can take the awesome sausages from Rosamunde's Sausage grill next door into this bar and eat it here and stuff. too cool. Beer and Beer Sausage. That's just about perfect.
author: Tolga E.

description:
If you like beer this is your Western Wall or Mecca. Stopped by here last night after many firestones at the Yelp party.

He'brew was hosting a 11th anniversary party. Took down some He'brew Rye. I don't really understand the brewing process but it was brewed or aged(?) in rye whisky oak barrels.

Soooo good. Almost all the beers are under $5 and you could go here 100 times and drink different beer every time. 
In fact in writing this, I decided I really need to go here more often. I haven't down the Rosamunde Sausage/Tornado combo yet, but it seems to be all the rage and goes together like fixed gears and tight jeans.
author: Gabe b.

description: Always a great place to fill up on a varied amount of brewed beer. No food served but outside eats are welcome.
author: Alissa F.

description:
Been coming to this place for 12 years now, and still there's nowhere in the city with a better beer selection. Pliny the Elder and Moonlight Toast all in one session.....Damn that's heaven. 

Tips for non-regulars: Drink on a night when Johnny, Kirstin, Stu, or the cute new girl(from Mad Dog) are bartending. The older bartenders will not help you pick a beer, or describe it to you.
author: Tim S.

description:
Fabulous beer bar. I went to school in Washington DC, and I have been looking for something to replace to brickskeller  for quite some time. This is certainly no replacement, but it's the best we have in fabulous San Francisco.

This bar is awesome - really friendly people, and the bartenders are really friendly and talkative too as long as it isn't super crowded. if it is super crowded (as it usually is on a Friday or Saturday night) then it can take you up to 20 minutes to get a beer, and the bartenders, while still friendly, have very little patience for you trying to decide on which beer to choose.

The one other great thing about this place is it is "bring your own food" - a very cool concept for a bar. Again, that doesn't work so well after 10 pm on a Friday, but anytime during the day it's great to grab a burrito or something and stop in for a pint.
author: Adam W.

description:
Yeah, that one bartender is a bitch.  A really cool bitch!  She gave me two free beers when I smiled and gave her a thumbs up after she yelled down the bar at me to hold the fuck on.   Or maybe because I didn't order a Bud or a Stella, I donno.  Whatever, the Toronado works for me.   The attitude and decor make up for the location, and the beer would make up for any kind of restroom madness.  At least there's not a line for the damn thing.  

This makes 500 reviews for the 'Nado!
author: Jared L.

description:
This place is a mixed bag.  What's in the bag?

The cons - 
Semi rude bartenders.  Not really rude, just beer snobby.  I didn't even know beer drinkers got this snobby.  It's frickin BEER for crying out loud.  I ordered a Stella.  Shoot me, I like Stella.  It tastes good.  The guy proudly said they 'didn't carry stella, but at least I didn't order PBR.'  I was too afraid to ask what was wrong with PBR.   And apparently I can't pronounce Duvel OR Chimay.  And I drink and order them a lot.  When I can't get Stella or I feel like drinking beer from a fancy cup.   Small improper intonations of a vowel will not be tolerated if it is in regards to beer here.  You may speak with a lisp, but you damn sure better enunciate the name of the beer you are ordering like you were James Earle Jones if you are gonna drink here.

OK I'm exaggerating.  

Pros - Cool old beer crap everywhere. A lot of good beer on tap, especially if you like Belgian beers etc.  And they may not have Stella, but they don't have Coors Light or MGD either.  So I'll take the good with the bad.  The crowd is pretty laid back and cool.

And some of the funniest bathroom wall reading of any pub I've been too.  I would have stayed in the bathroom an extra thirty minutes reading it if (a) it didn't smell a little and (b) my friends wouldn't think I was making a hand party.  It does feel weird when you walk out of the bathroom laughing and people look at you like 'what were you doing in there???'
author: Nahum M.

description:
Almost always crowded, almost always worth it.

Actually, when it's crowded these days I usually step a couple of doors down to the Noc Noc.  Even though I've been a semi-regular at the Toronado since 1991, I still get attitude from the bartenders sometimes, and the crowds annoy me more than they used to.

But if I go on a weekday afternoon, or early in the day on a Saturday, I love nothing more than queuing up an hour's worth of tunes on the jukebox and blowing my extra cash on the huge variety of great beer.

Here's a Tip:  Buy a Toronado T-shirt.  They've been looking cool for almost 20 years.
author: Doublejack X.

description:
Toronado is by far my favorite bar in the city. To be fair, I'm a fanatic for excellent beer, so I'm partial to any place that serves it. They feature mostly West Coast micro brews, with some other micro brews from the rest of the country and international beers as well. The selection is always excellent and cheap most of the time. The beer paraphernalia all over the walls and ceiling show the colorful history of this place.

A couple drawbacks for some people, but not me - the bartenders have an edge to them, and can seem unaccommodating to those who don't know what they want. The menu can be a bit intimidating for those who don't know great beer. The place is really out of control on weekend nights - most bars are - so I know to avoid going there.

My recommendation is that if you're interested in truly great beer, come here with an open mind and have fun.
author: Chris M.

description:
BEER!! BEER!!! and more BEER! They have a great selection. I love IPAs and they always have something new for me to try. Endless beers on draft. 

The place gets packed, but I definitely don't mind standing with a good beer in hand. I usually come here late at night, but I will definitely check the place out during Happy Hour sometime.
author: crystal e.

description:
As I continue my stroll down memory lane, hitting all my "firsts" in San Francisco, Toronado leaps out as the bar where I had my first kiss with my favorite former boyfriend... 

Our first sort of group date, we'd been to a  gallery opening on Fillmore near Haight, and as the rest of our gang dispersed for the evening, we headed down to Toronado for a drink.  Don't remember much about the bar, only about the boy, and the kiss, as we finally gave up on random small talk and he tugged me towards him as he leaned against a wall near the door.  Some random guy tried to break us apart, saying, "Are you two on your honeymoon or what?"

"Yes," I said, never looking away from the nearly nattily dressed boy with the beautiful beady brown eyes, who bore a striking resemblance to Pueris Eternis, "We're on our honeymoon."  And we continued on.

Five stars for being the right place, at the right time.
author: H.A. ..

description: Great amount of drinks. Probably a lot you may not have heard of before. Either way it is a good spot to get a quick drink with friends. Just be aware that the bartender lady sometimes forgets your face so she might ID you many times... she forgot mine even after ordering from her 5 mins before.
author: Sonlay V.

description: A dive bar worth going to. I'm not a dive bar type of person but this place was dope. It was packed on a monday night (I was here to watch the NBA playoffs and eat my food from next door). Great environment and some unique beers on draught to choose from.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I have to admit, I was a little timid about going here, concerned that I might do something to offend the bartender and be kicked out of the establishment. (I tend to take a while to figure out what I want to drink sometimes but knew that I'd have to be swift and decisive here). 

So, we ordered off the main board. And, then, later, I noticed that there was a list of Belgian beers behind the bar that are served in bottles. Guess I was hoping for more selection of Belgian style beers. Perhaps I'll do better the next time I go now that I know more about how things works there.

We were joined by a mom & son pair at our table after a while. I liked the divey atmosphere.  

Great food nearby as others have mentioned. You can bring it in here to consume with your beer. We opted to eat beforehand and then head to the bar.
author: Tina Z.

description:
Beer Heaven!
I'm a dark beer fan and most of the time it is so hard to find a variety, but not in the Toronado. This place is really great, the staff is friendly as are the patrons and the interior darkness just adds to the character of the bar.
author: E P.

description:
I got to visit the legendary Toronado while in the City and found that it was pretty much what others have said. 

That being rude bartenders (which I can deal with), Rank smells throughout the place (which I can deal with), and a vast beer selection.  

So I figured out how I was going to do this before showing up, let me share.

1. Know beforehand what beer you'll want -granted this may be hard to do if you don't know what they have.

2. Don't ask questions. They don't care and are mostly too busy to give any input on your selection. The bartender with the "Go F@#% Yourself" tee shirt sums it up pretty well.

3. Wear non-high fashion basic street clothing so you don't stand out and get jacked in the Haight, and in case the drunken guy spills his beer on you.  

4. Drink your glass of beer or three, pay, and then leave.

By doing this you won't have any grand expectations of this place and you'll fit right in.

After having been to both Toronado's (now in San Diego) I like the SD one best.
author: Howeler G.

description:
New to Yelp.  Have been reading posts and found it very helpful in making decisions on eating, drinking, etc...
So I am now going to return the favor.  
I have only been to Toronado once, but will absolutely return.  An amazing beer selection served perfectly.  
The place is unpretentious and inviting.  Good spot.
author: Chris A.

description:
Three words for you: Barley Wine Festival!!! 
If you like good beer, then you must go to the Toronado... but be forewarned, you better know what you want when you order, otherwise you will get the "look".  Some people call the bartenders there Beer Snobs, I call them Beer Geniuses, as they only serve the best of the best.  Where else can you enjoy a nice yummy beer and a delicious sausage from the place next door.  The crowd is eclectic, total SF, I love it.  I don't drink beer as much as I did in college, but when I get a craving for a great beer, I only head to one place, and that is the Toronado.
author: Mariana A.

description:
This is definitely a business where it is more important to look at what people write, rather than the rating they give. Different people prioritize different things.

I'll admit it; the service in this bar is terrible. You might stand at the bar for a good 10 minutes before someone helping you. And you'll probably have to stand. It's extremely crowded.

All that aside, it has an absolutely incredible selection of beers, and lots of great special events. Granted, I live half a block away so I come here all the time, but even if I didn't live in the neighborhood, it'd still be worth the trip when I'm looking to try some good beer.
author: Mark A.

description: Mmmmm beer. And in very close proximity to excellent snausages.  The only crappy bit is everyone knows this and then it's a biyatch to get a seat to enjoy aforementioned beer and grub. Fie!
author: Julienne G.

description: Five stars.  Yep.  Five.  A gloriously filthy dive bar with a massive draught beer selection.  I had the Franziskaner, the Aventinus--oh hell, and a couple more that I forgot.  Beer selection seems to change regularly.  Beers priced between $4 and $6 for the most part.  Toronado has become one of my favorite beer joints.  We were fortunate to find parking and a place to park our asses.  Bartender seemed surly, but I thought that pretty much fit the bill for this place.  He was quick and attentive though.  Cash only, but there's an ATM on site.
author: Timothy D.

description: A favorite of mine next to 21st Amendment and Monk's Kettle. Russian River beer is sold here and it is great. Try a beer called The Dissenent.
author: Michael M.

description: This place gets ridiculously crowded on Fri/Sat nights.  However, the beer selection here keeps me coming back.  Also, Rosamunde is next door!
author: Khac L.

description:
Sometimes I love being the only Asian person in joint.  This place is one of those rare SF examples.  Bars should all have this sort of personality.  They had about 50 types of beers listed on the wall and I can't wait to try some more of them on my next trip after heading to the equally awesome sausage grille next door.  

This is also one of those places where the famous $9 SF beer does not live thank god.  I had a 1/2 litre Heff, which outlived my sausage and it cost around $4!
author: patrick o.

description:
I can add nothing to the hundreds of reviews about this place but to agree that the beer selection is unlike anywhere else. 

Not the place to sit and have a conversation though.
author: Inna H.

description:
Broadest selection of domestic and imported beers in Northern California. Small, noisy, very rustic, great atmosphere. A must for anyone who appreciates adult beverages - don't go alone, or you will feel left out. Corral people and go as a group. Park at least a block away so you have to walk through the Haight - that's part of the experience. Don't mind the people on the street - Kalifornia exiles smokers from indoors like all the oher Fascist Utopias - no one will mess with you.

Remember to bring lots of money, because the beer prices are all over the map and you don't want to have to miss out on a special beverage because you didn't bring enough cash. Also, please tip generously - the staff rocks, and they need the cash to make up for having to be on overdrive all night.

If you can, catch this place on a Monday or a Tuesday night when it's mostly locals and less crowded. That's when the really good conversations happen.
author: Gregory M.

description:
I once walked 13 blocks to get sauced on Pliny The Elder at Toronado. I would do it again, right now, if only I were in San Francisco and despite the fact that it's Wednesday in the middle of the work day. This is a bar at which to begin and end your descent into abject alcoholism. If you're looking for some trendy shot bar or swell faux martini cocktail lounge, go somewhere else.   

Dive bar? Check. Huge beer selection? Check. Awesome jukebox? Yessir. Lets you bring in sausage or pizza from the greasy counter joints next door? Sure thing!  If what you crave is amazing beer in a totally unpretentious environment, surrounded by like-minded people NOT trying to look cool, this is your place.
author: Sean F.

description:
I want to give this place 4 stars, but the bartenders are not always that friendly. The beer is killer and they often have a very good selection. The music is loud, the crowd is loud...good elements for a good bar. 
If you like Belgium beers, this is one of the better choices in the city!!
author: JR H.

description: Beer is good. Also, hot dogs next is very smart and tasty. Affordable. Cash only, sucka.
author: Ramin R.

description:
Excellent place to grab a good beer (they have a very nice selection) on the cheap.  Pair it with a sausage from Rosamunde next door (they'll let you bring it to the bar) and it's a match made in heaven.  

Ok.. so it's true that the barstaff can have an attitude.  When I went the last time the bartender was overweight, not the most attractive, and wore a t-shirt that said "I'm the guy you need to blow to get a drink".  When you walk in, he's sizing you up to see what kind of patron you'll be.  

Bottom line:  This is a no frills place to have a beer and maybe a sausage if you're so inclined.  Go there for what it's intended for and you'll have no problems with the bartender.  Order a soda or a water.. and maybe you'll get some attitude.
author: Engelbert H.

description:
the moment you walk into Toronado it becomes painfully clear that with bars, just like anything else, there is a certain gold standard that is a cut above the competition.  Toronado is the gold medal winner in the dive bar category.  It is the type of dive bar that makes you proud to be a blue collar sucker with a beer gut and one pair of levi's that you've worn for the last 234 days.  

Man, talk about the real deal.  I don't know what it is exactly but this place looks, smells, and feels like it belongs.  Toronado is in perfect harmony with the Lower Haight.  Sort of like the Ocean is in perfect harmony with San Francisco.  I had my first "Death and Taxes" there, and nearly cried my eyes off.    Holy shite was that good.  I also had my first Hoegarden there.  It was orgasmic.

This place is inexplicably proper.  It's mad f'in cool.  It's visually pleasing as well.  You can't go wrong here, unless you are, at your very core, wrong.  

Even the name has rhythm.  

Say it.  

Yeah, baby.
author: chris o.

description:
Two men enter... one man leaves...  this is to beer what the octagon is to UFC.  From Pliney The Elder (don't ask) to barleywine ad nausea, the Toronado is the beer drinkers bar... in fact it's been rated one of the best beer bars in the country.

Once the alcohol hits you squarely in the domepiece, feel free to peruse the lovely taps (can you tell the Anderson Valley?  hint: it's the awesome bear) or grab some steaming pizza from Mythic.

Only downside here is the parking... oh and the fact that if you go into too dressy, someone from the beer underworld will try to fight you and make a beer out of your fancy shoes.

but seriously if you're a homebrewer looking for mad love from other homebrewers, brew it up at Toronado.
author: John R.

description:
how dare Yelp categorize this as a dive bar!  That's a total insult.  This is not a dive bar....it is THE dive bar that you hope heaven has in store for you.  Complete with old beer (and "other") smells in every nook and cranny.  

OK, have I scared you away from it now?

...damn, it's that lil' five star rating thing at the top, isn't it?

Why does a stinky, sticky (ever touched the door handle or anything else inside?) dive bar get 5 stars?  It's mecca baby.  Look up the definition.  Great fresh N.W. microbrewed ales, incredible selection of Belgian beers, and the Tamale Lady 'round midnight just in time to save us all from dreaded strong ales on empty stomach-itis.

Dave, the owner, keeps the very cleanest tap system in town--he cleans his tap lines on a very regular basis, so despite the "patina" of the place, we're getting the very cleanest, tastiest, and largest  selection of great ales this side of heaven.  

My only question: is the grafitti in the bathroom as funny to someone who is sober?  Not sure I'll ever know the answer to that one.

Don't forget to pay homage to the old tap handles along the walls--they are artifacts from our irrationally exuberant forefathers in the brewing industry, who laid down their lives so we can now drink quality product.
author: Ken H.

description: Want to go to a place with a large selection of beer, with nothing but amazing tunes, to spend time with friends while in SF? Then go to the Toronado. This place rocks. It's a total dive bar that doesn't pretend to be anything but what it is. The only downside, is it does get annoying to try to yell a conversation, but this place is worth it.
author: Phil M.

description: Best side-by-side combo ever.   Sausage from next door plus beer here.
author: Ted R.

description:
If you like beer, than read no further and get over to the Toronado! Unless it's after hours, of course...

This is a great place to hang with friends and knock back a few. They have a fantastic beer selection, and the fact that you can order a sausage from the joint next door and bring it into the Toronado is pretty cool. Of course, this allows you to get some some food in your belly that allows you to drink more beer, so it works out pretty well for all parties involved.

They have a pretty good jukebox here too, and used to show the Simpsons on Sunday nights (do they still do this?).
author: Art D.

description:
Best beer selection in San Francisco, hands down.  It's not even close.  Try something sour, like the Rodenbach Grand Cru or the Petrus Brown.    Get a sausage next door if they are open.  if it's late, hope the tamale lady comes through.  

Bartenders are hit or miss for friendliness, but who cares?  They are knowledgeable and won't spill your beer. Plus they pump Tool through the stereo system.  That rules.
author: Kevin W.

description: Great beer selection, but not much else as far as alcohol goes. Atmosphere is certainly "dive bar" at its finest. Actually, I had a lot of fun here. No pretense, no frills (no mirrors in the bathrooms ladies!), but a honest good time. Oh, and stop over next door for the beer sausage with spicy chili - it's incredible!
author: Lee D.

description:
If you know of a bar that has a better selection of strange and tasty beers than the Toronado, tell me and I will buy you lots of presents out of gratitude.

Death and Taxes, which they serve, is one of my most favorite beers ever. And who can resist a place that has a wide selection of beers made by monks? For some reason, beer tastes so much better if its makers have taken a vow of chastity.
author: Ben P.

description:
If you're looking for a beer selection+bar this is the place to go. If you're looking for smiles and understanding...try your human resources. 
The place looks decent enough to drink in and their selection should keep you fairly occupied. Yes, they also have TVs. 
Nice!
author: C G.

description:
Picture this: Sunday afternoon, NCAA regional finals, #1 North Carolina vs. #2 Georgetown, huge $7 stein of hoegaarden in front of me, the Misfits screaming from the jukebox, half-eaten rosamunde sausage percolating in my belly, 20 or so Toronado denizens cheering wildly at one small tv screen...Final Score: North Carolina  84 --- Georgetown 96. 

I heart you Toronado. Want to know why? Because much like most of the Lower Haight itself, you root for and relish being the underdog. 5 stars.
author: John T.

description:
Okay, first of all: basketball is dumb.

I headed over here on Tuesday, not realizing that the Warriors/Mavericks game was that night.  I mean, it was fun being in a bar full of rowdy, excited (and ultimately disappointed) people, but I wish they had been excited about something other than basketball.  Because basketball does not excite me.

But enough about me: on to Toronado.  I have problems with making decisions, and knew I'd have trouble picking out a beer (back to me again...), so I picked one from the online menu beforehand, then got there and it wasn't on tap.  Oh well.  I asked what one of the Belgian beers was like, and the bartender, who told us she was about to take out her .44 on the girls sitting at the bar before us (yikes!), belted out, "Alright, you want it?"  "Um, yes please," I said meekly, and she laughed.  "Just kidding!  I'll let ya taste it" and poured some into one of those pretty Belgian beer glasses.  It was delish, so I had her fill the rest of the thing up.   And gave a big tip.  After all, I didn't want her pulling out her .44 on me.

One interesting part of the evening: a bunch of people were doing shots of some German drink that smelled like licorice and claimed to help with digestion and came in tiny little bottles.  That was interesting.
author: Gina K.

description:
My hubby's old roommate practically lives in this bar.  The first time he took us, I was a little dubious because I'm a vodka and whiskey gal.  Beer is good, but I always feel so full after knocking a few back.  I was pleasantly surprised by the fabulous selection of beer and enjoyed every glass I was given.  I tried so many that I don't remember all the names, and each time I have been back I've tried something new.  If only they found a way to bring over some St. Bernardus...

Study the board and know what you want by the time the bartenders come to you.  If you ask if they have something that's not on the board, you'll get the brush off and a blunt, "Look at the board!" Don't be afraid to tell them what you like and ask for something comparable.  They know their beer.  Don't get your feelings hurt if they're short with you when it's busy (which is most of the time).  And get a sausage from next door.  

It's a great place to chill with friends while watching a game.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I was visiting SF for a week and was told I had to visit Toronado.  So I did, several times during that week.  Living in SoCal it's pretty hard to get some of Northern California's best beers, especially some of the really good IPA's.  But at Toronado they aren't just available, they are cheap!  

It seems to get excessively busy, but that's ok.  For beer this good, it's worth it.  

The only thing I don't like is that my plane left the same day that a monk from the Orval Abbey came in for a tasting so I couldn't go.  Bummer.
author: daniel m.

description:
I loves me some PBR, but sometimes a woman's gotta get classy-ish...and that's exactly where Toronado comes into play.

The best beer I've had in the city has been at this bar - and the menu ROTATES. It's not always the same beer...so the beer lover in everyone can get a taste test of different "fancy beer" from all over the world. 

Imagine, if you will, a bar decorated by hundreds of taps, random asshole-inspired stickers, and the rudest (see: quite lovable) bar staff in existence. This is Toronado.

I've been here countless times and I'll continue to come back. That means a lot considering I usually have to wait a decade or so to get a re-fill (and this is the only reason they aren't a 5-star joint, in my book). Yes, this place is popular (and when you taste the beer, you'll see why). 

They also have a rad happy hour every day until 6 p.m. Something like $3 a pint if I remember correctly, but I can never make it there that early.

It's also nice that there's a sausage joint next door that caters to the vegan-class, and Toronado is happy to have the brats in their haus. 

Plus-side: I've never had to wait more than two minutes for the bathroom. As a woman, I will worship a bar when this is the case.


(Funny quip: The last time I was in Toronado, the owner's wife was tending bar. She is a spunky character and anyone without a spine should probably stay away. She'll knock you down about 52 pegs or two and continue to curb-stomp your face...and that's why she rocks. I overheard her make a comment at the bar about Yelp.

"While you're giving me a shitty review for my attitude on Yelp, I'll be kicking my feet up and watching my 50" flat-screen in the comfort of my living room, so who's winning?")
author: Danyell K.

description: Great bar, dive atmosphere, Pliny on tap and many more...but I mostly only care about Pliny. Definitely worth a visit if you enjoy good beer and reasonable prices.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Okay, so I might be slightly biased because I met my boyfriend here... But all mushiness aside, this is such a great place. I love the half door when you enter, giving it a fun, saloon type of feel.

They have a beer for everyone. For those who aren't huge beer drinkers (like myself) -- the framboise lambic is AMAZING. They also have mead (mulled honey wine with spices). Very knowledgeable staff, they are great with recommendations and are usually nice about letting you try another beer if you really don't like what you ordered.

If you're hungry, order a sausage or two from Rosamunde next door before heading to Toronado, and they'll deliver it right to your table just as that first sip of a cold brew is sliding down your throat. mmmmmmm....
author: Jill M.

description:
No frills, no nonsense beer bar. Everything is faded old wood, painted, grafitti'd, and carved over by patrons many times over. The crowd looks decidedly early-late 20s, hipster, with funky hairdos and tattoos to match. Not one shred of a pastel color on any of them.

Where the bar lacks in decorum, dress, or the like, they've channeled into their beer selection, which reads sophisticatedly by region and vintage in a way usually reserved for the haughty wine. If you don't know your beers don't ask the hard-looking bartender with the accent and arm tats, but the female one with the chunky blonde highlights, as she's much more amicable to the unfamiliar.

Happy hours make for cheaper beers, but not really by much. They should consider taking another dollar off to compete with other happy hours. Disappointed to find no trace of bar snacks, not even peanuts or pretzels. You'll be dependent on the sausage shop next door, and hopefully it's open when you're coming to this bar.
author: Clar L.

description:
This...is my kind of place.
More beers than you can shake a fist at and a guest appearance by the Tamale Lady!

This place wasn't too crowded and just the right amount of "dive-iness" that I look for in a bar. I was good and drunk off of delicious brew and barely made it into a cab and home.

Excellent night in my opinion.
author: Erin F.

description:
Almost every person I know who lives in SF brags that they don't have a TV in their house.  That's because most of the bars in SF do, and the Toronado is one of them!

This is a great bar with many fantastic beers ... and a bonus is that the best sausages in the city can not only be purchased next door, but can be brought into the bar and enjoyed with your favorite beer!  This is a kick-ass place to hang out!

.....if only they would turn off those damn TV's!
author: dianthe h.

description:
Toronado bartenders - you ruin beer for enthusiasts and brewers alike - grow up.   

What kind of place actually tries to make having a delicious beer miserable?
author: workingstiff f.

description: The toronado is a great place to sample some of the finest beers and some of the finest haight street discourse with some of the finest SF patrons from the neighborhood. Don't forget to shut the door on your way in, tip the bartenders respectfully, and try not to spill anything. Don't order the cosmo. They don't have that kind of @#$(*@#$ there, I've been advised. They shouldn't have to have it since you can get it across the street anyway. They had Rochefort in bottles, Orval night with the distributor opening some seasonal bottles, I had Kwak on tap out of a nice eccentric Kwak glass. Many many beers on tap. A good beer pub should smell like a brewery a bit. I love the Torondado and God bless the Bay Area.
author: Asher B.

description:
The bartender is bitter and so is the beer. Ask him about the mead.
This place is pretty boring and I'm not sure if the fantastic beer selection makes up for it.

No.

No, it doesn't.

But still, I give it 4 stars.
author: Angela C.

description:
I tried Duchesse De Bourgogne there for the first time and I knew I had found a good spot for tasting.  Going in the middle-to-late afternoon is a good idea if you want to kick back.  It gets a little crowded at night and I can't say that the seating is ideal if you're looking to hang out with friends and conversation.

I can't imagine that I could add much more to the tons of reviews already here.  Stop by there, and try the pizza place next door-- yeah, everybody says to try the sausages, but the pizza was pretty good (after a few pints, anyway).
author: Dan H.

description:
Originally this review was identical to my Rosamunde review but that's not fair. So here is the new, improved, and totally original review.

I was reading another review from some guy whining about how the bartender was a total _________ (insert not nice word here.)  I don't care what anyone says, Johnny is cool. I only go on Tuesdays for the cheesebugers next door so Johnny is the only one I know. Don't piss him off. Don't do stupid things. I saw a guy last week put his beer on top of the jukebox right next to the sign that says, "DON'T PUT YOUR BEER HERE, EVER!" Expect the bartender to yell at you. That doesn't make him a bad person, it makes YOU a bad person.

Toronado is a "dive bar" yes but they only have the best beers there. Johnny is a veritable sommelier of beer. It's a high class dive bar, but in the couple of years I've been going there I've already seen a change. Tourists and yuppies are starting to show up. I saw a guy working on his laptop at the bar. It's not an Internet cafe, people. It's a bar. It's awesome beer. It's dogs drinking beer. Real dogs. No Irish Setters or Pomeranians. I'm talking mutts, pitbulls, and wirey terriers.

I'm not sure where I'm going with this. Whereas I want to see Toronado prosper, I don't want you there. I don't want yuppies, striped shirts, or tourists to take over the place. I want it to be a quiet, cool place where I can hang out and drink my Black Prince Porter. I want to drink next to a dog, an old man, and a rockstar.

Cheers
author: Hunter G.

description: F this place and its fascist sweater wearing following.  Yeah tons of microbrews, I get it.  The interior was drab and the staff was ultra elitist and rude and the crowd was pretty much along those lines as well.  I don't mind a rude bartender or a crowded place but this place just soured me.  The beer I had was fine and in the side room it was chill but jeez there are by far hundreds of better bars in this town, even the block that beat the pants off Toronado.  Keep your beer and your clothing.
author: Sin F.

description: I used to love this bar. It has an amazing selection of craft beers, so I chose to impress my date by taking her here a few weeks ago. (I live on Haight and she isn't from the city) This time I got incredibly rude service. This was on a weekday about 6pm so it was not busy by any means. The bartender (middle aged male with long curly hair) seemed to be deliberately ignoring us. And even when he did service us, it was in the rudest condescending way. My date (who has been a bartender for 7 years, and now manages a bar/grill chain) couldn't believe the way we were being treated. We brought back sushi (they do not serve food there and I have always brought food back in the past with no issues). The bartender was busy socializing most of the time, but when he did finally happen to walk to my end of the bar, and was asked very politely if we could get napkins.... He let out a notable sigh and gave us a serious look of disgust when handing them to me. Like previously mentioned my date has been a bar tender for quite a long time and we would never leave a mess or disrespect a bartender. The wait for the beers was absolutely ridiculous and took us nearly 20 minutes to get served (and the bar was NOT crowded... ...this was not a Friday night there) When I asked if we could switch our beers because they were warm, we were told "No that's how they are supposed to be, you ordered it man" as he rolled his eyes and walked away. I am still shocked that I left a tip but all my friends are bartenders (including my date) so I don't have the heart to not do that. If you get the right bartender then this place is awesome. But they just lost a customer who lives on Haight st.
author: Holmes C.

description: Epic beer selection! Jukebox normally has some variety of rocking tunes. Bartenders are really friendly and knowledgeable, and it's cool how you can bring in sausages from next door. It gets insanely and uncomfortably crowded/loud on weekends, but on a weeknight it's really just fantastic if you're into craft beers.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Abuse and beer is terribly white trash. 

The beer: Fantastic selection.  The only reason to go.

The service: The guy with tattoos and an accent is a good chap.  The woman (who I hear is the owner's wife) is an absolute bitch.  She ignored me for ten minutes because she was so busy yapping with some friends (there were only a dozen of us in the bar).  When she did "notice" me, she snapped at me, "What the fuck is wrong with you?"  

My arm was in a sling because of a motorcycle accident.  You'd think Toronado would give a man a free drink for this.  Not.  I didn't like the tone of her voice, nor did I like the way she treated someone (temporarily) disabled.  

She obviously doesn't like herself.  The fellows next to me told me not to complain about her rudeness because I might be kicked out.  They told me she's the owner's girl and has a history of being rude to customers.  Which is surprising to note, because the music is so damn loud that I'm impressed I could hear their warnings.  

Overall: Great beer, but probably the worst smelling bar in the Lower Haight.   This isn't a dive bar, but it sure smells like one (lots of vomit).  If an older woman is pouring beer, give three signs of the cross and flee quickly.

Update (November 2009): That evil woman is still there.  Do not enter the bar if a woman is serving.  You will be abused.  And for no good reason. 

Lightning was designed for a purpose.

Update (February 2016): She's still there.  Told me she packs a gun.  She's her own caricature.  Still rude.  And threatening.
author: Bryan R.

description: Heck yes, this place rules! But it's the sausages next door tip this into the five star range...
author: Jessie O.

description: I really enjoyed the Prohibition ale for ~$4! and it went well with my hot dog from Rosamunde from next door.
author: Ze Lin X.

description: This is a dive bar that serves big beer...Good tap selection and nice selection of bottles.  The crowd and neighborhood up here seem rough, but then again, I'm a little sheltered.  The place has a hell's angels vibe that makes me sit on the edge of my seat -  fight or flight style.  After a couple beers, that goes away.
author: Layla M.

description:
The beers here will knock you on your ass, fo sho.  Two beers here and I was hammered.  TWO BEERS!  They don't play around.  

However, there are a ton of people in here at night, so it gets really crowded and there aren't too many places to sit or stand without being in the way, so you're constantly dancing around people who are trying to walk around (if you're standing up).
author: Jackee K.

description: I have to agree with K.L. I love the beer selection but the bar staff can be rude. The last time we were there, my boyfriend handed the bartender a $20 for a $5 beer. The bartender only gave him back $5 and refused to believe that my boyfriend gave her a $20. Luckily, the boy was relentless and she gave him back the extra $10 after a big ol' fuss. Haven't been back since. Bleh.
author: Lizette R.

description: This place is usually packed and effing loud most of the time, but they have some of the best beer selection in the city. If you can get a seat, this is a great place to watch the game and drink some high quality beer.
author: Dale S.

description:
The Toronado's taps are among the best in the Bay Area, but you can have a more enjoyable experience if you remember a few simple rules.
1) Don't overdress. No one will be impressed, particularly the bartenders.
2) If you're hungry, stop at the excellent Rosamunde Sausage Grill next door and place your order. Beer loves sausages. You will be told to return in 5-10 minutes to pick it up. You are welcome to bring your sausage in a yellow basket into the bar as long as you clean up after yourself.
3) There really is a caste system at the Toronado; it's the "regulars" and everybody else. If you belong to the latter category, do not expect any conversation or pleasantries or any other sort of human interaction with the bartenders. Don't take it personally, they treat everybody this way.
4) Know what you want. There's a beer board at the back of the bar. Study it and be ready to place your order when the bartender acknowledges you. No questions, no conversation. Grab your beer, tip $1 and find a place to drink it. As you drink your first one, strategize about your second. A session beer, under 5.5% abv (I like Allagash White as my "thinking beer"), is a good start; you can always go higher with your next beers.
5) Get to know your neighbors. Unlike the bartenders, most of your fellow beer drinkers are quite friendly and more than willing to share information and beer knowledge. This can help you make your next beer decision.
6) Finally, try to pick a day and time when it's not likely to be too busy. Mid-afternoons are perfect, even on weekends. The experience is literally night and day.
author: chuck l.

description: This place is beer-lovers' heaven. A huge selection of excellent beer on tap. I was lead here on a search for Pliny and was not disappointed. Oooh, and the Tamale Lady came!..and her tamales were some of the best I've had. It was the holidays and a good third of the menu was comprised of local winter and holiday brews. Wish this place was not so far away.
author: Colleen B.

description:
toranado is a very different place if you go during the day or at night.  I recommend the daytime...  you find a place to sit, you can order your beer right away, and all in all it's just a great place to hang out with friends in the afternoon.  there are very few bars with such a vast selection of good beers, and you can't go wrong with the double IPA!  if you get hungry, stop next door for a sausage and wash it down with your beer.

nighttime is a different story.  it's way too crowded for my taste, meaning there's barely any room to stand/exist and it takes forever to get a drink.  of course that's to be expected on a weekend, but what really bugged me was that the bouncer working the night I went was a douche-bag lunatic.  on a total power trip, which would have been easy to ignore if he wasn't constantly screaming to someone about one thing or another.  the crowd is harmless... there's nothing to yell about.  good thing about nighttime is that chances are, the tamale lady will make an appearance.
author: Jen P.

description:
Great bar for beer, one of the best in the city.  They have an amazing selection and most of the time serve it in the glass which is supposed to be served with the beer.  Very rare for the US.  The only problem about this place is that it's so bright inside.  Why can't they turn down the lights?  
It gets too crowded on the weekends though and sometimes it's hard to move around and get to the bar.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Great dive bar with GOOOOD beers on tap. It gets very, very crowded, though. Eclectic mix of people, as you would expect for this area. Worth checking out if you are in the neighborhood.

PS - get the awesome sausages next door and you can bring them in. MMMM!!!
author: Paul B.

description:
Wow, five stars???? That's like saying Motel 6 is in the same league as a Hilton. Clearly, this place doesn't really deserved it. Honestly if you give out beer, ppl will drink up anywhere, so those who like to drink so much and doesn't care about the surroundings. Go ahead. Well, I am a social drinker, so I don't really end up drinking that much. So I can honest give you a real hand review of this place unlike some others. First off, to first time drinkers, Haights is far from the most clean up area in SF. It's kinda a downer type of bar. The place only take Cash. If you have a Card, I wouldn't even try to use it, as it's seems like they might do something that isn't kewl with it. The good part about the bar is that the drinks are $4 for beers. The baretenders are far from clean, and totally smell like left over bong juice spit.  They are kinda rude as hell. The old man bartender can be such a perv to women. The women there are equally rude as the man. The size of the restroom is small, and smells even worst. Seeing that, it is a bar, and in the Haights. I let that pass. It's somewhat crowded, and most of the drinkers are young. Still, there are better bars than this. 

Supposely it's the best beer in San Francisco, I kinda doubt that, but it's not the worst. Hours: 11:30 AM to 2:00 AM. Happy Hour isn't until 6:00 PM. You can pick from 50 Quality Beers on Draughts and 100 Bottled Bottles. Check it out, if you need a drink.
author: Ivy V.

description: Now as far as finding an awesome beer selection this place is second to none.You can also find bar tender attitude that is second to none as well.And as far as parking there should be a "none" section.
author: Big J.

description:
Beer. Lots of beautiful, glorious, delicious beer. Their menu is always changing and always full of unique, impressive, and often rare beer. You just need to know what you're talking about, they bartenders and most of the patrons take their beer seriously and act as such, so don't expect too much in the way of friendly conversation or advice about what to order, so that drops them a star. But if you like beer (and who doesn't seriously?) this place is fairly close to beer-heaven.

Burp.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Disclaimer: This is only a review of the bathroom. The establishment, as a whole, rocks, aside from the fact that it rocks a little too much sometimes, making it impossible to get more beer.

That said, the bathroom of the Toronado is an undocumented gate to another dimension. Thou shalt not touch anything in the bathroom with thine bare hands. Thou shalt make every attempt to sterilize one's self upon departure, and not touch the door handle or the latch. Thou shalt do one's best to get back to the beer as soon as is humanly possible.

Now, that may sound like the bathroom is gross, and that I don't suggest using it. While I wouldn't suggest dropping the deuce there, I wouldn't suggest that you do that in *any* bar. I mean, come on! Don't you have a home? Do you live in the park? (And seriously, if you live in the park, what are you doing on yelp? Get a goddamned job, already, you dirty slacker!) The Toronado's bathroom rates a four, because, quite simply, it is exactly what a proper beer hall bathroom should be: disgusting, but not to biohazard standards. Just beer hall disgusting. Know what I mean?
author: Poops M.

description: Toronado is Toronado!  If you know your beer then  be prepared to get really excitged or learn something new here.  You can't really rate it because it's really above all other dive bars.   There are one or two bartenders that I keep wondering why they keep them employed there, other than that this bar is my hubby and my second home really!  lol
author: Ingrid Y.

description: Great beer? check. Happy hour prices? check. Sausage next door? check. Good vibe with happy dogs chilling on the ground? Indeed. A great time was had by all.
author: Fudge D.

description:
BEER.  PERIOD.  Toronado is the easily the best beer bar in the city, with over 30 beers on tap, and a whole page front and back of bottled belgian beers.  Try not to be intimidated by the WALL of beer that is the menu, though you almost certainly will be (I was).

yes yes, people complain about the bartenders being beer snobs.  
They are, but they know their stuff.  Don't panic.  here's what you do:

1) When flagging down the bartendere, know what you like, if not the exact beer you want.  Though the bartenders are beer-snobs, they're still friendly.  If you don't know what you want to drink, tell them what type of beer you like, and they'll give tastes of a few beers before you buy.  They are serious about their beer, and like it when you are too.

2) Don't ask for a PBR, Bud, or any of that shite.  

3)  If you have no idea what you like and want to earn the bartender's immediate approval, order an Old Stock barleywine (from the tap if they have it, otherwise just get the bottle).  

[I had a beer here from the bottle called JW Lee's I believe, that was brewed in LAGAVULIN (read:  very smokey/peaty single malt scotch) casks, and it tasted like honey ham...delicious... I kid you not.  Don't miss the barleywine festival.  If you didn't know, Barleywine has like 15% alcohol, and is basically really really strong beer, that is usually really really tasty.]

4) Go buy a gourmet sausage from Rosamunde grill, next door, and enjoy it with your beer at the Toronado.  Rosamunde rents their space from the Tornado, and the grillmaster at Rosamunde will even come bus tables in the Toronado every once in a while (though you really should bring the baskets back for the guy).  My Rosamunde review (and guide) http://www.yelp.com/biz/g9LSMqUK5dkUcmpgTnU-dQ?hrid=hkxBnEpt1MAu_busmemIhg


Attn:  wine snobs...the Toronado will make you love your beer with a passion.
author: Fong L.

description:
The number of beer choices makes my head spin.  I drink IPAs and haven't been too happy with the choices at most SF bars.  Toronado has at least 6 or 7 good selections.  

I probably won't ever come here just to hang out and drink, but with a sausage from next door it hits the spot.
author: Katie S.

description:
Despite the divey atmosphere, what a lot of people don't seem to understand is that Toronado's the beer version of an upscale wine bar or cigar shop. If you don't know what you're up for, the condescending bastards behind the bar will be sure to remind you of it.


 All that aside HOLY MULTITUDE OF BEERS TO BEAT YOUR LIVER INTO SUBMISSION WITH, BATMAN! Not only are there a load of beers on tap, but they constantly rotate. So you have to keep going back, and going back, and yeah.


 A couple of winning aspects: They have Cask Ales. That's right, that gross, flat room-temperature stuff that comes out from a hand pump. Beautiful! Also, one of the nicer laundromats in town is across the street. Go put in a few loads, get loaded, and call it a great Sunday afternoon.
author: Omid T.

description: I was pretty excited when I saw that SF had a Toronado- and I wondered if it was anything like San Diego's, so my friend and went in and grabbed some beers- from comparing it to the one down here- apparently they are the same thing- but obviously different- I'd say I liked the atmosphere a lot better up there then the one down here, but the beer selection definitely wasn't as large. Over-all, the staff was great, and the loaded me up with different "testers" to figure out which beer I wanted next. I'll definitely be visiting again.
author: Megan L.

description: There is a special fondness in my heart for any establishment of this size that offers upwards of 50 (where I stopped counting) different beers on tap. The selection always blows me away here....it really is HEAVEN for any beer lover. My favorite way to end an afternoon is to take a little stroll through the beautiful and charming Lower Haight with Jason H. and arrive at Toronado to enjoy the bounty of beer that awaits.
author: Emily S.

description: Good selection, but when I leave, I feel like I need a shower, a hot shower with plenty'o'soap.
author: eric w.

description:
Scenario: Barley Wine Festival!  OMG!

Product: SO.  MUCH.  BEER.  Toronado has such a wide selection of beverages.  And it gets even better during Barley Wine Fest.  Prices are very reasonable, and that's another reason I love coming here.

Service: They serve it up quick and cold.  What else could you ask for?

Atmosphere: It's very dark inside and pretty much always full of people.  I like to sit in the back room on the comfy couches and watch some sports on the tube.  The neighborhood is great and Memphis Minnie's BBQ is right across the street.

Uniquity: The wide selection of beers, great location, and chill, unpretentious atmosphere make this a wonderful bar.
author: Robert R.

description:
Yeah, the guys that work here can be a little gruff, but that's the charm of this place. There's oodles of fun stuff on the walls and on the bar stools to look at. Not a place to pick up chicks or win a popularity contest, but its the beer lover's answer to the growing trend of 'too-cool-for-school' wine and cocktail bars. 

They really do have an unparalleled selection of intensely good beer. They have beer, beer, and nothing more than beer, but feel free to bring back some Memphis Minnie's or Rosamunde's to complement your Double IPA or Oatmeal Stout.
author: Brandon B.

description:
This place is just a solid.  I love beer, and this is THE place for beer in San Francisco.  It's a complete sausage fest--and I am not talking about having Rosamunde next door (which is fantastic).  I mean it is just full of guys, and the women are few and far between.  Also, if you are a woman, the guys are not the best looking around.  
BUT, that's not why you come here.  You come here for an INCREDIBLE selection of beer on tap, and a grungy-hip vibe that certain people (like me) love.   
Nothing is better than a night out with some friends, beers at Toronado, and a surprise visit by the Tamale lady.
author: Blake W.

description:
One of the best beer bars in SF. Next door there is an awesome sausage shop. Get a brat and take it back to Toronado and savor it with a fine glass of beer.

They just opened a Toronado in San Diego, and I love it. The place doesn't have the feel of the original Toronado in SF--but how could any place replicate the essence of the Haight?
author: Liana V.

description:
So what they say is true!  This dingy Haight institution has a helluva draft selection packed into a stinky, endearing little dutch door-ed heaven.  The bartender meant business as he asked for our selection: 

Delirium Tremens

They have this stuff on tap!  It's hard to find, has an obscene amount of punch, and is named for my favorite life-threatening manifestation of alcohol withdrawal!

Keeping us company were all sorts of characters, both human, canine and in-between.  All that would have made this perfect would have been a sausage from next door.  

Next time, as I will return.
author: Eric S.

description:
Bitburger Pils with a Merquez from Rosamunde...My idea of heaven on earth.  Love the bartenders here...so nice ,funny and knowledgeable

Huge selection..

Oh,there is an adorable dog that hangs out,looks up at you with sweet,pleading eyes...He obviously wanted a bite of Rosamunde...and of course we obliged him.
author: Bleep S.

description: Though I missed the SF Beer Week Barley Wine festival at Toronado (Feb 14th), the beer kept on flowing 'til Sunday .  Nearly 40 different varieties and $2 3oz. samples!  I had the chance to try some beer I would otherwise be unable to find just about anywhere, as well as a few favorites from Russian River and Stone.  A great time with good friends...I plan to hit this up again next year.
author: Chris R.

description:
This place doesn't need another reveiew.  But there are two reasons I'm writing one:

(a) Not every review is 5 stars!  WTF, people?  Don't you understand that this THE PLACE to go in SF for beer?  I mean, if you don't want to drink it at a picnic table with 50 of your best friends, I mean (see "Zeitgeist").

(b) I need to add it to my yelp-list of Best Beer in SF.

So: Like I just said, best beer in SF.  Beer snobbery?  Bullshit; just don't act pretentious and you won't get pretension back.  Ask the bartender what goes perfectly with your vegan spicy-tofu sausage with mango chutney from next door (see "Rosamunde"), get an Affligem Blonde.  Let your friend order you a shot of Underberg (see "Fernet"; "cough syrup").  Have a Chimay because you can no longer make decisions and you know it's good.  Show up to meet the guy who's looking at the room for rent in your apartment already drunk, at 8pm.

Step 3?  Profit!!

I [heart] Toronado.  This is on my "Things That Made Me Move To California" list.  Actually, maybe I should make one of those, too ...
author: Nori H.

description:
I give this place 3 stars only because Rosamundes is next door with some fantastic sausages, otherwise it would be 2.  A place with a good beer selection and no atmosphere is called a liquor store, throw in some atmosphere and you have what I would call a bar.  This place is lit like a damned runway- aren't dive bars with crap attitudes supposed to be so dark you can't tell a $10 from a $20?  

Why, yes they are.  

But as with every dark cloud there is a silver lining, bring your own friends and definitely your own women, and you can sample some tasty Barley Pops here,  and if you mistakenly wear a collar or wash your hair before entering and are thrown out then cry the whole 20 feet to the next bar- like Noc Noc where it is dark and oh so wonderfully cave like...
author: Johnny G.

description:
Cool Spot.

Verry very low key.  

Two very cool things about this place.

1st:  The Beer selection is Amazing.  They change the beers on tap really really often. I've also heard that you should ask  to see the 750 ml  menu at the bar, as you can get some cool specialty beers .

2nd.  The fact that you can bring sausages in from Rosamunde and not feel guilty about it.   The sausages are BOMB and nothing washes a spicy sausage down like a nice beer.
author: Adam L.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet - it's one of my all-time favorite drinking spots in the city! Watch out for the Drake's Imperial Stout - it's a killer so I recommend you make that one of your early pints. I first went to Toronado's for their barley wine festival. I highly recommend it and can't wait until next year's. You can sample 40-50 different kinds of barley wine and after a handful, you're toast! All of the beers there are high in alcohol content and reasonably priced so it's definitely worth the trek out if you don't live nearby.

P.S. If you've been to Ann Arbor and/or read my reviews from there, then this place JUST might beat Ashley's (eek, i never thought i'd say such a thing!). Remember, friends don't let friends drink cheap beer.
author: Susan L.

description:
One of the best bars in SF for all sorts of reasons but the top four are thus:

1. Cheap
2. One of, if not The, best tap set in SF
3. Loads of character
4. Rosamudes sausages for the drunk munchies
author: M L.

description:
I like to sample the strange and wonderful beers that this place features.  English Ales Porter, for instance.  That stuff is good.

EDIT 2018
Having been coming here consistently for the past ten years, I had to finally give Toronado it's fifth star. 

It's loud and often crowded, and sometimes it takes longer than you'd like to get a beer, and sometimes some wild stuff happens, but it's still the number one true dive bar for beer connoisseurs in the city. 

It's an institution.  You can find stuff on tap here that you won't find anywhere else, and it's still at dive bar prices.

We should all appreciate it while it's still around.
author: Gopal R.

description:
While the Toronado has great beer selection, and I love a good beer, often times I do not want to deal with the crowd or the noise.  I am not a fan of the music that is pumped out of the jukebox usually.  They have a great happy hour that lasts until 6pm everyday except the weekend.    I usually want to chat with my mates over beer, and the Toronado is not as conducive to having conversations as other bars.  

The 4 stars is strictly for the quality of the beverages being served.
author: Asher Y.

description:
Beer selection: 
Amazing.  More beer on tap than I could try in a week of going there every night.  The bottle list is even better.

Tried:
 An imperial stout on tap (great, sweet but with good bitterness) + The Abyss (also a stout, but aged in bourbon & oak barrels)

The Service: 
To the point, no nonsense, friendly-enough.  When we ordered the large bottle of The Abyss, the bartender stopped at the table later and asked us about it. He seemed to sincerely want to know if we liked it, and if he should try it.

The Ambiance: It wasn't overly loud even on a Friday with a Sharks game ending and a Giants game starting. But it did get more crowded after 8.

Would I go there again? Absolutely.  Would I make it my home for drinking? Maybe.
author: B R.

description:
Until the past couple of years, the best beer selection in the city.  Lately, however, other places have caught up (Monk's Kettle, La Trappe, City Beer), and some have the attractive option of actually having FOOD with your beer.

Also, there is one guy who works the bar and has the most extreme attitude I've ever come across.  If I walk in and he's working I immediately turn around and head over to Noc Noc instead.
author: Mike J.

description:
read first: it gets crowded, but on thursdays later on in clears out and you can sit. cash only, if you forget, there's a photo of johnny cash giving you the finger to remind you, "cash only."

if they asked me, and i know they didn't, they should post up someone out front checking IDs: pay him with beer, food whatever, but do it. hard enough to fight for a spot at the bar and order beers without having to drag the other four people you came with so we can all show you our IDs, followed by an unpleasant exchange with the bartender when you try to order three beers. just check IDs at the door when it gets crowded.

phew, actually this place is awesome, as others have rightfully noted. the beer selection is diverse and excellent, featuring lots of local breweries and new releases from all over. if you haven't done so, try a russian river brewco or moonlight brewco beer. rosamunde is next door if you get hungry. parking is street, or do yourself a favor and take the 6, drops off right in front, or take the N and walk a few blocks. always a few cask ales available, and once things settle down the bartenders can recommend a good brew. beer!
author: Christopher V.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm a beer nut. By default, this makes Toronado beer heaven. There are hundreds of beers on tap, many in bottles, and definitely a few you won't find in any store. I recommend "Pliny the Elder". It's a double IPA and based on (un)scientific research, their most popular beer. The bartender referred to it as "liquid crack" and I couldn't agree more. 
It can get a bit crowded and it can take some time to get the bartender's attention, but it's worth the wait. 
Bottom line: definitely a great place to meet some friends, sip some suds, and jam to cuts off Led Zeppelin I.
author: Matt F.

description: I don't know why there is so much talk about the service and people being nasty.  The  bartenders are always super nice, I've even gotten some free drinks.  The beer selection is overwhelming but nicely advertised so even those with bad eyesight can read the menu.
